record.title: Insert 01-Inside flap
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: The Fine Arts Festival of the 1939 Summer Session of the University of Iowa will bring to the campus of that institution many distinguished guest artists, teachers, dramatists, and recitalists. Many of the visitors will serve as members of the faculty of the School of Fine Arts dur¬ ing the entire Summer Session. Examination of the Festival program will disclose rich offerings m each of the fields of the fine arts. The State University of Iowa is developing a Fine Arts campus of notable beauty. The buildings are architecturally distinguished and adequately equipped. The Iowa Union, containing the general auditorium for the Festival, and the Univer¬ sity Theatre will be serviced by air cooling machinery of the latest design from the begin¬ ning of the Summer Session of 1939. Art Exhibitions Band and Choral Concerts Chamber Music Conferences Dramas Lectures Oratorios Radio Plays Recitals Symphonies Together ^vith all of the general advantages of the Summer Session of one of America's great Universities on a campus notable for its beauty. University of Iowa Libraries

record.full-text: THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF IOWA Eugene A. Gilmore, President Summer Session, June 10 - August 25 Paul C. Packer, Summer Session Director George F. Kay, Dean of College of Liberal Arts Earl Enyeart Harper, Director of School of Fine Arts DEPARTMENT OF ART Lester D. Longman, Head Jean Chariot, Grant Wood, Donald Mattison, Charles Okerbloom, Jr., Harry Stinson, Edna Patzig, Francis McCray The faculty of the Department of Art, including Grant Wood, and augmented by Jean Chariot and Donald Mattison, will teach courses during the Summer Session. A complete curriculum will be offered in oil, tempera, fresco, and water-color painting, life drawing and painting, sculpture, lithography, etching, illustration, design, and the history of art. DEPARTMENT OF DRAMATIC ART E. C. Mabie, Head Paul Green, Vance M. Morton. H. D. Sellman. A. S. Gillette, E. P. Conkle, William D. Coder, Jllheodore yiehman^ Helejn_EQU:esl^.^L^ Earl Seigfred. Peter-Marroney,-John-C-^l- ton, Jr. Members of the regular faculty of the Department of Dramatic Art will offer a full range of gradu¬ ate and undergraduate courses during the Summer Session. Opportunity will be afforded for participation in plays and observation of direction and production. Mr. Paul Green will join the faculty during the period of the Fine Arts Festival. DEPARTMENT OF MUSIC Philip Greeley Clapp, Head Modeste Alloo. Thompson Stone. Charles B. Righter. Hans Muenzer, Hans Koelbel, Esther M. Swisher, Addison Alspach, Herald I. Stark. H. C. Stump, Ansel Martin, Vivian M. Robe, Ardith Larson, Margaret Brandt, Thomas Muir, Himie Voxman, Howard Snyder, Arnold Small, Otto Jelinek, Thomas Collins, Lorene Liston, Paul Dawson, William Gower, Alan Richardson, Charles Eble. The music faculty, inckiding Modeste Alloo and Thompson Stone, will teach throughout the en¬ tire Siunmer Session. A full curriculum is offered in theoretical and applied music at the gradu¬ ate and undergraduate levels with participation and teacher training in chorus, orchestra, band, and chamber music. A rare opportunity will be afforded to observe the daily work of the All- State High School musical organizations. FINE ARTS FESTIVAL COMMITTEE Earl Enyeart Harper, Philip Greeley Clapp, Frederic G. Higbee, Lester D. Longman, Edward C. Mabie, Bruce E. Mahan, Frederick M. Pownall. For further information address Director of the School of Fine Arts, University of Iowa, Iowa City, Iowa. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Insert 02-Page 01
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: The State university of Iowa IOWA CITY. IOWA Office of the Director SCHOOL OF FINE ARTS June, 1939 Dear Friends of the Fine Arts: The State University of Iowa believes that the Fine Arts are of vital practical importance In human life. In accordance with this belief, the School of Fine Arts was organized ten years ago. This summer witnesses the inauguration of a unique and comprehensive Festival of Fine Arts in which each of the three Fine Arts for which curricula have been provided by the University will be represented by a com¬ plete program. A fourth, architecture, will be represented by an internationally distinguished artist and lecturer. RECITAL BY LAWRENCE TIBBETT Mr. Tibbett will present a recital in the Field House, July 19, at 8:15 o'clock p.m. General admission, $1.00; reserved seats, $1.50. Mail orders with check or money order enclosed may be sent to Mr. Charles S. Gallher, Field House, State University of Iowa, Iowa City, Iowa. WORLD-PREMIERE IN THE THEATER The University Theater will be the scene of the world-premiere of "Paul and the Blue Ox" by Ellsworth P. Conkle, author of "Prologue to Glory," July 17 and 18. Friday evening, July 21, and Saturday afternoon and evening, July 2)^, "The House of Connelly" by Paul Green will be produced with Mr. Green personally directing. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Insert 02-Page 02
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: Admission to the Theater, $1.00. Mail orders may be addressed to Professor E. C. Mabie, University Theater, State University of Iowa. CONCERTS Concerts except the recital by Mr. Tibbett will be presented in the Lounge of the Iowa Memorial Union. Admission will be free, by ticket which may be obtained in the Lobby of the Union. Requests by mail for free tickets for any or all concerts should be ad¬ dressed to the Director of the School of Fine Arts, State University of Iowa, with enclosed addressed and stamped envelope* FINE ARTS LUNCHEONS The philosophy vdiich underlies the organiza¬ tion and development of the School of Fine Arts at the State University of Iowa will be discussed each day, Monday to Friday, July 17-21 inclusive, at luncheons In the River Room of the Iowa Union and Saturday morning in the House Chamber of the Old Stone Capitol. A series of distinguished artists, including Messrs. Grant Wood, Lawrence Tibbett, and Frank Lloyd Wright will speak at these meetings. Attendance at the luncheons will be limited to 300. Tickets, sixty-five cents, may be ob¬ tained in the Union Lobby or hry mail order addressed to the Director of the School of Fine Arts, State University of Iowa. ART EXHIBITIONS During the period of the Festival forty pic¬ tures from the Corcoran Gallery will be hung in the Art Building. Twelve representative works by Grant Wood, and seventeen by Marvin Cone will be hting in the Lounge of Iowa Union. Catalogs will be provided. Admission will be free. PERSONNEL OF MUSICAL ORGANIZATIONS The University Symphony Orchestra is comprised of experienced graduate students, unusually talented un¬ dergraduate students, and a ntimber of first rank profes¬ sional artists. This orchestra must be compared with professional symphony orchestras for technical profi¬ ciency, tone quality, and interpretative ability. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Insert 02-Page 03
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: The Chamber Music Organization which will be heard in concert Monday night, July 17, is comprised of widely known professional artists. The University Chorus is comprised of graduate, professional, and undergraduate students in the depart¬ ment of Music, talented singers enrolled in the Univer¬ sity, and experienced singers from church choirs and community choral organizations of Iowa City and neighbor¬ ing towns. The membership of the Summer Session Symphonic Band is drawn from the famous University of Iowa Band, augmented by summer school students, many of whom are professional band conductors in universities and high schools throughout the United States. The All-State musical organizations are com¬ prised of outstanding high school players and singers selected from over the entire state. Practically every member of the All-State orchestra, band, and chorus has won state or national recognition as a high school musician. All-State instrumentalists and singers are brought to the University campus and maintained In resi¬ dence for a period of five weeks in preparation for their special contribution to the Fine Arts Festival. LECTURES AND RADIO BROADCASTS The distinguished American architect, Frank Lloyd Wright, will lecture Friday night, July 21, on the west lawn of the Old Stone Capitol. He will speak again and lead a discussion in the House Chamber of the Old Stone Capitol Saturday morning, at 9:00 o'clock. This will take the place of the Art Luncheon on that date. Philip Greeley Clapp will lecture on History and Appreciation of Music each afternoon, Monday to Friday inclusive, at 2:00 p.m. The lectures, which will be delivered in the North Hall of the Music Studio Build¬ ing, will be open only to a limited public, but each lecture will be broadcast by Radio Station WSUI. Many other lectures by members of the Summer Session faculty of the State University of Iowa will be made available to the public by special announcement during the week of the Fine Arts Festival. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Insert 02-Page 04
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: During the Festival, Radio Station WSUI will broadcast feature events of the Fine Arts Festival, and will likewise present a ntimber of special programs in¬ cluding radio drama. SUMMER COMFORT For the comfort of the students of the Summer Session, and particularly of those who take part in or attend the Festival of Fine Arts, the Iowa Memorial Union and the University Theater have been completely air- conditioned. Cool comfort will be experienced in any weather or in any temperature. RICH OFFERING - LOW COST The cost of spending the entire week of July sixteen to twenty-three on the campus of the State Uni¬ versity of Iowa in attendance upon the Fine Arts Festival will be very low, owing to a generous arrangement by which the University provides tickets of admission to the majority of events free of charge. CALENDAR OF EVENING EVENTS Sunday, July 16 Monday, July 17 Tuesday, July 18 Wednesday, July 19 Thursday, July 20 Friday, July 21 Saturday, July 22 Sunday, July 23 Concert, Symphony Orchestra Concert, String Quartet Play, "Paul and the Blue Ox" Concert, Symphonic Band and All-State Chamber Orchestra Play, "Paul and the Blue Ox" Recital, Lawrence Tibbett Concert, All-State Symphony Orchestra and Chorus Lecture, Frank Lloyd Wright Play, "The House of Connelly" Play, "The House of Connelly" Oratorio, Verdi Requiem University of Iowa Libraries

record.full-text: Program Note Tradition says you shall never tell a Paul Bunyan tale as you heard or read it. Tradition says you shall embellish it with in¬ vention and innovation which you by some peculiar intuition, or hear-say, know to be true. record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: PROGRAM Overture to the Opera, "Le Roi d'Ys" Lalo Double Concerto in A minor for violin and cello, opus 102 Brahms Allegro Andante Vivace non troppo Intermission Symphony in E flat, "The Pioneers" Clapp (first performance) "The Pioneers" is based upon the conception of those vigorous early settlers who, in the face of the gravest hardships, persisted in pushing on into the unknown until they had conquered a continent. There is no attempt at realistic depiction o£ single episodes in narrative sequence, but the composer has attempted to express some suggestion o£ the ad¬ venturous spirit which actuated the pioneers, contrasts between their exuberance of spirit and the grief and hardships which beset them, and finally the indomitable spirit which finally triumphed over all obstacles and consummated in the building of a nation. No traditional melodies or folk songs are used in the composition; but one lyrical theme which recurs a number of times is deliberately composed in imitation of the ballads of the period (mostly Scotch-Irish or English in origin), and the march-like theme which occurs early in the composition and gradually assumes more and more importance in the development until it becomes the basis of the final climax is like¬ wise composed in direct imitation of some of the old time march and dance tunes. The Symphony consists of two connected movements, to be played without pause; the first is in the usual form of a symphonic first movement, while the second is a set of free variations on the march theme referred to above. P. G. C. University of Iowa Libraries

(What Affliction) Soprano, Mezzo-Soprano and Tenor e-Rex tremendae (King of Glories) Quartet and Chorus f—Recordare (Ah! Domine Jesu (Oh, Lord God) Offertory for Soprano, Mezzo-Soprano, Tenor and Bass 4. Sanctus (Holy) Fugue for Txvo Choirs Intermission 5. Agnus Dei (Lamb of God) Soprano, Mezzo-Soprano and Chorus 6. record.title: Page 44
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: I. REQUIEM AND KYRIE Solo Quartet and Chorus Requiem aeternam dona eis, Eternal rest give unto them, O Lord, Domine, et lux perpetua luceat eis. and let perpetual light shine on them. Te decet hymnus, Deus, in Sion, Thou, O God, art praised in Zion, and et tibi reddetur votum in Jerusa- unto Thee shall the vow be performed in lem. Jerusalem. Fxaudi orationem meam, ad te Hear my prayer, unto Thee shall all omnis caro veniet. flesh come. Kyrie eleison, Christe eleison. Lord have mercy! Christ have mercy. n. DIES IRAE Four Solo Parts and Chorus Chorus Dies irae, dies ilia, Day of vengeance, lo! that morning. Solvet saeclum in favilla On the earth in ashes dawning. Teste David cum Sibylla. David with the Sibyl warning! Qiiantus tremor est futurus, Ah! what terror is impending, Quando Judex est venturus. When the Judge is seen descending, Cuncta stride discussurus. And each secret veil is rending! Bass and Chorus Tuba mirum spargens sonum, To the Throne, the trumpet sounding. Per sepulchra regionum, Through the sepulchres resounding, Coget omnes ante thronum. Summons all with voice astounding. Mors stupebit et natura. Death and Nature, maz'd, are quaking. Cum resurget creatura. When the grave's deep slumber breaking, Judicanti responsura. Man to judgment is awaking. Mezzo-Soprano and Chorus Liber scriptus proferetur, Now the written book containing In quo totum continetur, Record to all time pertaining. Untie mundus judicetur. Opens tor the world's arraigning. Judex ergo, cum sedebit, See the Judge, his seat attaining, Quidquid latet apparebit. Darkest mysteries explaining. Nil inultum remanebit. Nothing unavenged remaining! Trio—Soprano, Mezzo-Soprano and Tenor ihiid sum miser tunc dicturus, What shall I then say unfriended, Qiiem patronum rogaturus. By what advocate attended. Cum vix Justus sit securus? When the just are scarce defended? Quartet and Chorus Rex tremendae majestatis. King of Majesty tremendous. Qui salvandos salvas gratis, By the saving grace defend us; Salva me, fons pietatis. Fount of piety, safety send us. Duet—Soprano and Mezzo-Soprano Recordare, Jesu pie, Jesus, think of thy wayfaring. Quod sum causa tuae viae; For my sins the death-crown wearing; Ne me perdas ilia die. Save me in that day despairing. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 45
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: Quaerens me sedisli lassus, Redemisti crucem passus, Tantus labor non sit cassus. Juste Judex ultionis, Donum fac remissionis, Ante diem rationis. Ingemisco tamquam reus. Culpa rubet vultus meus, SuppUcanti parce Deus. Qui Mariam absolvisti, Et latronem exaudisti, Mihi quoque spem dedisti. Preces meae non sunt dignae, Sed tu bonus fac benigne, Ne perenni cremer igne. Inter oves locum praesta, Et ab haedis me sequestra, Statuens in parte dextra. Confutatis maledictis, Flammis acribus addictis, Voca me cum benedictis. Oro supplex et acclinis, Cor contritum quasi cinis, Gere curam mei finis. Lacrymosa dies ilia, Qua resurget ex favilla, Judicandus homo reus. Huic ergo parce Deus. Pie Jesu Domine, Dona eis requiem. Amen. Worn and weary thou hast sought me. By Thy cross and passion bought me. Spare the hope Thy labor's brought me. Righteous Judge of retribution, Give, O give me absolution, Ere that day of dissolution. Tenor Solo As a guilty culprit groaning. Flushed my face, my errors owning. Spare, O God, Thy suppliant moaning. Thou to Mary gav'st remission, Heard'st the dying thief's petition, Bad'st me hope in my contrition. In my prayers no worth discerning. Yet on me Tliy favor turning. Save me from Thy endless burning! Give me when Thy sheep confiding, Thou art from the goats dividing, On Thy right a place abiding. Bass Solo and Chorus When the ^vicked are rejected. And to bitter flames subjected. Call me forth with thine elected. Low in supplication bending. Heart as though with ashes blending. Care for me when all is ending. Quartet and Chorus When on that dread day of weeping, Guilty man in ashes sleeping. Wakes to his adjudication. Save him, God, from condemnation. Lord Jesus, all-pitying. Grant them rest. Amen. III. DOMINE JESU Offertory for the Four Solo Voices Domine Jesu Christe, Rex Lord Jesus Christ, King of Glory, de- Gloriae, libera aninias omnium liver the souls of all the faithful dead fidelium defunctorum de poenis from the punishment of hell, and from inferni et de profundo lacji: the deep lake. Libera eas de ore leonis, ne ab- sorbeat eas tartarus, ne cadant in obscurum; sed signifer sanctus Michael repraesentet eas in lucem sanctam; quam olim Abrahue promisisti et semini ejus. Hostias et preces tibi, Domine, laudis offerimiis; tu suscipe pro animabus illis, quarum hodie memoriam fucimus. Faceas, Do¬ mine, de morte transire ad vitam, quam olim Abrahae promisisti et semini ejus. Deliver them from the lion's mouth; let not hell swallow them, let them not fall into darkness; but let Saint Michael, the standard bearer, bring them into the holy light which once thou didst promise to Abraham and his seed. Offerings of prayer and praise we bring Thee, O Lord; receive them for those souls whom today we coinmemorate. Let them go from death to that life which once tliou didst promise to Abraham and his seed. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 46
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: IV. SANCTUS Fugue for Two Choirs Sanctus, sanctus, sanctus, Domi- Holy, holy, holy. Lord God of Hosts! iius Deus Sabaoth. Pleni sunt coeli Heaven and earth are full of Thy glory. et terra gloria tua. Hosanna in Hosanna in the highest. excelsis. Benedictus, qui venit in nomine Blessed is He that cometh in the name Domini. Hosanna in excelsis. of the Lord. Hosanna in the highest! Intermission V. AGNUS DEI Soprano, Mezzo-Soprano and Chorus Agnus Dei, qui tollis peccata Lamb of God, that taketh away the mundi, dona eis requiem.. Agnus sins of the ivorld, grant them rest. Lamb Dei, qui tollis peccata mundi, dona of God, that taketh away the sins of eis requiem sempiternam. the world, grant them rest everlasting. VI. LUX AETERNA Trio—Mezzo-Soprano, Tenor and Bass Lux aeterna luceat eis, Domine, Let perpetual light shine on them, O cum Sanctis tuis in aeternum, quia Lord, with thy saints forever, for thou pius es. are gracious. Requiem aeternam dona eis, Eternal rest give unto them, O Lord, Domine, et lux perpetua luceat eis. and let perpetual light shine upon them. VIL LIBERA ME Solo for Soprano—Chorus and Final Fugue Libera me, Domine, de morte Deliver me, O Lord, from eternal aeterna, in die ilia tremenda, death, in that dread day when the quando coeli movendi sunt et terra, heavens and the earth shall be moved, dutn veneris judicare saeculum f)er when thou shalt come to judge the ignem. world by fire. Tremens faclus sum ego et I am full of tenor and fear at the timeo, dum discussio venerit atque judgment that shall come and at the Ventura ira, quaiido coeli movendi coming of thy wrath, when the heavens sunt et terra. and the earth shall be moved. Dies irae, dies ilia, calamitatis. Day of \vrath, dread day of calamity et miseriae, dies magna et amara and misery, dread day of bitter sorrow. vnlde. Requiem aeternam dona eis. Do- Eternal rest give unto them, O Lord, tnine, et lux perpetua luceat eis. and let perpetual light shine on them. The finale is extremely quiet; absolute silence on the part of the audience is desirable, in order that the effect may not be marred. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Fine Arts Festival, University of Iowa, July 16-23, 1939
record.description: Festival included a panel featuring Grant Wood, Paul Green, Lawrence Tibbett, and Frank Lloyd Wright; an exhibition of paintings by Grant Wood and Marvin Cone; a graduate student art exhibition; plays and musical performances.

record.full-text: 'T* HE Fine Arts Festival at the University of lovv'a was established in the Summer ¦*- Session of 1939. Concerts, plays, art exhibitions, lectures, and radio programs are presented each year. This summer, for the first time, a major exhibition of con' temporary art is included. It is hoped that it will be an annual event and that it will become known to art lovers as the 'Iowa Summer Show." From the works of art shown each year the University expects to purchase representa' tive examples for its permanent collection. A jury, composed of the head of the art department and two invited artists or critics will select twelve works of art and from these the University will make its purchases. An organization to be known as the Iowa Art Association, Inc. is being formed to cooperate with representatives of the School of Fine Arts in presenting the annual exhibition and in securing additional funds for purchases. This first exhibition is composed of the work of artists who are citi2;ens of the United States or working in this country. It consists largely of paintings in oil with a small selection of work in other media. In succeeding years, however, sculpture, prints and drawings, and the art of other countries will also be shown. Lester D. Longman, Head of the Art Department at the University of Iowa, made the selection and was chairman of the jury. The other members of the jury were Lucile Blanch, artist of Woodstock, New York, and Henry R. Hope, Head of the Art Department at the University of Indiana. Nearly all the paintings are for sale. Prices are posted in the exhibition galleries. Educational institutions, art museums, and private collectors of the Middle West will find the summer show at Iowa a convenient occasion for making purchases. The University thanks the artists and collectors who have contributed paintings to the exhibition and gratefully acknowledges the helpful cooperation of the following New York Galleries: A. C. A., 63 East 57th St. Art of This Century, 30 W. 57th St, Assoc. Am. Artists, 711 5th Ave., and 846 N. Michigan Ave., Chicago Babcock, 38 East 57th St. Brandt, 15 East 57th St. Downtown, 43 East 51st St. Durlacher, 11 East 57th St. Ferargil, 63 East 57th St. Kleemann, 65 East 57th St. Kraushaar, 32 East 57th St. Levitt, 16 West 57th St. Levy, 42 East 57th St. Macbeth, 11 East 57th St. Midtown, 605 Madison Ave. Milch, 108 West 57th St. New Art Circle, 41 East 57th St. Nierendorf, 53 East 57th St. Perls, 32 East 58th St. Pierre Matisse, 41 East 57th St. Rehn, 683 5th Ave. Rosenberg, 16 East 57th St. Valentine, 55 East 57th St. Weyhe, 794 Lexington Ave. Willard, 32 East 57th St. Earl E. record.title: Page 06

record.full-text: FOREWORD The purpose of this exhibition is to present to University students and to people in this part of the country a cross'section of progressive painting in the United States. The function is educational, not merely informative. Often exhibitions are designed instead to illustrate every current type of painting regardless of merit. These are easier to organize, but they are less exciting; they generate less discussion and the excess pic¬ tures are distracting. In this exhibition as in most others there are some regrettable omissions, when leading artists had no work available in New York which would repre- sent them well. Nevertheless the frontiers of experimentation are shown as well as much discriminating work of less controversial character. Perhaps the most salient inference from the exhibition is that our terminology in the discussion of modern art is rapidly becoming obsolete. Fewer paintings are pure sur- realism, abstraction, expressionism, neo-romanticism, or sociallyconscioLis realism. In¬ stead many subtly fuse in new compounds the values sought by several of these move¬ ments. New meanings are arising and we have not yet learned to know their names. There is a kind of formal art, to give but one example, which is often near-abstract and inspired by surrealism, and which might be termed 'surrealistic formalism'. In other cases the patterns of integration are not congealed as yet in any way which could be classified. This evolution is due in part to the presence in America of numerous European exiles, who in many cases will remain as citizens, and whose work will soon be thought of as American. The melting pot has reached a new boiling point and is fashioning a syn¬ thesis of forthright American directness, boldness and energy, with European sub¬ tlety, refinement, and theoretical control. It seems long ago that we went through the provincial and naive promotion of subject illustrations called American Scene'. This was never an esthetically contemporary art. Time has proved its pictorial cliches a most inadequate vehicle in which to hold the dynamic energy, the turbulence and excitement of our age. Our creative artists found more relevant visual metaphors, but throughout the 1930''s they were kept on the de¬ fensive by the attacks of chauvinistic popularizers. Now the issues are on a higher level of discussion. We no longer feel it necessary to explain and justify Picasso, Ma¬ tisse, Rouault and Beckmann. We take them in our stride, recognizing that the artistic discoveries of the European schools reflect a time-spirit more truly than a place. Artists now interpret the American environment with no fear of foreign influence, and seek with honesty and self-confidence to shape new forms which ritualize our spiritual con¬ cerns. American painting has never been more vigorous, more proHfic, or more im¬ pressive. Lester D. Longman University of Iowa Libraries

record.full-text: A Short History of the Annual Fine Aiis Festival of the State University of Iowa By EARL ENYEART HARPER Director, School of Fine Arts and Iowa Memorial Union Beginnings and Development The annual Fine Arts Festival at the State University of Iowa was inaugurated during the summer session of 1939. The first, second, and third annual Festivals were compressed within a period of one week each. The Fourth Festival was dated July 1 through 29, 1942. In 1943 the fifth annual Fine Arts Festival was extended to eight weeks, the full period of the summer session, and this pattern has been followed since. At the time the Festival was founded Dr. Eugene A. Gilmore was President of the University. He, together with Dr. George F. Kay, Dean of the College of Liberal Arts, and particularlv Dr. Paul C. Packer, Dean of the College of Education and Director of the Summer Session, sup¬ ported the new project with approval and vision. Dr. Virgil M. Handier came to the presidency of the University of Iowa in 1940 and his under¬ standing of, and sympathy with the role of the Fine Arts in university education has been the basis of continuing support of the Festival since the first days of his administration. Dean Kay was succeeded in turn by Drs. Harry K. Newburn, Earl J. McGrath, and Dewey B. Stuit, as deans of the College of Liberal Arts. Each of these leaders has contributed to the continuance and expansion of the Festival. Dean Packer was succeeded as Director of the Summer Session by Dean Earl J. McGrath, Professor H. Clay Harshbarger, Dean Elmer T. Peterson, Provost Harvey H. Davis, Acting Dean Henry DeKock, and Dean Howard K. Jones. The counsel, sympathy, and assistance of these University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 06
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: educators have been indispensable in all aspects of development of the arts program at the University of Iowa, including particularly the Fine Arts Festival. Those who have been responsible for planning the Festival as a whole, and who have led in the development of the various programs involved have been the Director of the School of Fine Arts and the executives of the departments of the School. In the beginning these were the writer and Professors Philip Greeley Clapp, Department of Music, Edward C. Arabic, Department of Dramatic Art, and Lester D. Longman, Department of Art. These leaders have been succeeded in turn by Professors Himie Voxman, H. Clay Harshbarger, and Frank Seiberling. Since the State University of Iowa Museum of Natural His¬ tory was incorporated in the organization of the School in 1949, Walter C. Thietje, Curator, has shared in the preparation of each successive program. Charles B. Righter, for many years Director of the University Bands, was also Director of the All State High School Music Camp and was an active member of the committee in charge of the Festival until 1954 when he was succeeded by Frederick C. Ebbs both as Uni¬ versity Conductor of Bands and as All State Camp Director. Scores of faculty members, visiting conductors, artists, playwrights, theatre directors, and lecturers have shared not only in the programs of the Festival but in the development of objectives, policies and pro¬ cedures. For the twenty-fifth SUI Fine Arts Festival the members of the general committee are: Dean Howard R. Jones of the College of Edu¬ cation, Director of the SUI Summer Session; Professors H. Clay Harsh¬ barger, Chairman, Department of Speech and Dramatic Art; Orville A. Hitchcock, Assistant Dean of the Graduate College and Chairman of the Committee on University Lectures; Frank Seiberling, Head, De¬ partment of Art; Walter C. Thietje, Curator, University Museum of Natural History; Himie Voxman, Head, Department of Music and Chairman, Committee on University Concerts; Mr. George F. Stevens, Associate Director, Iowa Memorial Union, and Earl E. Harper, Director, School of Fine Arts and the Iowa Memorial Union, Chairman of the Committee and Director of the Festival since its founding. The members of the general committee together with Professors Herald I. Stark, Arnold S. Gillette, Harrold Shiffler, and Mr. William L. Adamson, Manager, comprise the committee in charge of the twen¬ ty-fifth annual Fine Arts Festival opera productions. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 07
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: For its Festival of Fine Arts the State University of Iowa has em¬ ployed artist members of its own faculties and professional visiting artists and educators as teachers, directors, coaches, and critics in the preparation and presentation of concerts, operas, plays, and art exhibi¬ tions featuring both performances and creative achievements by stu¬ dents. The major exception to this rule has been the annual presentation of important exhibitions of works of art by acknowledged masters. In 1945, the first of a series of special exhibitions of contemporary art on a large scale was introduced. The assistance of artists and col¬ lectors throughout the country as well as directors of galleries in New York City and Chicago was enlisted in the development of art shows of national significance, appropriately catalogued. Gallery directors in the early stages of the Festival noted the scarcity of presentations of art throughout the country during the summer months. They cooperated not only generously, but gratefully, stating that the SUI Festival in summertime gave opportunity for paintings, sculptures, and prints to "work" when otherwise they would be shut away in darkened store¬ rooms. Today competition for paintings, sculptures, and works of art in all media for summer exhibitions is keen. In 1950 plans of several years came to fruition in the preparation and presentation of opera in full form as a cooperative enterprise of the Departments of Music and Dramatic Art. Later the SUI Opera Workshop, functioning throughout the school year as well as in summer, was predicated upon the Festival opera productions. In its initial stages the Opera Workshop was financed from earnings of the Festival opera. The Iowa Memorial Union has served as the central home of the SUI Fine Arts Festival since its inception and has provided the office for the Festival Director and a meeting place for all committees. Major art exhibitions have been housed partly in the Union and partly in the Art Building. The University of Iowa Theatre has been the center for a distinguished program of play productions. Operas have been pre¬ sented in Macbride Auditorium. The Music Buildings have been used extensively for Festival orches¬ tral, choral, ensemble, and recital preparation, and for lectures, semi¬ nars, recitals, and concerts. In particular the Music Buildings have served as the center of All State High School Music Camps which have brought hundreds of talented high school students and more hundreds of visitors to the campus each summer. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 08
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: In addition to housing art exhibitions the Art Building and surround¬ ings have been the scenes of manv and varied programs, public as¬ semblies, and social gatherings in connection with successive Festivals. On occasion the Field House of the University has been pressed into service for events drawing an attendance of 5,000 to 10,000 auditors. The Union and the Theatre were the first buildings on the SUI cam¬ pus to have the benefit of air conditioning, a direct result of the de¬ velopment of the Festival. Macbride Auditorium was reconstructed, refurnished, provided with new lighting, and air conditioned in 1957. The use of this auditorium for Festival opera rehearsals and per¬ formances was a major factor in this development. MUSIC Throughout the development of the SUI Festival of Fine Arts, orches¬ tras, choruses, bands, chamber music ensembles, and recitals for voice and instruments have been featured each year. Symphony concerts ha\e been offered annually under conductors Philip Greeley Clapp, Modeste Alloo, Arthur Berdahl, Charles Gigante, Paul Olefsky, James Dixon, and conductors of the All State High School Music Camp. Symphonic works performed during the twenty-five year period of the Festival have ranged from the great repertory compositions of Bach. Beethoven, Brahms, and Wagner, to those of Ravel, Strauss, and Alban Berg, and have likewise included commissioned works by contemporary composers plaved from manuscript. During the early days of the Festival, under the leadership of Dr. Phihp Greeley Clapp, the symphonic works of Anton Bruckner and Gustav Mahler were played frequently. On memorable occasions Dr. Clapp was presented the famous Mahler and Bruckner Medals. Summer Session band concerts have been conducted by Professors Charles Boardman Righter and Frederick C. Ebbs, and by visiting conductors. The choral portions of the Festival from 1939 through 1946 were conducted by Dr. Thompson Stone, conductor of the Handel and Havdn Societv of Boston. He was succeeded as Festival choral conductor bv Professor Herald Stark of the faculty of the Department of Music in 1947. The following choral works were presented with orchestra under the batons of these two conductors: University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 09
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: 1939—The "Manzoni" Requiem, Verdi 1940—The Damnation of Faust, Berlioz 1941—The Dream of Gerontius, Elgar 1942—Requiem, Brahms 1943—(A) Hora Novissima, Horatio Parker (B) Benedicite, Vaughan Williams 1944-(A) God's Time is the Best Time, Bach (B) Suite: "Flos Campi," WiUiams (C) A Song of Destiny, Brahms (D) Cantata: "Gallia," Gounod 1945—The Specter's Bride, Dvorak 1946—Requiem, Verdi 1947-( A) Chant of Darkness, PhiHp Greeley Clapp (B) Envoy, WiUiam G. Blanchard 1948—(A) Requiem, Mozart (B) Symphony of Psalms, Stravinsky 1949—King David, Honegger In 1950, as previously noted, the Departments of Music and Dramatic Art joined forces for the first major opera production of the SUI Fine Arts Festival. From that date Professor Herald Stark, has served as opera conductor. The Department of Music has provided the singers and the orchestra. The Department of Dramatic Art has provided the dramatic director, the directors of scene design, lighting, and costumes, and crews to handle production. Professor Arnold S. Gillette, Director of the SUI Theatre, has been in general supervision of these services continuously since 1950, and has designed the stage settings for all of the operas. Professors Harold Grain, Lewin Goff, Peter Arnott, and Harrold Shiffler have served as dramatic coaches, the latter for a total of nine years. Miss Margaret Hall and Messrs. Walter S. Dewev and David Thayer have supervised costuming and lighting since the be¬ ginning of opera productions. The operas which have been produced under this happv arrangement are as follows: 1950—The Bartered Bride, Smetana 1951—Die Fledermaus, Strauss 1952—Cosi fan tutte, Mozart 1953—La Boheme, Puccini University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 10
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: 1954—Love For Three Oranges, Prokofieff 1955—The Marriage of Figaro, Mozart 1956—Samson and Delilah, Saint-Saens (Presented in choral-dramatic form) 1957-Albert Herring, Britten 1958—Madame Butterflv, Puccini 1959-(A) Rita, Donizetti (B) Western Child, Paul Engle and Philip Bezanson 1960—Carmen, Bizet 1961—Merry Wives of Windsor, Nicolai 1962-The Crucible, Ward 1963-(A) L'Infidelta Delusa, Haydn (B) La Traviata, Verdi Many concerts of chamber music have been presented by faculty and student string, brass, and reed ensembles, and occasionallv noted artists have been presented in recital. In observance of the twenty-fifth annual presentation of the Festival of Fine Arts the great Metropolitan basso, Jerome Hines, will appear. ART Beginning with the first Festival in 1939 paintings, sculptures, prints, drawings, works of art in the fields of ceramics and silver smithing, African masks, African art and artifacts, Mexican art and Chinese paint¬ ings have been presented in successive Festival exhibitions. Several times art created or collected in Iowa has been featured. The works of art thus presented during the twenty-five years of the Festival represent practically every name well known in contemporary art in the United States and a good many from abroad, particularly England, Germany and Mexico. They represent drawings by masters over a period of six centuries, and works of art by distinguished artists of the faculty of the SUI Department of Art, former students who are now themselves well known professional artists and teachers, and pro¬ fessional and graduate students on the campus. As already noted special emphasis was placed upon contemporary American art from 1945 to 1950. In connection with this development University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 11
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: President Virgil M. Hancher provided for annual purchases which have resulted in the development of the SUI Permanent Collection. No tax raised funds were involved. The number of works of art of all kinds inventoried in the SUI Per¬ manent Collection is approximately three hundred today of which approximately sixty are of major significance. Of these, fifteen paintings, two sculptures, and an African inask are shown in the Twentv-fifth Annual Fine Arts Festival exhibition in the Terrace Lounge of the Iowa Memorial Union and reproduced in this publica¬ tion. These are representative of works of art which have been pur¬ chased from Festival art exhibits since 1945. In addition, and equally significant, works of art by present or former faculty members of the Department of Art of the Universitv of Iowa have been purchased from Festival exhibitions and added to the collection. Among the artists thus represented are Humbert Albrizio, Byron Burford, Stuart Edie, Emil Ganso, Philip Guston, Mauricio Lasansky, James Lechay, Hal Lotter¬ man, Eugene Ludins, Fletcher Martin, Charles Okerbloom, Keith Vaughan, and Frank Wachowiak. As a result of a determined effort to arrange for a Festival exhibition of great art of the ages a notable presentation of thirty masterpieces from the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City was made available to the State Universitv of Iowa in the spring of 1948. Francis Henry Taylor, then Head of the MetropoHtan Museum, wrote a fore¬ word for the catalogue in which he said: "The Metropolitan Museum of Art sends this exhibition of art to the State University of Iowa with the belief that it will stimulate an interest in the splendid work on this campus—activities which have already achieved nationwide recognition and acclaim." The paintings, of great value, represented the work of such artists as Fra Filippo Lippi, Lucas Cranach, Jan Van Eyck, Hier- onymus Bosch, Pieter Brueghel, Peter Paul Rubens, Anthony Van Dyck, Frans Hals, Rembrandt van Rijn, El Greco, and Rosa Bonheur. This exhibition, by contractual requirement, was shipped in a sealed railway car, with armed guards. Staff members were sent from the Museum to supervise the movement of the masterpieces from the rail¬ road station to the Art Building. Armed guards were on duty twenty- four hours each day during the exhibition. In a period of three months more than 40,000 visitors were counted. This was an important by- jiroduct of the Festival. It required—and received—the support of the entire University administration. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 12
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: The exhibitions of art of all ages and in all media brought together and presented in successive Fine Arts Festivals at SUI have been care¬ fully related to the undergraduate and graduate curricula which have brought to the art department of the University one of the largest art department enrollments in the United States of America. A sampling of the art exhibitions of the SUI Festival of Fine Arts over a period of twenty-five years follows: 1939—(A) Exhibition of Paintings by Grant Wood and Marvin Cone, (40 Paintings) (B) Corcoran Gallery XVIth Biennial, (30 Paintings) 1945-1949—Five Successive Exhibitions of Contemporary Art Presenting a Total of 523 Paintings and 58 Sculptures 1951—Six Centuries of Master Drawings (228 Drawings) 1955— (A) Contemporary American Paintings (34 Paintings) (B) Contemporary Crafts and Ceramics (150 Works) 1956—African Sculpture (160 Examples) 1958— (A) Mexican Art—Pre-Columbian to Modern Times, (247 Paintings, Sculptures, Works in Ceramics and Silver, and Artifacts) (B) Contemporary Paintings (43 Paintings) 1960—Main Currents of Contemporary Painting (58 Paintings) 1962-(A) Vintage Moderns (79 Paintings; 26 Photographs) (B) Five Decades of the Figure in American Painting (9 Paintings) Those who have chiefly been responsible for choosing, collecting, and cataloguing the art exhibitions of the Festival during the past twenty-five years are the writer, Lester D. Longman, Humbert Albrizio, Mauricio Lasansky, William S. Heckscher, Roy Sieber, Raoul Delmare, Charles O. Guttler, Edith Halpert, Mildred LeVois, and Frank Seiber¬ ling. Many members of the faculty of the Department of Art have served as advisers and critics not only in the choice and arrangement of ex¬ hibits, but in deciding upon purchases. DRAMA The Department of Dramatic Art has made a magnificent contribution to the SUI Festival during the past quarter of a century. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 13
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: More than one hundred plays have been performed in the University Theatre and the Studio Theatre, and in addition several have been presented at Lake Okoboji on a special stage built for summer produc¬ tions there. The list of plays includes eighteen by William Shakespeare, three by MoHere, three by Richard B. Sheridan, three by George Bernard Shaw, and two each by Eugene O'Neill, Elmer Rice, and the team of George S. Kaufman and Moss Hart. Twenty-five plays written by students, former students, or faculty members of the Department of Dramatic Art, have been presented. Among playwrights who have either been associated with the SUI Theatre or who have had original scripts first produced during the Festival are Tennessee Williams, Elsworth Prouty Conkle, Paul Green, Howard Richardson, and Robert W. Anderson. Plays from many nations and most periods in the history of world drama, beginning with ancient Greece, are included in the list of Fes¬ tival offerings since 1939. THE TROJAN WOMEN by Euripides was performed in 1941, and Shakespearean productions have provided ex¬ amples of the historical plays, the tragedies, the comedies, and the dark comedies. Representative of the drama of several countries are the following: Czechoslovakia-THE INSECT COMEDY, J. and K. Capek England-SCHOOL FOR SCANDAL, Sheridan PYGMALION, Shaw France-THE MISER, MoHere TIGER AT THE GATES, Giraudoux Hungary—LILIOM, Molnar India-THE LITTLE CLAY CART, Sudraka Ireland-THE PLAYBOY OF THE WESTERN WORLD, Synge Italy-THE BURNT FLOWER BED, Betti Norway-THE DOLL'S HOUSE, Ibsen Spaiii-THE CRADLE SONG, G. and M. Martinez-Sierra United States-THE SKIN OF OUR TEETH, Wilder AH WILDERNESS, O'Neill A STREETCAR NAMED DESIRE, WiUiams DEATH OF A SALESMAN, Miller YOU CAN'T TAKE IT WITH YOU, Kaufman and Hart University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 14
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: In the summer of 1961, the University Theatre inaugurated a reper¬ tory program. A permanent cast for the entire repertory period prepares four plays and each play is presented five times. The new venture has proven very successful. A considerably greater number of theatre goers have desired admission during the first two years of the repertory pro¬ gram than could be admitted. From 1939 until his death in 1956, the Festival theatre program was directed by Professor Edward C. Mabie, one of the great names in educational theatre historv. From 1956 until now. Professor H. Clay Harshbarger, Chairman of the Department of Speech and Dramatic Art, and Professor Arnold S. Gillette, Director of the University Theatre, have directed the program. Professor GiUette has provided technical direction and the designs for scenery and sets in the University Theatre and for the operas during the entire life of the Fine Arts Festival. Regu¬ lar and visiting members of the faculty of the Department of Dramatic Art have directed the plays from the beginning, and have directed the dramatic development of the operas. Among the distinguished visiting directors have been Thomas Wood Stevens, Paul Green, Frederic Mc¬ Connell, B. Iden Payne, Hallie Flanagan Davis, and John Baird. LECTURES The Summer Session lectures were not born of the Fine Arts Festival. They were presented for many years before the Festival was conceived, as indeed, were other elements ultimately integrated in the Festival program. The inclusion in the Fine Arts Festival literature of the an¬ nouncement of the Summer Session lectures was determined upon by authorities of the Summer Session. The lectures have become a notable accompaniment of the Festival and frequently a lecturer is chosen with reference to his ability to speak with authority in the fields of the arts. From 1939 through 1954 the Summer Session lectures were under the chairmanship of Dr. M. Willard Lampe, Director, School of Religion of the State University of Iowa. Since 1955 the lectures have been under the chairmanship of Dr. Orville Hitchcock, Assistant Dean of the Graduate College and Professor in the Department of Speech and Dramatic Art. Notable personalities in drama, art, music, literature, politics, economics, education, reUgion, and journalism have been pre¬ sented. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 15
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: MUSEUM Since the Museum of Natural History at the State University of Iowa was placed under the administration of the School of Fine Arts, Mr. Walter C. Thietje, Curator, has coUaborated with the committee in charge of the Fine Arts Festival each year. Bird HaU, Bird Hall Annex and Mammal Hall have received additions to the exhibits prepared for students and the public which have been timed for initial presentation as special features of successive Festivals. In addition an attractive cen¬ ter of exhibits has been developed in the lower corridor of Macbride Hall and here special exhibits have been planned each summer. An entire divisional program in Anthropology was introduced during the school year of 1962-63. This has resulted in the construction of six exhibition cases in the first floor corridor of Macbride Hall. For the Twenty-fifth Annual Fine Arts Festival these cases will be used to present a featured exhibition titled "The Indians of Iowa," which de¬ picts cultural traditions in Iowa pre-history dating from 10,000 B.C. It is probable that this expansion in the program of the Museum will result in the establishment of a "Hall of Man." THE SYMBOL The symbol, which brings into an integrated silhouette the mask, lyre, and palette, signifying Drama, Music, and Art, was suggested by the Festival director and dravrai by Miss Alice Davis of the faculty of the Department of Art, now a member of the faculty of Iowa State Univer¬ sity, Ames, Iowa. It was used on all literature, catalogues and programs of the First Annual Festival of Fine Arts. It has been similarly used for all of the Festivals including the Twenty-fifth and has been repro¬ duced thousands of times. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: The Twenty-Fifth Annual Fine Arts Festival, State University of Iowa: program, history, exhibition, June 10 - August 7, 1963, Iowa City, Iowa
record.description: Festival included eighteen paintings and sculptures from the permanent collection of the State University of Iowa ; an exhibition of fine prints; anthropological and other exhibitions in the Museum of Natural History; lectures by Dr. Zelma George, August Hechscher, Dean Howard Wilson and Mrs. Marquis Childs; two operas, "L'Infidelta delusa" by Joseph Haydn and "La Traviata" by Giuseppe Verdi; plays by William Shakespeare, J.M. Synge, Moliere and Tennessee Williams; musical performances; "A short history of the Annual Fine Arts Festival of the State University of Iowa"--pages 5-15.

M. (John Millington), 1871-1909; Moliere, 1622-1673; Williams, Tennessee, 1911-1983; Shiffler, Harrold C.; Stark, Herald I. (Herald Ira), 1907-1997; Gousseff, James W.; Schaal, David G.; Terfloth, John H.; Weber, Max; Miro, Juan; Beckmann, Max, 1884-1950; Feininger, Lyonel, 1871-1956; Davis, Stuart, 1892-1964; Stamos, Theodoros, 1922-1997; Siporin, Mitchell, 1910-1976; Hartley, Marsden, 1877-1943; Levine, Jack, 1915-; Lipchitz, Jacques, 1891-1973; Zerbe, Karl, 1903-1972; Matta Echaurren, Roberto Sebastia´n, 1912-2002; Baumbach, Harold, 1903-; De Martini, Joseph; Pereira, Irene Rice, 1902-1971; Kreis, Henry, 1899-1963; Pollock, Jackson, 1912-1956

record.full-text: THE THIRD ANNUAL EXHIBITION OF CONTEMPORARY ART (The Iowa Sum¬ mer Show) is presented by the School of Fine Arts at the State University of Iowa as one of the major events of the Ninth Annual Fine Arts Festival. The exhibition this year presents 128 paintings from a number of the best known galleries, artists' studios, and private collections in the United States. The selec¬ tions were made by Dr. Lester D. Longman, Head of the Department of Art at the State University of Iowa. As in previous years twelve paintings have been selected from which the University will make purchases according to its available means. These are indicated in the catalogue by asterisks. The jury for 1947 was as follows: Albert Christ-Janer, Di¬ rector of the Cranbrook Museum, Cranbrook Academy of Art, Bloomfield Hills, Michigan; Professor Dwight Kirsch, Chairman, Department of Art, University of Nebraska; and Professor Lester D. Longman. The University is grateful to all who have made loans of paintings to the exhibi¬ tion and in particular acknowledges the cooperation of the following galleries in New York City: A. C. A., 63 E. 57th St. Art of This Century, 30 W. 57th St. Associated American Artists, 711 5th Aye. Babcock, 38 E. 57th St. Bignou, 32 E. 57th St. Buchholz, 32 E. 57th St. Chinese, 38 E. 57th St. Contemporary Arts Center, 106 E. 57th St. Downtown, 32 E. 51st St. Durand-Ruel, 12 E. 57th St. Durlacher, 11 E. 57th St. Feigl, 601 Madison Ave. Ferargil, 63 E. 57th St. Hugo, 26 E. 55th St. Kleemann, 65 E. 57th St. Knoedler, 14 E. 57th St. Kootz, 15 E. 57th St. Levitt, 16 W. 57th St. Levy, 42 E. 57th St. Macbeth, 11 E. 57th St. Matisse, 41 E. 57th St. Midtown, 605 Madison Ave. Milch, 108 W. 57th St. New Art Circle, 41 E. 57th St. Nierendorf, 53 E. 57th St. Niveau, 63 E. 57th St. Norlyst, 59 W. 56th St. Parsons, 15 E. 57th St. Passedoit, 121 E. 57th St. Perls, 32 E. 58th St. Rehn, 683 5th Ave. Rosenberg, 16 E. 57th St. Schaefer, 32 E. 57th St. Valentine, 55 E. 57th St. Weyhe, 794 Lexington Ave. Those administratively responsible for the Iowa Summer Show are pleased with the growing interest in the exhibition. It will be of interest to educational institutions, museums, and private collectors to know that most of the paintings are for sale. Purchases must be made directly from the galleries or the artists. Price lists are available at the exhibition. > " EARL E. HARPER Director, School of Fine Arts University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 05
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: FOREWORD Those who watch Paris for new ideas were sadly disillusioned by the recent exhi¬ bition of contemporary French painting at the Whitney Museum. The younger French artists are eclectic and uninspired, content with a diligent repetition of certain memorable phrases from Picasso, Matisse, Rouault, and other fertile minds of the older generation. If the exhibition represented their best work, let us hope the deterioration is curable and will not result in demoralization and atrophy. At present the United States is producing a large quantity of creditable painting. We may be ready to export ideas. One major reason, of course, is that for the past decade we have attracted talented foreign artists to our shores as France did for over a century. Since creative artists always seek freedom, perhaps this good for¬ tune will continue. There is a certain satisfaction in reaching this degree of maturity. In the past some of our artists paid homage to Europe in humble and submissive imitation. Others exhibited their jealousy by rancorous, chauvinistic rebellion, as in the abor¬ tive provincialism of the 1930's. Some illustrators who had no style at all boasted of being singularly American on this account. We were victims of an inferiority complex. Now it is gone and is not likely to return. A position of leadership is be¬ ing thrust upon us in art as in politics, and we should behave as though we deserve it. Doubtless we can provide the artist with a high level of material prosperity. Holly¬ wood attracts cinema artists from everywhere with that bait, but for purposes of mass consumption promptly debases their talent to an infantile level of expression. The critical question is whether we can equal the achievement of France in foster¬ ing the mature imagination. Will enough of us welcome the new in art that men of genuine originality can live here? Are we sufficiently intelligent, liberal, tol¬ erant? Their crucial need is not economic prosperity, but understanding, encour¬ agement, and freedom from a rigid Philistine conventionality of thought and con¬ duct. Standardized minds do not beget a superior art, and a society in mental lock step will not nurture it. For the time being, at least, we are not doing too badly. The 1947 "Iowa Summer Show" attests to the originality, the vigor, the variety, and the abundance of American painting. Those who attended the 1946 exhibition, however, will observe that the present one is not greatly different in character. Apparently no major change has taken place in the nature of art expression during the interim. One is at pains to discover any important artist hitherto unknown, or to identify a new trend. This is quite the opposite of the situation last summer. Between June, 1945 and June, 1946 a sweeping liberal trend occurred, as was pointed out in the fore- University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 06
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: word to last year's catalogue. Those who keep abreast of such matters will have noted that all the national exhibitions subsequent to the 1946 "Summer Show" re¬ corded the same trend. We could scarcely expect such a rapid change in emphasis two years in succession. Instead, the past twelve months seem to have been de¬ voted to stabilizing the new equilibrium. In the process a clarification of issues is taking place. The avant-garde, concerned with the area of surrealistic abstraction, no longer seems shocking, and one is bet¬ ter able to evaluate the scope of its contribution and its promise for the future. Its concepts are wearing a little thin in places, but it is not yet seriously challenged. In this connection Matta still seems to be of central importance, as indicated last summer. Geometric abstraction, which had such a long career, seems increasingly passe; and even its former devotees have renounced it in most cases for more evoc¬ ative surrealistic forms. Other modes of expression attract approximately the same following as in 1946. Occasionally one hears the prophecy that painting will swing back to traditional, innocuous "representation." This could occur in the form of a cultural retreat re¬ flecting current political conservatism, but at the moment it seems unlikely without actual coercion by reactionaries outside the field of art. There is evidence, unfor¬ tunately, that even this can happen here as it did in Germany unless we have the zeal and energy to prevent it. The incident of the State Department exhibition por¬ tends intolerance. It is folly to underestimate the insolence of cultural bigotry. On the other hand, some predict the free discovery of original forms of more repre¬ sentational nature than those which have been exciting experimental artists in re¬ cent months. This would be quite different from reaction, for there is no reason to link the concept of progress with the fortunes of "abstraction." Indeed there is no significant distinction between the "representational" and the "abstract," for all art of consequence is both at once. Since there is no clear evidence of any such devel¬ opment on a wide front, these speculotions presumably reflect a growing impa¬ tience with the vogue for precious little sensations. They disclose an appetite for more complex and monumental statements, involving more responsible concepts, for a strategy employing more of the resources of three-dimensional design and more of the elements of visual reality. These are components of painting which are always at the disposal of artists who accept an obligation to make use of them. Pictorial expression in the domain of the experimental, however intriguing, is now often so fragmentary and casual, so mannered or so esoteric, that an ambition for greater richness of form and profundity of content is neither surprising nor unrea¬ sonable, and most lovers of art would be glad to see on the horizon progressive art¬ ists who will make the attempt to achieve this in larger measure. LESTER D. LONGMAN University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Third summer exhibition of contemporary art, University of Iowa, June 15 - July 30, 1947
record.description: "The third annual exhibition of contemporary art (The Iowa Summer Show) is presented by the School of Fine Arts at the State University of Iowa as one of the major events of the Ninth Annual Fine Arts Festival. The exhibition this year presents 128 paintings from a number of the best known galleries, artists' studios, and private collections in the United States. The selections were made by Dr. Lester D. Longman, Head of the Department of Art at the State University of Iowa"--page 4; exhibition of paintings by University of Iowa students.

record.full-text: 'W^- "W^ THE SUMMER EXHIBITION OF CONTEMPORARY ART at the State University of Iowa, a major feature of the Annual Fine Arts Festival, has been accepted as an im¬ portant addition to the list of major art exhibitions in the United States. Those ad¬ ministratively responsible for it are nov/ confident it will be an annual event. This year there are 160 paintings, drawings, and prints, drawn from private collec¬ tions, artists' studios, and thirty-four galleries. The exhibition was selected by Dr. Lester D. Longman, Head of the Department of Art at the State University of Iowa. A jury of critics and artists has again selected twelve paintings from which the University will make purchases according to its resources. The jury for 1946 was as follows: Professor Lester D. Longman; H. W. Janson, Professor of Art at Washington University, St. Louis; and Paul Parker, Director of the Des Moines Art Center. Most of the pictures in this exhibition are for sale and price lists are available. Edu¬ cational institutions, art museums, and private collectors will find this show a convenient occasion to make purchases from works of art carefully selected from a much larger number which were given critical consideration. An Iowa Fine Arts Association has been incorporated by distinguished citizens to assist the University in the development of its program in the fine arts. The first meetings of the new corporation were held at the time of the formal opening of the Summer Show of 1946. The University thanks the artists and the collectors who have contributed paintings to the exhibition and gratefully acknowledges the helpful cooperation of the following New York galleries: A. C. A., 63 E. 57th St. Art of This Century, 30 W. 57th St. Assoc. Am. Artists, 711 5th Ave. Babcocic, 38 E. 57th St. Bignou, 32 E. 57th St. Brandt, 15 E. 57th St. Buchholz, 32 E. 57th St. Contemp. record.title: Page 05
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: FOREWORD The "iowa Summer Show" presents each year a cross-section of progressive American painting. This time a few European artists and a section of prints and drawings are included. Sculpture will be shown as soon as the technical problems of transportation and installation can be solved. The present exhibition is too conservative to give due weight to the area of greatest activity and progress. The past year has witnessed a more general acceptance of "modernism" among artists, collectors, and amateurs. The pace of evolution in this direction has been accelerated as the production of art soars and sales multiply. The old academicians and local scene illustrators are increasingly inconspicuous, while artists who recently occupied the center have suddenly become the members of the right. Some of the conservative painters of established reputation are "going modern." Former radicals see themselves out-flanked and speak of our obligation to respect the cubist-classical tradition as the central discipline of twentieth century art. Young painters are boldly experimental in conjuring up a host of unfamiliar shivers, and the Museum of Modern Art is increasingly persuasive in capturing their imaginations and certifying their achievements. The more adventurous critics are preparing mentally for the time when an art that seems disloyal to the generation of Picasso will, at first, appear intolerable. Attitudes toward modern European artists are rapidly shifting, so that Ce'zanne and Gauguin have become quiet, old masters. Matisse, Dufy and Modigliani are compre¬ hensible to all whose path crosses the modern idioms. Rouault and Beckmann have become magnificently "classical." Chagall is spiritually contemporary and intriguing, and shares the center of the stage with Picasso, Le'ger, Mird, and Klee. The orthodox surrealists are a gushing fountain, pouring forth a novel iconography of anti-esthetic and subversive images and hypnagogical shock-mechanisms. They function as per¬ vasive stimulants. The vigorous and deserving school of socially-conscious realism is suffering a decline and enjoys relatively few new converts, as though it had been a creature of the de¬ pression and is doomed by inflation. The romantic painters of mood and landscape are similarly eclipsed by new directions. Natural primitives and whimsical painters of private fantasy still are captivating, but what I have elsewhere called 'surrealistic formalism' is the area of most rapid expansion, of exploration and enthusiasm. Both abstract and semi-representational artists are fusing formal and surrealistic values, re¬ solving anew the ageless polarity of the classic and romantic. At present the more abstract of these arfists are the exponents of the marginal frontier where most excite¬ ment gathers. The term is designed to include only those who are esthetically ingra¬ tiating, in terms either of non-objective design or expressive drawing, and whose ideological allegiances are surrealistic. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 06
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: .¦•Tj^'tf^ Experiments with "pure" form and "tasteful" figurative design are now too readily intelligible. The violence of expressionism is no longer sufFiciently stimulating. Dalinian illusionism and other surrealist forms of non-esthetic imagery are disquieting and pro¬ vocative, but soon exhaust their seductive powers. What seems to be required is the powerful impact of surrealist psychic surgery expressed in a formal art of dynamic hieroglyphs. The extravagant results are not very "beautiful," but they get under your skin and irritate you. They stick like leeches in the imagination, center your thoughts in new concerns, sensitize the mind to new dimensions of poetic meaning, and provoke a massive shift in values. The most magnetically insidious are the paintings of what may be called the visceral school, devotees of pathological or gangrenous biological matter. They build a cul¬ ture out of vulgarity, to judge by conventional standards, although we know that what was shocking twenty years ago is mild enough today. One might reasonably conclude that the world has gone crazy. This is also the impression you get from your newspaper. The artists themselves are barometric, not crazy, though it is human as well as traditional to hate the bearer of bad news. Many prefer Pollyanna's message or the attitude of an ostrich. To the artist these poems of decomposition are exhilarting as well as true. If he makes you hate him for his frankness, he is persuasive; if in time your hatred turns to wonder, he is successful. So many new names have been enrolled in the ranks of the abstract painters that they constitute our newest "academy." After time has separated the grain from the chafF there will be much to commend. But now slight and often elementary patterns of precious ambiguity are taken seriously, though they exhibit little knowledge of the complicated problems of pictorial design of form in space. Many are mannered imi¬ tations or eclectic combinations, and hence no more admirable than work by any other formulae. Often they will not stand the test of time physically, much less spiritu¬ ally. Made for the opportunistic present they are fashionably irresponsible. Another danger seems to be that young artists may be too well satisfied with the con¬ tagion of the ideograph qua evocative image. To make it at the same time formally expressive is obviously not so easy and in this the orthodox surrealists have not been helpful. Perhaps the original man today is the artist who can do this without undue allegiance to the recent Picasso and Le'ger, and the late work of Kandinsky, or to Chagall, Mird, and Klee. One is inclined to watch a man like Matta, not because we can ever predict the future in this mercurial work of art, but because he seems to sym¬ bolize the state of affairs at the present moment. LESTER D. LONGMAN -K -i University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Second summer exhibition of contemporary art, University of Iowa, June 16 - July 31, 1946
record.description: "The summer exhibition of contemporary art at the State University of Iowa [is] a major feature of the Annual Fine Arts Festival. This year there are 160 paintings, drawings and prints, drawn from private collections, artists' studios, and thirty-four galleries. The exhibition was selected by Dr. Lester D. Longman, Head of the Department of Art at the State University of Iowa"--page 4."; exhibition of paintings by University of Iowa students.
