record.full-text: ACKNOWlfDGMENT The Department of Art expresses deep appreciation to the following lenders to the exhibition whose generosity has made the exhibition possible: The Art Institute of Chicago, The Alfred Stieglitz Collection The Columbus Gallery of Fine Arts, The Ferdinand Howald Collection The Downtown Gallery Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Bloedel Mr. and Mrs. Richard Evans, II The William H. Lane Foundation Mr. and Mrs. Milton Lowenthal The Museum of Modern Art Yale University Art Museum, Collection, Soci6t6 Anonyme Special appreciation and a tribute is here expressed to Edith Gregory Halpert, Directorof the Downtown Gallery, who for many years has valiantly supported American art and artists. This exhibition, to which she has con¬ tributed so generously, is its own tribute to the artists but also to her early recognition of the qualities that have proven enduring in their work. The successor to Alfred Stieglitz as representative of Demuth, Dove, Marin and O'Keeffe, she has been instrumental in en¬ couraging and showing many other American artists and has been a leader in the discovery and preservation of American primitive art. Her recent magnificent gift of paintings to the Corcoran Gallery in Washington im¬ portantly augments that collection in the modern field, making it a leading center for the study of American painting. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 03
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: A VINTAGE PERIOD OF MODERN AMERICAN ART, INCLUDING AN ANNIVERSARY BOW TO ALFRED STIEGLITZ INTRODUCTION Who shall recognize and separate the true avant- garde from the beguiling novelty, the manufactured sensation, or the ardent - but passing - cause? In this country during the first decade of our century, a num¬ ber of critics and artists thought they discerned, or in effect were creating, the esthetic wave of the future. Under the spell of Robert Henri, one group saw the great hope in social realism and the American Scene. Their artistic sources were mainly Velasquez, Hals and Goya, with a bow to Manet. Under the pleasant thrall of Monet and Renoir, another, less cohesivei, group included such Impress¬ ionist artists as Childe Hassam and William Glackens. They appeared radical to many Americans. Also painting and looked upon by their adherents as progressive were artists of "The 10" such as Thomas Dewing and Willard Metcalf who in the 90's had dev¬ eloped from the example of Whistler and the Barbizon School, a kind of indigenous luminism having a para¬ doxically cool romanticism not seen in the prototypes. Finally, there were the artists of this exhibition, most of whom were protSg6s of - or at least exhibited by - Alfred Stieglitz. Almost invariably, they rec¬ eived a bad, even abusive, press, and might therefore hove been expected at least to attract some attention from the curious. But not enough curiosity-seekers were also interested in art. Among the several groups in the early century looked upon by their lay - and even professional - contemporaries as progressive, dar¬ ing, radical or crazy, they were the least conspicuous and least understood. It is they we salute. The most indefatigable of their supporters, Alfred Stieglitz, made public his ingrained defiance of accep¬ ted norms in 1902 with the launching of the "Photogra¬ phic Secession. " In this 60th anniversary of his formal secession from the past, it is appropriate to take ano¬ ther look at the individuals he launched, at their "fel¬ low travelers" in the modern esthetic and, incidentally, University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 04
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: at Alfred Stieglitz himself, who has been so well borne out by time. Stieglitz' action in 1902 may well be taken as the first of a series that transformed the modern art move¬ ment in this country from the experiments of isolated individuals into a cause. His was by no means the on¬ ly organizing voice in the wilderness, but the early date of his public action - at first related only to pho¬ tography - and his dedicated support of a modern view of art, once it developed, gave him a central place in the large group of pioneers. The son of a wealthy wool merchant, a German 6migi<, Stieglitz had started out for Germany in 1881 to study engineering but soon gave it up for photogra¬ phy. After 9 years in Europe and an abortive experi¬ ence in this country trying to run a photo-engraving company, he retired from conventional business to de¬ vote himself wholly to photography and, later, to exhi¬ biting the works of artists and photographers he consi¬ dered worthy. He had himself already won internatio¬ nal fame as a photographer. Although some of the world's best photographs date from the pioneering years after the I850's, subsequent cost-lowering and technical improvements paralleled a decline in photography's art quality. Although the Photo Secession was set off by a disagreement with the publishers of Camera Notes, connected with policies of the New York Camera Club, the movement's true origin and meaning were broader. Henceforth the pic¬ torial or art quality of photography, while recognized as having parallels in principle with the other arts, would decreasingly involve the appearance and "look" of the non-photographic medio, such as painting. Even in the 90's, when Stieglitz sought'romantic tonal effects, he was already striving for pictorial organization. He would wait, if necessary for hours, until passing subject matter or changing light and shade were properly situa¬ ted - as he visualized them in related placement on the flat plane of his negative. Stieglitz' later conversion to the abstract tendencies of Post-Impressionism was well-prepared by such observation and experimentation. As the first American to exhibit Matisse - in 1908 - Stieglitz was not contradicting his interest in photogra¬ phy; he became a dedicated seeker through photography of the heightening visual unity which is the basis of most art, even as he supported the most abstract tenden¬ cies in the treatment of subject in painting. Moreover, as his taste for the abstract in painting grew, especial¬ ly after he became acquainted with Max Weber in 1910, he ultimately heightened the formal quality of his pho¬ tography both by creative isolation of sharp detail, as in the nude studies,or through isolation of natural pic¬ torial effects, as in the cloud pictures. By isolation and by arbitrary placement and lighting he demonstra¬ ted the power of controlled photography to reveal mul¬ tiple data with unifying simplicity. Through his photography alone, Stieglitz would have made a contribution to the growth of a modern vision in America, but he fostered the same also in other ways. He was as well known for his relentless opposition to Philistinism and for his crusading polemics in support of modern tendencies. His periodicals Camera Notes and especially Camera Work went far beyond photography in their range of subject matter. Stieglitz also became recognized, gradually, as his country's earliest and most vigorous dealer in art having strongly abstract tendencies, whether French, beginning with CSzonne, or American under the same succession of influence. In his two room gallery at 291 5th Avenue, opened in 1905 and operated until the war, he gave the first introduction or one-man show in this country to such French artists as CSzanne, Toul¬ ouse-Lautrec, Matisse, Picasso, Henri Rousseau, Fran¬ cis Picabia, Gino Severini and Brancusi; and the first comprehensive exhibition or one-man show to the ar¬ tists in our exhibition, Marsden Hartley, Oscar Bluem- ner, Arthur G. Dove, John Marin, Alfred Maurer, Max Weber, Stanton Macdona Id-Wright, Georgia O'Keeffe and in later years, to Charles Demuth. The momentum of the modern artistic vision and its inner necessity in a world of new scientific, philo¬ sophical and psychological outlook would have made a new esthetic inevitable in this country, even without Stieglitz. But he was still its most dynamic early par¬ tisan. His gallery was not only a center for presenting the French-influenced avant-garde but a perpetual sa¬ lon in which he was the spell binder, super-salesman, philosopher, sophisticate, social charmer, prosecuting attorney and attorney for the defense - depending upon which role the situation called for. He was alert to University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 05
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: I Bluemner 2 Bluemner creativity of any sort that expressed the central import¬ ance of the esthetic. It was nevertheless remarkable that a man whose activity was so deeply involved with the visual arts should, for example, be the first one to print something written by Gertrude Stein. In 1929 he named his final gallery An American Place and no longer exhibited European artists; yet his influence was never directed towards the American and democratic concerns of the "ash can" artists or of the regionalists of the '30's. His appeal was to the elite and to the esthetically elect, as he saw them. It is characteristic of the tone of An American Place that he did not list its telephone number in the directory, thereby discouraging the idly curious and, presumably, hoi poloi. He and his followers, like the social rea¬ lists, abhored those prevailing American values which equated success with wealth; but this did not lead him towards art as a way to social justice but rather to art as a way of life. For Stieglitz the good life was that in which the esthetic experience was the most gener¬ ally sought after. It was a life centered, as Lewis Mumford has observed, "in contemplation and idle re¬ verie, high craftsmanship and patient manipulation, a willing acceptance of the emotions, an emphasis on the ecstacy of being, rather than a concentration on the pragmatic strain of 'getting there. '" This was also the temper, by and large, of all the artists of our present exhibition, including those like Prendergast and Davis who were not in the immediate Stieglitz circle. Yet all these artists constituted a group only in the loose sense of having a common ad¬ herence to the central place of form in art and life. This explains in part why it was not Stieglitz or his followers who organized the "Armory Show" of 1913 with its importation of advanced European art on a vast scale. Indeed, the very enormity of the Armory Show made it lack exclusiveness, and although its foreign section was esoteric enough, it was not pres¬ ented with the cultist overtone that infused the atmos¬ phere at "291. " Nevertheless, the then associates of Stieglitz like Max Weber, Marsden Hartley and Arthur G. Dove, as well as Stieglitz himself, very probably understood what was going on at the Armory Show better than its organizers, Walt Kuhn, Arthur B. Davies and Walter Pach. And it was above all Alfred Stieglitz whogave of his enthusiasm, breadth of interest, vision and per¬ sonal fortune to nourish the new mode in the early days - not only by written and spoken work, but by dedica¬ ted support of its leading photographers and artists. Without staging the Armory Show, he prepared the way for it in several preceding years through his modern in¬ sights - by precept and action. Despite his herculean efforts in arranging the exhi¬ bition, includinga trip abroad at his own expense, Kuhn was relatively little affected by it. Most of the Ash University of Iowa Libraries

record.full-text: Can group also participated in one way or another but were not fundamentally changed. Their central inter¬ est lay in projecting the world around them; cubism, futurism, fauvism, even Cezanne seemed to offer little that would enhance this objective. Robert Henri, their leader and evangelist, was completely unaffected, al¬ though as a liberal he supported the desirability of displaying ail visual viewpoints. Our present exhibition contains works by many, possibly most, of those American artists whoeither shar¬ ed the esthetic of the modern French movement already or were strongly influenced by it as a result of the Ar¬ mory Show. Stuart Davis, for example, although not going to Paris initially until 1928, had already been influenced strongly by the explosion at the Armory, 15 years earlier. Other artists of our exhibition, like Char¬ les Sheeler, were initial converts who then assimilated the European formal emphasis into their own - more rea¬ listic - vision. On the other hand, Maurice Prender- gast's limited but decorative and personal treatment of Signac's example had matured by 1910 and remained essentially the same. Whether their styles matured before or after the Armory Show, all these artists developed a new con¬ ception of art from the contemporary French art of their day. Not one of them created a school of follo¬ wers, despite the willingness of Macdona Id-Wright and despite the strong influence of Max Weber. Rath¬ er, their influence lay in establishing in this country a principle of artistic expression based on the primacy of form. Both Abstract Expressionism and the geometric variants of non-objective art are the logical sequel of the fundamental tendency to abstraction found in these American vintage moderns. Today many of their ex¬ periments appear dated, and they were certainly French inspired, but this exhibition may make clear that if some of them prepared a base for later American abstr¬ action, others pioneered in and predated that abstrac¬ tion. ainly both Macdona Id-Wright and Morgan Russell, if somewhat blocked by their intellectualization, antici¬ pated the art of today and in that sense were far ahead of the great majority of their contemporaries, includ¬ ing the French. Georgia O'Keeffe was also an early experimenter with non-objectivity and merits a place as an Ameri¬ can pioneer of this direction even though she returned to an abstract realism for a considerable period. Like her, Charles Sheeler, Charles Demuth and Stuart Davis developed a personal form of abstract realism which finds no close parallel abroad, yet which is only a step from current "hard-edge" abstraction. Max Weber's artistic maturity came later, but his originality and ex¬ perimental attitude and his concentrated search for a personal esthetic typifies these artists as a group. In the mosaic of achievement which creates the progressive artistic character of a period, the better artists support and express the new tendencies, a feat which may in itself require considerable insight, cour¬ age and ability. A very few others, while also draw¬ ing from the past and present, have the genius not mere¬ ly to be up-to-date. They create work whose true ori¬ ginality may come as o pleasant surprise only later, af¬ ter their vision has become generally adopted. This ex¬ hibition reveals the remarkable extent to which Ameri¬ can artists of an earlier generation employed the forms of expression which many people have thought original to our time. The years have shown the true avant-garde to be those who were dedicated not to a particular style or subject matter but to a fundamentally new insight - that art need not imitate, that it may be esthetically self-sufficient. It was launched in America largely by these artists. They opened the way for a new freedom of expression, greatly increasing the power of the pic¬ torial arts to express the complex nature of life today. Frank Seiberling In particular the best of Arthur B. Dove had no close French parallel in its time and, indeed, looks not only American but remarkably contemporary. John Ma¬ rin, too, developed a statement which is more a person¬ al vision than a European parallel and, again, looks remarkably current. These two artists are the giants of our group in terms of their early originality, but cert- University of Iowa Libraries

record.full-text: CATALOG with BIOGRAPHICAL NOTES Because the exhibited works date no later than 1932, the biographical notes refer to the given artist's develop¬ ment, generally speaking, up to that time. Most of the artists moved towards a greater or lesser degree of abs¬ traction in the years that followed, and some changed their approaches radically. The aim of the exhibition is to suggest their contribution to a modern esthetic, during the pioneering period. The artists are listed alphabetically and the dates of works are those given by the owners. OSCAR BLUEMNER, 1867-1938. Born in Hanover, Germany, of a family of architects, he studied painting and architecture in Germany be¬ fore coming to this country, at the age of 25. He prac¬ ticed architecture successfully until 1912 when, although 45 years old, he retired from architecture and became a full-lime painter. He traveled extensively in Europe, where he was impressed with German Expressionism and with Cubism. He was given his first one-man show by Stieglitz in the fall of 1915. Bluemner's painting has a warm precision, an Expressionistic tendency only partly restrained by an architectonic order drawn from Cubism. The result at best has a certain grandeur and mystery. 1. OLD CANAL PORT Oil, 30-1/4x40-1/2, 1914. The Whitney Museum of American Art 2. WINTER NIGHT (YELLOW AND BLACK) Oil, 21 X 26-1/4, 1930. Bertha Schaef§r Gallery JOHN COVERT, 1882- Born in Pittsburgh, Covert lived in Munich from 1908- '12, where he had a scholarship from the German gov¬ ernment. He moved to Paris for the following two years and also did some traveling in England and else¬ where on the Continent. Hence Covert had a longer exposure to the modern European than did most Ameri¬ can artists who traveled abroad in the early years of University of Iowa Libraries

After returning to this count¬ ry in 1916, he continued his abstract experimentation, painting a number of unusual non-objective works. He retired from painting after 1923. 3. BRASS BAND Oil, 26 X 24, 1919. Yale University Art Gallery; Collection, Socifetfe Anonyme STUART DAVIS, 1894- Born in Philadelphia, he came to New York at the age of 16 and studied for three years with Robert Henri. Under this influence, he became a social realist and contributed satirical cartoons to the Masses, then a liberal-socialist magazine which was suppressed for 8 Davis i.i*'-.' J Nas* 12 Demuth its pacifism in 1916. He developed considerable skill as a draftsman. The Armory Show had a more profound effect on him than on most other Henri alumni. At first. Van Gogh provided a psychologically sympathe¬ tic carryover from social realism, but Davis moved ra¬ pidly towards greater abstraction, experimenting brief¬ ly, by 1920, with non-objectivity. He developed a very personal style during the '20's, even though in¬ fluenced by Picasso and Lfeger. On the whole he re¬ tained a strong feeling for the object which he presen¬ ted in flat planes or sharp contours brilliant in color and tastefully organized. Davis's first trip to Paris in 1928 only confirmed and heightened his enthusiasm for modern French art, but he continued to show this influ¬ ence in a highly personal way, more brash and gaythan the French. He stuck rather consistently to a "hard" contour and was certainly one of the most successful abstractionists in America prior to the '40's. He com¬ bined to an unusual degree the power to project objects in a formal way which, though considerably distorted in shape and color, were somehow amusingly real and convincing. 4. PUkCE PAS DE LOUP Oil, 36-1/4 X 28-3/4, 1928. The Whitney Museum of American Art CHARLES DEMUTH, 1883-1935. He was born in Lancaster, Pennsylvania, to which he often returned as an adult. He always retained a strong attachment for his home there. Slightly incap¬ acitated from polio, he lacked robust health. A mod¬ est independent income enabled him to live without financial duress. In these physical and economic res¬ pects he somewhat paralleled Toulouse-Lautrec, like whom he was also something of a dandy and Bohemian. He studied at the Philadelphia Academy and never quite abandoned the meticulous draftsmanship he learn¬ ed there and which he continued to develop independ¬ ently. Abroad in 1904 and 1912, he was greatly im¬ pressed with Cezanne's water colors and, after the sec¬ ond trip, began experiments in water color which led to Cubist Realism, which he and Charles Sheeler dev¬ eloped independently, around 1917. While this style might never have evolved without its French prototype, it was distinctly American in its attachment to the sub¬ ject and in its clarity of light. Certain parallels are found also in the work of Lyonel Feininger and Stuart Davis. Demuth became a close friend of Stieglitz who gave him one-man shows at An American Place. He preferred water cobr to a greater extent, even, than John Marin, and beside his cityscapes, which are certainly among the best of their day, he executed many meticulous and refined flower studies; also, high¬ ly personal book illustrations, which he preferred to do for sophisticated, psychological novels and short stories such as those of Henry James. In the draftsmanship of these illustrations he recalls Klee, but he lacked Klee's range of interest, subtlety and depth. Demuth, never¬ theless, is an interesting artist who brought a very per¬ sonal, refined and decorative abstraction to American realism. 10 University of Iowa Libraries

The Columbus Gallery of Fine Arts, The Ferdinand Howald Collection ARTHUR G. DOVE, 1880-1946. Born in Canandaiguo, New York, he became a success¬ ful illustrator in New York City (1903-1907). After a trip abroad in I907-'08, he gave up commercial art and tried a combination of farming and painting. By 1910 he was already working as an artist In a highly indivi¬ dual and abstract manner, with varying extent of abs¬ tract reference to the outer world. His first one-man show at Stieglitz' "291" gallery, in 1912, marked the beginning of a long and intimate relationship in which Stieglitz' belief in Dove's originality was unwavering. Dove's painting has a lyrical quality, an unusual dir¬ ectness and a certain pathos. Sometimes his work is marred by crudeness of color relatranships. But the very lack of a French taste and refinement in color, or perhaps of interest in such, gave the natural origin¬ ality of Dove an independence wanting in many mod¬ ern American artists of his generation. Dove painted in a way that was more abstract than most French artists, yet there remained a paradoxical realism in most of his art, which was deeply rooted in nature. He transformed natural into abstract forms in ways to evoke a variety of moods, and is certainly an early, if not the first. Abstract Expressionist. Dove even made collages having emotional content and which, like so much of his painting, were far more than exercises in formal ar¬ rangement. On the whole he avoided geometric shapes 11 University of Iowa Libraries

RUNNING RIVER Oil on Metal, 21 x 16, 1927. The Downtown Gallery 20. BOAT GOING THROUGH INLET Oil, 21 X 29-1/2, 1929. The Downtown Gallery MARSDEN HARTLEY, 1877-1943. A native of Lewiston, Maine, Hartley loved the rugged terrain of his state, where he often returned to paint in the summers. He lived there again during his last years. At the turn of the century he was studying at the Chase School in New York, following a period at the National Academy. He began to paint Impression¬ istic landscapes and was also influenced by the dark palette and large shapes of Albert Ryder. His first one-man show was held at "291" in 1909. His early style gave way to new experiments following a trip abroad in 1912-13, where he was especially impressed with Kandinsky and Delaunay. He exhibited with the American section of the Armory Show, with the Blue Rider group in Munich and at the Berlin Autumn Salon of 1913 - all exhibitions which favored new tendencies. 12 University of Iowa Libraries

In the '20's Hart¬ ley returned to a more realistic style having a strong¬ ly Expressionistic tendency. There is a vigorandspon¬ taneity to his painting which accounts partly for its rea¬ dy appeal and also for its occasional unevenness. He was not a painstaking craftsman like Max Weber, for example, nor so complex a person, but he brought to pioneering American abstraction a corresponding fresh¬ ness that had the joy of discovery and a dynamic ener¬ gy and directness. 21. The Whitney Museum of American Art STANTON MACDONALD-WRIGHT, 1890- Born in Charlottesville, Virginia, he lived in France for several years after 1906, founding with Morgan Russell in 1913 a school of abstract painting called Syn- chromism. Influenced by Cfezanne, Synchromism sought to achieve form through the advancing or reced¬ ing effects of colors. It tended in practice towards a high degree of abstraction, even to non-objectivity. Morgan Russell had more experience in art than Mac¬ donald-Wright and took the theoretical lead in their enterprise, which also involved manifestoes released in 1913 against Delaunay's rather parallel movement, Orphism. An art movement as theoretically based as Synchromism was no doubt foredoomed, but it served 31 Marin [I ) 24. E Oil, 47-1/2x47, 1915. University of Iowa /'/.y- 14 University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 15

record.full-text: a valuable function in its time as a radical statement for the importance and sufficiency of form in art as distinct from content. It served to spur abstract exp¬ erimentation by other artists who gave little or no cre¬ dence to Synchromism's theories of "color orchestra¬ tion" and movement. In terms of a future favoring non-objective art, Macdonald-Wright's and Morgan's paintings were certainly among the most avant-garde of their day. Macdonald-Wright returned to this country in 1916 and in the following year was given his first large one-man show, by Alfred Stieglitz. Like many other American artists working before the '20's, he turned away from abstraction for a time. His rec¬ ent paintings are again non-objective. 26. CONCEPTION -SYNCHROMY Oil, 30x24, 1915. The Whitney Museum of American Art 27. ORIENTAL, SYNCHROMY IN BLUE-GREEN Oil, 36 x50, 1918. The Whitney Museum of American Art 28. CALIFORNIA LANDSCAPE Oil, 29-7/8x22-1/8 The Columbus Gallery of Fine Arts, Ferdinand Howald Collection JOHN MARIN, 1870-1953. 35 Marin Born in Rutherford, New Jersey, Marin first took up ar¬ chitecture as a career, practicing it for a number of years. Following study at the Pennsylvania Academy in 1899 he became increasingly attracted to the graphic arts and gave up architecture. Abroad most of the time between 1905 and 1911, he at first made etchings in a Whistlerian manner and saw relatively little contempo¬ rary art; but by 1908 his water colors had become some¬ what more experimental. Following his first one-man show at "291" in 1910 and from meeting Alfred Stieglitz the previous year, he became more interested in the mod¬ ern French movement, though he never pursued it system¬ atically or extensively. Stieglitz perceived his talent, lavished praise and encouragement upon him and contri¬ buted to his economic security. It was at this time, at the age of 40, that Marin began truly to find himself as an artist. At first, the freedom and spontaneity of Fauve art provided him a tool for expressing his emotional re- 15 University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 16
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: action to the dynamism of American urban life. Under his brush the skyscrapers seemed to pulse with energy and yet with a certain instability - half-noble, half-fright¬ ening. In the years that followed, Marin's essential esthetic modernity derived increasingly from his strong sense of the picture plane. He was very sensitive to the dual function of brush strokes as flat shapes - which may have an abstract, decorative relation - and as an illusionary suggestion of volume and spacial depth. Like Dove he remained attached to nature - at least during the period covered by this exhibition - and he too demonstrated that he could work in a completely abstract way. Moreover, while regularly starting from nature, he frequently pushed the developing abstract¬ ion so far as to become, in effect, abstractly Expression¬ istic. Marin's work, if it does not always achieve the "Blessed Equilibrium" he sought, does seem to flow from inside, to arouse a direct, intimate sense of the artist. While not devoid of theory or formal influences - he certainly knew the water colors of Cfezanneand stud¬ ied Cubist art - his work remained singularly free of external and inhibiting formal influences. He did not develop a fundamentally new style or found a school, but his is one of the most "realized" and personal con¬ tributions to modern American abstract art. 29. TREE AND SEA, MAINE Water Color, 22-1/2 x 15-1/2, 1932. The Downtown Gallery ALFRED H. MAURER, 1868-1932. Maurer was born in New York City. His father was a well-known artist working for Currier and Ives. The son had a conventional academic training and became a successful conservative artist, winning a First Prize at the Carnegie International in 1901. However, in the previous year he hod gone abroad, where he became friends with the avant-garde in Paris, including Gert¬ rude Stein and Matisse. Maurer was an early convert to Fauvism. His drastic change of style bewildered and outraged his father, leading to on estrangement. Maur- er's first one-man show, at "291" in 1909, attracted only apathy or hostility from public and critics. He soon switched from his Fauve manner to Cubism and became one of the best Cubist painters in America. He also painted haunting portraits whose exaggeratedly large eyes are evocative and yearning. He was a sensitive man whose lack of recognition ended in suicide. Maur- er's art swung between the polarities of Cubist discipline and a Fauvist-Expressionistic vehemence. 40. Bertha Schaefer Gallery GEORGIA O'KEEFFE, 1887- Bom in Sun Prairie, Wisconsin, she studied at the Art Institute of Chicago and at the Art Students League in New York under William M. Chase, the apostle of the loaded brush. She also studied with Arthur Wesley Dow. From these various sources and on her own initiative she developed a sound mastery of traditional techniques; but she was much too original in spirit to be satisfied with this and began experimenting with abstraction on her own. O'Keeffe did not meet Alfred Stieglitz, her future husband, until 1916, after he had seen and ad¬ mired some abstract drawings of hers. A one-man show followed. For a time previously, she had been teach¬ ing in Texas. In New York after 1916 and especially in the '20's, she began experimenting with enlargements and enlarged details of natural forms, employing abs- tractrealism andagenerally high scaleof color values. These and her surrealistic skulls are popularly associat¬ ed with her but she also painted many landscapes -often highly abstracted - and some non-objective works which were among her most exciting of the '20's. O'Keeffe very probably received some influence - or at least support for a natural tendency - from the precision and clarity of Charles Demuth, but it was not the Cubist side of Demuth's style; O'Keeffe's painting, with a few exceptions, is only at the fringe of Cubist-Realism. It has been called Precisionist and Immaculate/ terms which are indeed suggestive. More than most artists, she has painted in a continuing variety of ways, all marked by clarity and reserve, the more impressive for the enlargement of subject. An age of scientific ab- servation and of the precise machine may be implicit in the culture that could produce such an art; neverthe¬ less, it reveals the beauty of the commonplace and the serenity of precise forms, which she seems to invest also with a pervasive femininity. 46. record.full-text: MAURICE PRENDERGAST, 1859-1924. Bom in St. John's, Newfoundland, he was brought up in Boston. He studied in Paris in l886-'89 where, after a Whistlerian period, he saw Cezanne's work and be¬ came the first in America to support him. His painting gradually evolved towards the decorative style now associated with him - patterns of small flat brushstrokes, representing people in a landscape. The style suggests Signac, but without use of the latter's theories of color harmony and additive color. Prendergast simply took the externals of another style and made something quite personal of it. A genuine pioneer of modem art in Am¬ erica he remained for a number of years the first and only artist in this country working in a Post-Impression¬ istic manner. 56. RESTING, ST. MALO Oil, 24 X 30, 1919. The Columbus Gallery of Fine Arts, Ferdinand Howald Collection 57. MASSACHUSETTS SHORE Water Color and Pastel, 13-1/2 x 19-1/2 The Columbus Gallery of Fine Arts, Ferdinand Howald Collection MAN RAY, 1890- Born in Philadelphia; he gave up the study of engineer¬ ing and architecture for painting, which he studied at the National Academy. Following his first one-man show in 1912 and the Armory Show in the following year, he turned to abstraction and became one of the most aggressive of the avant-garde. He was especially in¬ fluenced by Marcel Duchamp and was taken up by the Da Da group. Because he later became famous as a photographer after moving permanently to Paris in 1921, his contribution to the pioneering of abstract painting in America has been somewhat overlooked. He had a sensitive and fertile approach to designing, often mak¬ ing use of curving shapes in a modified Cubistic over- 53 O'Keeffe lay. 58. JAZZ Air Brush Color on Paper, 31 x 25. The Columbus Gallery of Fine Arts, Ferdinand Howald Collection 23 University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 24
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: f '< 54 O'Keeffe 55 O'Keeffe MORGAN RUSSE LL, 1886- Bom in New York he studied under Henri. After 1906 he became a virtual expatriate in France, where he lived until 1946 before resettling in this country. He was the co-founder of Sychromism with S. Macdonald- Wright, q.v, Morgan abandoned his highly abstract painting in the '20's. 59. FOUR-PART SYNCHROMY Oil, 15-1/4 X 11-3/4, 1914. The Whitney Museum of American Art MORTON L. SCHAMBERG, I88I-I9I8 Born in Philadelphia; he studied at the University of Pennsylvania and at the Academy under Chase. He traveled abroad with his close friend, Charles Scheeler, remaining for three years, l906-'09. He exhibited at the Armory Show. Following an early influence from Matisse and from Cubism, he became interested in ma¬ chine subjects. This latter tendency, in turn, may have been influenced by Duchamp and Picabia, but Schamberg gave it a very personal treatment, less dry than that of the others and without complex and satirical overtones. He foreshadowed the later attempts of the Purist move¬ ment to give the machine a pleasing esthetic expression. He saw in the machine not something monstrous or threat¬ ening but a beneficent influence and source of artistic inspiration. 60. TElfPHONE Oil, 25-1/2x21-1/2, 1916. The Columbus Gallery of Fine Arts, Ferdinand Howald Collection CHARLES SHEELER, 1883- Born in Philadelphia, he studied at the Academy there, l903-'06, partly under Chase. He also attended Chase's summer classes in Europe, but remained conservative in his style until after the Armory show. He then experi- menfea with various kinds of abstraction, being influ¬ enced by Cfezanne, Cubism, and even Synchromism. About 1917, like Demuth, q.v., he began applying a modified Cubism to the rendition of architecture. He was more interested in a balance of textures than was 24 University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 25
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: Demuth, and retained an equally strong or stronger ob¬ servation of the subject. In short, Sheeler is psycholo¬ gically more detached. His lack of emotional involve¬ ment seems to hove permitted an increasing acceptance of visual fact, and his later work, aided by the prelimi¬ nary use of the camera, came to look like a cleaned-up color photograph. Sheeler was, in fact, a very good photographer as well as a realist technician with the brush. He knew enough about form to provide the cold¬ est realism with some pictorial organization. An artist who had worked abstractly, even non-objectively, in the end he did not need the expressive and emotional potential which abstraction and distortion provide. 61. LHASA Oil, 29 X 35-1/2, 1916. The Columbus Gallery of Fine Arts, Ferdinand Howald Collection 62. BUCKS COUNTY BARN Tempera and Crayon, 19-1/4 x 25-1/2, 1923. The Whitney Museum of American Art 63. LANDSCAPE Oil, 10 X 14, 1915. The William H. Lane Foundation studies for painting. In New York by 1900, he began study at the New York School of Art in 1902; but the greatest impact on his development as an artist came from living in Italy between I909-'I2. He also visited and lived in Paris. As a native Italian attracted by ex¬ perimental art, he gravitated naturally to Futurism, a movement glorifying dynamic action and founded by Italians. In the U.S. at the close of 1912, he began the work which led to some of the best Futurist paintings done anywhere, although the fragmented motion at the formal core of the style was hard to handle and resulted in some failures. Some of Stuart Davis's abstractions of the '20's may be at least cousins of Futurism, the pictorial liveliness of which undoubtedly appealed to many artists who could not subscribe to the movement's philosophical premises, in fact, a dynamically active, yet totally organized picture plane is the foundation of contemporary "action painting," in which Kandinsky and the Futurists and such Americans as Dove and Ma¬ rin are pioneers. And Stella, as an early - perhaps the first - Futurist in this country, was one of the most suc¬ cessful in producing a shifting, yet organized, effect. In time, Stella combined Futurist movement with Cubist- Realism to produce some of the greatest of American paintings within the broad Cubist milieu. JOSEPH STELL^, 1879-1946 Born in Muro-Lucano, Italy, Stella gave up medical 64. DER ROSENKAVALIER Oil, 24x30, c. 1915. The Whitney Museum of American Art 56 Prendergast 57 Prendergast 25 University of Iowa Libraries

record.full-text: 65. ABSTRACTION Water Color, 7x 11-1/2, 1918. The Downtown Gallery 66. COMPOSITION Pastel, 25 x 19, 1914. Private Collection 67. NEW YORK INTERPRETED Gouache and Ink, II x 8-1/2, 1923. Private Collection MAX WEBER, I88I-I96I Born in Russia, he came to this country at the age of 10. He studied at the Pratt Institute under Arthur W. Dow from 1898-1901. In Paris from l905-'08 he studied at the Julian Academy and with Matisse. He moved in the avant-garde circle and exhibited in several shows. Back in the U.S. in 1909, he exhibited at the Haas Gallery prior to meeting Alfred Stieglitz, upon whom he had an important and up-dating influence, even though Stieglitz had already exhibited Matisse and was aware of new trends. Weber was perhaps the most ec¬ lectic of the pioneer American moderns. He explored both Futurism and Cubism thoroughly during the early period of our exhibition and in the '20's continued, un¬ der a variety of influences, especially of Cezanne. He worked a great deal with the figure. Weber was a cul¬ tivated man with an avid curiosity about art which led him to all the museums and to a catholicity of taste. He had an eye for quality in both the past and present and was among the first Americans to recognize the import¬ ance of African negro art and of the modern primitive, Henri Rousseau, as well as the complexity of CSzanne. Primitivism remained a recurring and important part of his art, representing his search for enduring, ageless human qualities. Even as a Cubist, Weber had a per¬ sonal manner, giving expression to the passion and poet¬ ry of his nature. He often achieved a lyrical effect, or it could be one of great intensity. His was a rich con¬ tribution also to youngerortists, many of whom admired his painterly methods and enjoyed the contact with an artist of such breadth and depth. 68. record.full-text: PHOTOGRAPHY The photographers whose works are exhibited here are representative of the Photo Secession Group, a- round and including Alfred Stieglitz. Early works are emphasized. The intent is to suggest the experimental climate in photography, created by outstanding pion¬ eers such as these; also, their serious purpose to make photography an art without subservience to other art forms. ALVIN U^NGDON COBURN, 1882- Coburn took part in the original Photo Secession and remained a close friend of Stieglitz, who had discov¬ ered and continued to encourage his unusual talents. Beginning with the soft-focus photography fashionable at the turn of the century, Coburn turned away from a conception of photography as a way of imitating paint¬ erly or graphic effects. Instead he and a few of the photographic avant-garde began developing a style re¬ lated to the special potential of the camera forclarity and textural differentiation. Coburn was perhaps the most versatile of the pioneer photographers. He could work well in any manner. The photographs exhibited here are intended to give an idea only of his early style, prior to the Armory Show. 1. WEIR'S CLOSE - EDINBURGH 7-15/16 X 6-5/16, 1906. The Museum of Modern Art 2. BERNARD SHAW 8-5/16 X 6-1/2, before 1908. The Museum of Modern Art 3. ALFRED STIEGLITZ, ESQ. Diameter 6-3/16, before 1908. The Museum of Modern Art EDWARD STEICHEN, 1879- glitz, juror at a photography show in Chicago, hung most of Steichen's entries and in the following year bought the first photographs Steichen had sold. Camera Work No. 2 was given to his pictures, Steichen helped Stieglitz found the Photographic Secession of 1902. Steichen traveled abroad a number of times after 1900 and it was he who sent Stieglitz the drawings and wat¬ er colors of Rodin, Matisse and Cezanne and the Bran¬ cusi sculpture which were "firsts" in America at "291. " He became a colonel in World War I in charge of re¬ connaissance photography. (In World War 2 he was in charge of all Navy combat photography.) After the first war, he gave up painting to devote full time to the camera. He subjected himself to the most rigo¬ rous discipline, taking over a thousand photographs of a white cup and saucer on a white ground. Steichen is perhaps best known for his portraits, generally hav¬ ing highly effective contrasts of light and dark. But his refined technical skill and elegant feeling for de¬ sign were revealed equally in still life and urban scenes. In recent years he has been active in administrative work as Curator of Photography at the Museum of Mod¬ ern Art, from which he retires this year. Note: Nos. 4-8 are printed from negatives made from the original prints. No. 9 is from the original negative. 4. THE POOL-EVENING 13-13/16 X 10-5/8, 1899. The Museum of Modern Art 5. MY LITTLE SISTER Lillian Steichen, now Mrs. Carl Sandburg 7-3/16x9-11/16, 1899. The Museum of Modern Art 6. GEORGE FREDERICK WATTS 13-5/8 X 10-1/2, 1903. The Museum of Modem Art Born in Luxembourg; his parents moved to this country two years later and settled with him in Hancock,Mich¬ igan, where his father became a miner, his mother a milliner. Apprenticed as a youth to a lithography com¬ pany, he made photographic portraits on the side, also painted. He organized and was first president of the Milwaukee Art Students League. The Museum of Modern Art 17. THE MAURETANIA 13-5/16 X 10, 1910. The Museum of Modern Art 18. SPRING SHOWERS, NEW YORK 12 X 4-7/8, 1900. The Museum of Modern Art PAUL STRAND, 1890- Born in New York; he was given his first camera at the age of 12 and studied with Lewis Hine, who was then beginning his series of photographs of immigrants. He visited the "291" gallery soon after its opening and be¬ came a great admirer and friend of Stieglitz, who later introduced him to avant-garde painting and criticized his photography, giving him a one-man show in 1916. The last two issues of Camera Work were devoted to his photography in 1917. He experimented successfully with abstract photography, with documentaries of the city, and with the broad impact of the machine on soc¬ iety. By the mid-'20's, he was able to travel and be¬ gan a series of poetic nature studies. Strand has also worked,off and on,with motion pictures, being a camera man for the notable film of social realism "The Plow that Broke the Plains" and "Native Land," a film on the civil rights theme. A cultivated, warm and also sophis- 34 University of Iowa Libraries

Strand has produced photographs which have rarely been equaled for their uncanny combination of matter-of-fact- ness, visual order and deep feeling. record.full-text: PAINTINGS DRAWINGS SCULPTURE PRINTS from TWENTY-THREE IOWA COLLECTIONS A CATALOGUE OF THE EXHIBITION MAY 9 - AUGUST 6 together with an address by GIBSON A. DANES given at the opening of the exhibition and honoring the first use of the remodeled NEW GALLERY OF THE DEPARTMENT OF ART all being part of the XXIii FESTIVAL OF THE ARTS OF THE SCHOOL OF FINE ARTS THE UNIVERSITY OF IOWA 1961 University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 02
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: FOREWORD EARL E. HARPER, Director School of Fine Arts From galleries, museums, and private homes throughout the state of Iowa, paintings, sculptures, drawings and prints have been provided on loan to the State University of Iowa for an exhibition in the magnifi¬ cent new galleries of its Department of Art which first marked the open¬ ing of the new and beautiful facilities, and then remained to become a major feature of the Twenty-Third Annual Fine Arts Festival. This exhibition is composed of irreplaceable art objects of great aesthetic quality and intrinsic value. It affords indisputable evidence of great cultural interest in, and understanding of, the art of today throughout the state of Iowa. This exhibition, brought together by Dr. Frank Seiberling and the art faculty and now on view to the University public, is memorably signifi¬ cant, diversified, and rewarding. THE ARTS, THE ART GALLERY, AND THE UNIVERSITY TODAY The Challenge of the Best* GIBSON A. DANES, Dean The School of Art and Architecture Yale University It is indeed a pleasure to share with you in the celebration of your annual Festival of the Arts and especially in the dedication of your newly-expanded Art Gallery. Of the many developments in modern society, one of the most stirring in higher education has been the recog¬ nition of the significant role of the visual arts within the academic en¬ vironment. * an address on the occasion of the opening of the remodeled New Gallery of the Depart¬ ment of Art, May 9, 1961. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 03
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: This increasing awareness of the importance of displaying man's imaginative and creative achievements has taken place largely during the past three decades. A half century ago a gathering such as this, and especially one honoring collectors of modern art, was unheard of. The rapid metamorphosis of the art gallery has been one of the most satis¬ fying revolutionary developments in our time. The number of new museums and galleries dedicated to the visual arts has not only in¬ creased in America from a dozen or so in the late 19th Century to now almost a thousand, but even more importantly, this once venerable in¬ stitution has acquired new life and a sense of purpose. The art museum of even the recent past was too often an inert palatial storehouse. To¬ day, however, the museum in this country has become a vital educa¬ tional instrument, as natural and necessary to the cultural life of a town, city or university as the library or concert hall. That far-sighted Bostonian, James Jackson Jarves, one of the most advanced and perceptive collectors and art critics of the mid-Nineteenth Century, described the art gallery of his time; "In America the popular notion of them is simply as depositories of curiosities to amuse an idle hour, but not of sufficient importance to be critically examined." He goes on to justify the art gallery in the Victorian moralistic tone of that day: "Even for no higher purpose they deserve to be multiplied; for they beguile many from haunts of vice, and in the end will assuredly come to be esteemed on more rational if not aesthetic grounds. As it has taken several centuries to reduce the sense of beauty in us as a race to a mere negative state, probably it will take as many more of culture and encouragement in the opposite direction to make it a vital force again." I feel certain that even such a discerning and, at times, caustic com¬ mentator as Jarves, would have been surprised and delighted could he have known that his time table was far too pessimistic. The art gal¬ leries have certainly become a vital force in our society and if they have not "beguiled many from the haunts of vice," they have continually en¬ hanced the means for men to enrich the texture of living today. We have grown, during this period, I believe, wiser and much more sophisticated about the many-realmed mansion of the arts. We have become accustomed and attuned to the unexpected richness and diver¬ sity of the expression of our time. I think we can honestly say that we have grown in our perceptions and understanding. It is appropriate to note that your university was one of the first of the pioneers in making it possible for creative men—painters, writers, sculptors, playwrights, poets—to work and teach within the frame¬ work of academic disciplines. Your university was among the first to give them academic equality, not looking upon them with Puritanical dubiety nor treating them suspiciously as second-class citizens. Your precedent has been followed in one form or another by virtually every University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 04
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: college and university in the United States. The arts have clearly come of age. Another phenomenon closely related to the programs of studio teach¬ ing and of intensive, professional research in the practice of the arts, is the study of the arts as a part of the liberal education for all students. These developments during the past quarter of a century have been partly responsible for the stimulation of the interested layman and for the initial inoculations of the dedicated, serious collector. It is equally important to train the audience as it is the artist. Just as the playwright needs a stage, the artist needs the gallery and the museum. The art gallery in a university today exists along with the library as a center from which all students may gain a clear and vivid perception of the richness of man's accomplishments. It is a meeting ground for the producer (the artist) and the consumer (the layman). Just as the library is the storehouse of verbal knowledge, the art gal¬ lery is the repository for visual knowledge. Works of art re-create vividly the living historical moments of the past. As the late Francis Henry Tay¬ lor wrote, "It is this universality of a work of art which gives it its wide audience. For here is a document of history which any man can under¬ stand. . . . The museum and the library have been called the two halves of the public's memory of the past. But the museum, because of its obligatory emphasis on quality, is indeed much more; in its disposition to preserve the fragments of the past, it can . . . teach the truths of the ages . . . and thus develop in the individual a capacity for improve¬ ment." The art gallery, containing standards of excellence of the past and present, like the library occupies a special place in the life of a univer¬ sity. It is a resource, like the compact strata of gold and silver in a min¬ eral deposit, to be gleaned by those who seek. The accelerated growth of the art gallery in this country was paral¬ leled by the expanding disciplines of the History of Art and Archaeology and newer fields of Anthropology and the Social Sciences. These all combined in their various ways to provide a broader base for the re¬ search and methodology which has greatly enhanced our understanding of the Arts of many older but "new" civilizations. Our sense of time and space has been extended. It was not so long ago that Art History and also the museum dealt with a more limited scope of man's creative past. The arts of the ancient Mediterranean world, and even there only certain periods and centuries, were respectable, along with the Renais¬ sance in Western Europe. This neat tidy world of humanist scholarship and archaeology was disrupted by the acute perception of many gifted artists in the late 19th and 20th Centuries when they discovered the beauty and power of the arts of Africa, the South Seas and Pre-Co¬ lumbian America. The esthetic intuition of the avant garde painter and sculptor has broadened the spectrum of the scholar and critic. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 05
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: We realize today how the carvings, paintings and ceremonial artifacts and objects of once distant cultures give a wider range of artistic pleasure; but perhaps even more critical is the full comprehension of the meaning of the arts as the only basis for understanding the heritage of the Americas and Africa. The work of art is often the only point of contact that we have for generating common levels of communication. The objects themselves offer no linguistic barriers. They can "speak" to us with full intensity. We can become much more knowing and aware of the psychological attitudes of the present day Central and South American citizen by a knowledge of their artistic heritage. The richness and diversity of the ancient and colonial epochs are justly a source of national and regional pride. They possess a sense of history and con¬ tinuity with their many pasts that is very different from ours. Here our understanding is not only necessary, but grows more urgent almost by the hour. Bartlett H. Hayes has stated: "With the increasing awareness on the part of educators that man has learned to control nature, there is now a concomitant awareness that he has yet to know how to con¬ trol himself. To gain this knowledge is one of the primary functions of the Humanities and to implement it is one of the primary functions of Art. Suddenly, in the first order of things. Art has a practical function coupled with daily survival." It is a vital function of the university museum to present and inter¬ pret those cultures which may be alien, but are the very ones which can be most clearly grasped and we hope enjoyed through their varied artistic achievements. The growth of the art gallery has also paralleled the rise in impor¬ tance of our own contemporary artists, architects, painters, designers, and sculptors. The museum is certainly the custodian and the instrument of re-creation of the past, but it is also the recorder of the active present. For the first time in the history of our country our artists and architects have in their time achieved international recognition, and have affected directly young artists of all nations. It is relevant to note that the bright and promising artists have been often first recognized by the museum, which has played a vital role of exploring and presenting the arts of today. There is a broader and possibly a deeper function that the art gal¬ lery at a university may fulfill. It is a focal center for a rich interplay among the humanists—men of letters, historians, philosophers, artists, and scientists. At least some measure of the much-discussed cultural gap among learned men may be alleviated by the catalytic action of works of art and special exhibitions on a university campus. An art gallery can serve as the center for an intellectual meeting ground where the original objects of art become the generating source for the exchange of ideas. Joseph Fruton, a biochemist, said: "If one considers the endeavor of the individual artist or scientist, whether it be in University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 06
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: poetry or physics, music or chemistry, there is in each a blend of in¬ spiration and craftmanship, of imagination and self-discipline. To gain new insight into the world of nature and the world of man, the artist as well as the scientist, whatever his special business, seeks to abstract, through inspiration and imagination, what seems to him the "true" es¬ sence of the objects of his interest. Whether a painter suddenly becomes aware of a (to him) strikingly new configuration of forms and colors in a haphazard collection or ordered assembly of objects or people, or whether a chemist suddenly 'sees' the relative positions of the atoms in the molecules of a substance about which he has a set of partly con¬ nected data, each has had an inspiration whose emotional intensity may be no different in degree." The interplay between inspiration and technique may be clearly demonstrated in the potential of the art gallery on the campus of a mod¬ ern university which is today quintessentially as diverse and abundant as the world we live in today. Virtually every major discipline of the sciences and the humanities has many telling aspects to be revealed and comprehended visually. It is often easy to forget that the arts have never been and are not remote from life. The very nature of artistic creation is illuminating and revelatory. The arts provide a many-mir¬ rored world whose reflections may brilliantly light up seemingly remote corners of the intellectual life of a university. The art gallery becomes on one hand a vivid extension of the teach¬ ing in the classroom and studio, and on the other it is there for brows¬ ing, for exploration and reflection. The gallery must do more than simply store works of art: it must become a proving ground by which young artists may gauge and measure their own experiments and in which all students may perceive man's creative action at its highest level. It is equally a laboratory for the students who will become our historians, critics, artists and collectors. It presents the challenge of the best. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Paintings, drawings, sculpture, prints from twenty-three Iowa collections: a catalogue of the exhibition, The University of Iowa, May 9 - August 6, 1961
record.description: Festival included an address by Gibson A. Danes; "From galleries, museums and private homes ... this exhibition is composed of irreplaceable art objects of great aesthetic quality and intrinsic value. It affords indisputable evidence of great cultural interest in, and understanding of, the art of today throughout the state of Iowa ... brought together by Dr. Frank Seiberling and the art faculty"--page 2.

record.full-text: INTRODUCTION 50 5 C Xlr; 1 I -h q'^- /-I The Fifth Summer Exhibition of Contemporary Art at the State University of Iowa ful¬ fills a promise made in the catalogue of the First Exhibition in 1945, to the effect that "in succeeding years sculpture will be shown." The Exhibition is presented as a feature of the Eleventh Annual Festival of Fine Arts. The sculptures shown have been chosen by Dr. Lester D. Longman, Head of the De¬ partment of Art, and assembled under the guidance of Professor Humbert Albrizio, instruc¬ tor in sculpture. The jury to recommend work for purchase consisted of Jacques Lipchitz, Robert Laurent, and Lester D. Longman. Work by jury members will automatically be consid¬ ered for purchase. The catalogue was designed by Dale Ballantyne. The State University of Iowa thanks those who have made loans for the Exhibition and in particular expresses its appreciation to the following galleries in New York City: A.C.A., 61 E. 57th St. Artists' Gallery, 61 E. 57th St. Kleemann, 65 E. 57th St. Kraushaar, 32 E. 57th St. Associated American Artists, 711 5th Levy, 42 E. 57th St. Avenue Buchholz, 32 E. 57th St. Matisse, 41 E. 57th St. Clay Club Sculpture Center, 4 W. 8th Midtown, 605 Madison Ave. Street Downtown, 32 E. 51st St. Egan, 63 E. 57th St. Grand Central, 55 E. 57th St. Parsons, 15 E. 57th St. Passedoit, 121 E. 57th St. Willard, 32 E. 57th St. EARL E. HARPER Director, School of Fine Arts The University of Iowa pop APT^ University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 05
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: FOREWORD Universities ordinarily give little attention to sculpture. It seems fitting, therefore, that this fifth Summer Show should be devoted to a selection of sculpture representative of current production and typical of such exhibitions in the major museums of the country. Most of the objects included were created within the past few years by well-known, liv¬ ing artists. There are three principal trends in sculpture since the war. Together, they make this exhibition quite different in appearance from a similar survey in 1939. They are best illustrated in the work of such men as Lipchitz, to whom the younger men are greatly indebted, Moore, Arp and Calder, who also anticipate recent trends, Roszak, Lipton, Fer- ber, Noguchi, Giacometti, Hare, Smith, Amino, Nickford, and Grippe. The first trend is the multiplication of new media and methods of using them, parti¬ cularly the exploitation of welded and brazed stsel, beaten lead, and translucent plastics, and such innovations as the mobiles of Calder and the demountable sculpture of Nogu¬ chi. The artist continues to stress the textural appeal of his materials and endeavors to take full advantage of its possibilities as a medium. The second is the emergence of the idea of opsn rather than closed form. Sculpture is no longer exclusively an art of volumes enclosing space. Of course, Lipchitz, Archipenko, Moore, and others have long used voids within volumes as part of the plastic design. Now, however, sculpture often tends to approximate three-dimensional graphics. The third is the surrealistic preoccupation with the potential violence and treach¬ ery inherent in forms. It is a highly-charged, centrifugal psychology, whose pressure frac¬ tures the graceful and orderly discipline inherent in decorative organizations like those of Morris and Archipenko, and the early cubist "Woman" of Laurens. And by comparison it transforms the standard expressionism of Kaz and De Creeft into polite comment. It University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 06
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: seeks incongruous perspectives, strange encounters, nameless labyrinthine apparitions, and all manner of animated and marvelous phenomena. Often its discoveries hold the psychoanalytic mirror of art before the face of modern society. That is why its images haunt the complacent and make them angry. In the long run, however, it is therapeutic. And in any case great art is always a sharp instrument, not a plaything. There is continuous cross-fertilization between painting and sculpture, although in modern times painting is usually in advance of sculpture in introducing new general con¬ cepts insofar as these are independent of medium. Thus, in a sense, Calder may be said to translate Miro into sculptural terms, while Moore, Lipchitz, and Laurens give us sculp¬ tural equivalents of Picasso, and Noguchi and Amino of Tanguy. In previous Summer Shows we have seen paintings by Klee, Ernst, Matta, Baziotes, Gottlieb, Stamos, Rothko, Ruvolo, Seliger, and others, which are analogous in concept to the work of the younger experimental sculptors. The tension customary in painting between tradition and experiment seems some¬ what relaxed among sculptors. Lipchitz likes the work of Kreis, Kreis compliments Amino, Laurent praises Calder, Albrizio admires Giacometti. Such tolerance is healthy in that it permits the free operation of a basic principle in art. It would seem a truism, yet it is worth repeating, that to create a work of art which will live, an artist must do what he has to do, responding only to that which most deeply moves him in human experience. This is the central argument for freedom of expression, and of exhibition, performance, or pub¬ lication in the arts. It is both a right and an obligation, and may not be abridged, with¬ out mortal damage, either by lack of integrity in the artist himself, or by limiting the range and nature of his expression through patronage. A sincere artist cannot cater to the rules of an academy or to the expectations of a public which "knows" what is beau- University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 07
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: tiful. The result, at best, is technically proficient. Nor can he afford to follow fashions. The result is, at best, skillfully mannered. The artist who tries to please public taste when he longs to do something else is neither better nor worse than the one who attempts the lat¬ est style without having the life experiences which would normally produce it. In the light of this principle of freedom it is hoped that the visitor will endeavor to broaden his range of sympathies and refine his capacity to discriminate. Above all, give more than a passing glance to objects which intelligent and devoted men took months or even years to create. The rabid modernist should study carefully such works as those of Maillol, Kreis, and Zorach. He will then discover the injustice of speaking of all work of a traditional character as "academic." There is a sense in which great art does not date. There are no rules by which we can learn to make a work of such classical serenity as the Maillol "Bather." The "Girl Withdrawn" by Kreis has the grace and beauty of French de¬ tente sculpture of the 16th century, while the "Embrace" by Zorach rivals Rodin in esthetic quality and surpasses him in the delicacy, the dignity, and the nobility with which the love theme is expressed. Marini is influenced by Chinese sculpture, and his "Susanna" re¬ minds one as well of a nude by Rembrandt, but these bows to tradition cannot conceal its esthetic vitality. It vibrates with life, like the work of Roszak or Flannagan. The compulsive conservative should study most diligently the objects he likes least at first, and make an effort to revive a dormant imagination. If he gets so far as to remove from his voice the tone of ridicule and indignation it will be a great advance. If he de¬ cides to try his own resources in sculpture, he will quickly learn why these strange and startling inventions are considered beautiful. The realm of the beautiful is not so confined as some people suppose; nor did the Greeks exhaust its possibilities. On the other hand, in learning to discover values in unfamiliar forms, remember that one does not sacrifice University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 08
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: his pleasure in traditional styles of expression. The two have much more in common than appears at first glance. Obviously not all modern literature, music, and art has merit. But "modern art" is often attacked as a whole by the inexperienced, most of whom fail to realize that it has been going on for over half a century with increasing momentum, and is not a tempo¬ rary fad. Those who would like to be done with it should know that we can no more go back to the art of 1890 than we can to the science of that year. In both, what has hap¬ pened is indehbly inscribed in the stream of thought. Artists and critics have long since discovered that they are not likely to hear any ad¬ verse comments which have not been made hundreds of times before. They usually try to answer sympathetically, even though they have nothing to gain but to see others share their enjoyment. The only alternative, and much the easier course, is to dispose of prejudice and intolerance quickly by implying that one needs a special gift of insight to understand. This, however, is not the truth. Anyone can understand who has the opportuni¬ ty and is willing to take the time and effort, but not merely by obtaining further informa¬ tion. For the understanding of art is an educative process, not an informative one. Genuine education is a process of mental and spiritual growth which alters and develops one's personality as a whole. Hence it is not easily accomplished. One can see "modern art" for years, and learn how others react to it and what experts can be counted on to say, but if one has not experienced art in such a way that he becomes somehow different, he has learned nothing of importance from it. This is not to make of art appreciation a mystical process of revelations and conversions. It is merely the kind of thing a genuine education normally accomplishes in any field of liberal studies. LESTER D. LONGMAN University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 01
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: the University of l-mm Libraries VIRGIL M . HANCHER President of the State University of Iowa, 1940-1964 The Twenty-Sixth Fine Arts Festival is dedicated to Dr. Virgil M. Hancher who retires this year as the thirteenth president of the State University of Iowa. No one better epitomizes the title "Loyal Son of Old Gold." President Hancher was graduated from the Universitv in 1918, having served as senior class presi¬ dent, having led his class in scholarship, and having been elected to Phi Beta Kappa and Omicron Delta Kappa, senior mens honor society. He received the degree of Jiuis Doctor from the State University of Iowa in 1924. During his presidency, the State University of Iowa has grown in enrollment from 6,600 to 13,000, and the number of full-time faculty members has grown from 300 to 700. The value of the physical plant has increased from twenty-two million dollars to more than one hundred million dollars. These statistics are but a reflection of the development of the educational program which has kept pace with the tremendous expansion of knowledge. President Hancher's dedication to high tonality has brought excellence to the University's program of teaching, re¬ search, and service. President Hancher's talents as an educational leader have been widely recog¬ nized. He has served as president of the National Association of State Universi¬ ties, as president of the Association of American Universities, and as chairman of tlie American Council on Education. President Hancher's interest in international affairs—educational, political, so¬ cial, and economic—has been demonstrated by his appointment to many inter¬ national conferences and comniissions. In 1949, President Hancher was a dele¬ gate from the Association of .American Universities to a conference on Indian- American affairs in New Delhi. Now, fifteen years later, he returns to New Delhi to contribute his talents and insights to the Southeast Asia Program of the Ford Foundation, In 1952, President Hancher was appointed a member of the United States Na¬ tional Commission for UNESCO, serving until 1955, President Eisenhower ap¬ pointed him a member of the United States delegation to the United Nations Fourteenth General Assembly in 1959, Besides the degrees earned at the State University of Iowa, President Hancher holds the degree of bachelor of arts in jurisprudence from Oxford University, where he was a Rhodes Scholar, and an M,A. degree from Oxford University. Twelve colleges and universities have conferred honorary degrees upon him. f]f<.\ i-O p '¦ - ^7 ,¦ , c '^ p 3 r .' University of Iowa Libraries
