record.full-text: THE PRESIDENTS On the following pages are portraits and biographies of the thirteen presidents and four acting presidents of the State University of Iowa. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 09
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: AMOS DEAN /((/(/ J8.55 to February 1859 From early photograpli—no portrait availalile SUI's first president, Amos Dean, made only three short visits to Iowa City during his four- year administration. He preferred to retain his position as chancellor of the Albany La\v School. Dean organized die work of instruction for the new institution, outlined its policies, and applied to Congress for a fiuther grant of lands. His scheme of nine departments included mathematics, languages, prep school, geology, zoology, natural history, mineralogy, chemistry, and the normal department. Five teachers formed SUI's first faculty. Classes were held in the Mechanics' Academv while provisions were made for the first building constructed by the state. During his presidency. Dean recommended suspension of instruction to gather funds for operation and building, and to give students more time to become tjualified. The Board demanded he become a resident of Iowa City when instruction was resumed, but since his interests remained in the East, Dean resigned in 1859. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 10
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: SILAS TOTTEN Fcdl 1860 to August 1862 From early photograph—no portrait available SUI's second president, Silas Totten, had been rector of Trinity Parish of Iowa City, had served at William and Mary in Virginia, and had been a member of the faculty of Trinity College in Connecticut, where he was president for eleven years. He named the first department heads at SUI, reorganized the collegiate department, and suggested a prep school for thirteen-year-old entrants. Totten's theories of education are shown in this excerpt from his address on University Education, dehvered in Representatives Hall, Des Moines, before his appointment, ". . . What is a University or what ought it to be? It is not only an institution where knowledge is disseminated, but where it is also originated. It is a place both for instruction and investigation." Under his administration enrollment rose from 172 to 2.54. Totten resigned in 1S62. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 11
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: OLIVER SPENCER 1862 to June 1867 arionvmous Oliver Spencer, SUI's third president, had been a professor of chemistrv and philosophy under Totten. During his administration the Civil War began, and for the first time the number of women enrolled doubled that of men. Coeds were active in soldiers' aid societies making bandages and scraping lint. Old South Hall was built in 1864 and Old North Hall, containing a chapel, a chemistry laboratory, and an astronomical observatory, in 1865. Students and facultv were required to attend chin-ch at least once on Sunday. The chemistry laboratory was considered to be the best in the United States; however when coeds scheduled chemistry the professor, who was of German extraction, exclaimed "Mein Gott! I vill haf no petticoats in mine laboratory!" But he did, and seemed to enjoy it. President Lincoln appointed Spencer as consul at Genoa, Italy, in March, 1865, and in 1867, having decided to stiiv abroad, Spencer resigned. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 12
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: NATHAN R. LEONARD i<S67 to 1868 F. Schurig Nathan Leonard, professor of mathematics, served as vice president during Spencer's leave, and became acting president in 1867. Under Leonard, special activities were instituted in behalf of the students. The University's building committee was given authority to buy certain buildings that could be removed to lots owned by the University and rented to students who desired to board themselves. The Mechanics' Academy came into state possession as a dormitory. Leonard stepped down in 1868 for the successor to Spencer, but was appointed acting president for another year when Black resigned in 1870. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 13
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: JAMES BLACK March 1868 lo December 1870 anonvmous The State University of Iowa took definite form during the administration of tlie Reverend James Black. He was experienced in the field of higher education, having served as vice president of Washington and Jefferson College in Pennsvlvania. During his two years, the departments of law and medicine were inaugurated. Black was an excellent speaker and very j^opular witli the students, but his health was poor and he resigned in 1870, University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 14
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: GEORGE THACHER 1871 to June 1877 Ellen Day Hale Although George Thacher came to the University directly from the pulpit with little administrative experience, his term brought advances in the instructional program, and an expansion of the college curriculum. The normal department was abandoned, and a chair of didactics was set up for teachers" training, starting the first permanent teacher education program on a college level in this country. The whole academic period was extended to six years, with two to be sub-freshman. Three majors, classical, philosophical, and scientific, were outhned. In 1873 the chair of English language and literature, and a coiuse in civil engineering were established, Thacher left the presidency in 1877, University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 15
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: CHRISTIAN W. SLAGLE 1877 to June 1878 anonymoiLS Christian W. Slagle, a member of the Board of Regents, was selected as president pro tern. He agreed to act as head of the University for one year. During his term the state legislature provided the first permanent endowment for University support, an endowment long sought. The General Assembly then passed an act in 1878 prohibiting the use of anv part of the funds for instruction m prep or non-collegiate classes after July I, 1879. Records show that at the end of Slagle's administration 903 students had been graduated from the State University of Iowa. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 16
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: JOSIAH L. PICKARD 1878 to 1887 anonvTiioiis The sixth president, Josiah Pickard, came to the University with experience in the field of public education. He had been superintendent of public instruction in Wisconsin, and superintendent of Chicago schools. During his nine-year term, the Universitv went through an important period of growth and expansion. Sub-collegiate wcnk was dropped and closer relations developed between SUI and high schools. The mecUcal building was erected in 1882 and the geolog)' building in 1884. The dental and pharmacy departments were added, and the law course was extended to two years. President Pickard reorganized the University into four divisions, collegiate, law, medical, and homeopathic medicine. Pickard resigned in February of 1887, University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 17
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: CHARLES A. SCHAEFFER March SO, 1887 to September 23, 1898 Bradford Lambert A Striking physical growth took place during the administration of SUI's seventh president, A former professor of chemistry at Cornell University, Schaeffer worked to obtain funds for building a chemistry laboratory, a modern hospital, a gymnasium, and a homeopathic medical unit, and sought additional svuns for greater library equipment and an athletic field. In 1890 the citv donated an entire block and the adjoining street for the hospital, but the General Assembly refused to grant appropriations, Schaeffer finally succeeded in providing a permanent building fund through an annual tax. Just as the building program was starting, 1897, the library in Old North Hall burned and valuable collections were lost, Dr, Schaeffer died in the beginning of his twelfth year. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 18
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: AMOS NOYES CURRIER 1898 to 1899 F. Sehiirig Amos N, Currier, dean of the college of liberal arts, was appointed acting president of the University in 1898, He had attended Dartmouth, taught at Central College for ten years as a professor in ancient and modern languages, and at SUI for forty years as a professor of Latin. George MacLean, SUI's eighth president, said of him, "If it is difficult to be president, it is deadly to be acting president. Dean Currier not only survived, but strengthened himself and the institution." In June of 1899 Currier retued to become professor emeritus of Latin and literatvu'e, and historiographer of SUI. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 19
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: GEORGE E. MACLEAN June 1899 to June 1911 Gollaiicz As eighth president, George E. MacLean did much to fulfill Schaeffer's dream of campus expansion. His administration has been called the building era. The program included Schaeffer Hall (the collegiate building), the medical laboratory, the anatomy buildings, the engineering building, the law building, and Macbride Hall, which was completed upon removal of the geology building to its present site in 1905. University Hospital, the present East Hall, was ready for occupation in 1902. The medical course of studv was extended to four years. By I9I0, eighteen buildings stood from the proceeds of the millage tax. During this administration $150,000 was spent for campus growth. SUI now owned fortv acres on the west side of the river, where it originally held only thirteen. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 20
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: JOHN G. BOWMAN Fall 1911 to March 1914 on loan from the University of Pitt.sbiirgli, Pitt.sburgh, Pa. John G. Bowman became the ninth president of SUI at the age of thirty-five. He was a former instructor, alumnus, and a native of Iowa. Bowman had completed his education at Columbia University and had been an instructor there in English. He had served as secretary of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, as a director of the American College of Surgeons, and as a trustee of the National Board of Medical Examiners. His was a difficult administration; unrest and confusion resulted from attempts by the newly created State Board of Education to reorganize and reapportion the work of instruction. In spite of this. Dr. Bowman was able to organize two new colleges, education and fine arts, the latter operating for only two or three years. University extension was also developed under this progressive administrator. The president's home, the physics building, the laundry, Eastlawn, and the women's gymnasium were completed, and Currier Hall was started. It was under Bowman's administration that SUI made many advances in the area of student go\'ernment, and took the initial steps toward building a student union on the SUI campus. Bowman resigned from the presidencv in March of 1914. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 21
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: THOMAS H. MACBRIDE 1914 to 1916 Charles A. Cumming Professor Thomas H. Macbride had been the head of botanv since 1884 and was advanced in years when he accepted the presidency in 1914 with the understanding that he \\'ould soon be reheved. He had begun teaching at fourteen and had served as a country school teacher before coming to SUI where he eventually became head of botanv. Macbride is credited with the establishment of the Iowa Lakeside Laboratory at Lake Okoboji. During his administration the new dental building was started and plans wei-e made for the school of music. Dr. Macbride, a quiet and gentle man, beloved by his students, stepped down from the presidency in 1916. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 22
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: WALTER A. JESSUP August 1916 to July 1934 Sidney Dickinson SUI's eleventh president, Walter A. Jessup, came to the University in 1912 as director of the school of education with a background in public school supervision in Indiana. He had been dean of the college of education at Indiana University, and became the first dean of the college of education at the State University of Iowa. During his administration the most notable feature was campus expansion and construction on the west side of the Iowa River. New buildings included the children's hospital, 1917; Westlawn, psychopathic hospital, and the Quadrangle, 1919; the armory, 1920; fine arts studio and pre-scliool, 1922; cliemistry-botany-pharmacy building, plumbing shop and women's gymnasium annex, 1923; DeHaan building, Kellogg dormitory, and University Hall, 1924; field house, medical laboratory, Iowa Memorial Union, 1927; the power plant, 1928; general hospital, 1929; stadium and water filter plant, 1930; locker house of Finkbine field, 1931, and the central garage and mechanical engineering laboratory, 1932. A marked development in the medical college and the state hospitals also took place during Jessup's progressive administration. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 23
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: EUGENE A. GILMORE July 1934 to July 1940 Harold Brett Before coming to SUI, Eugene Gilmore had spent nearly ten years as vice governor and secretary of public instruction in the Philippine Islands, and had been visiting professor of law at several universities. He had served also as acting dean of the University of Wisconsin law school, and as dean of the law college at the State University of Iowa. His administration brought a further development of the campus on the west side of the river. The fine arts building and the law commons were completed in 1935, the University theatre in 1936, the botanical laboratory and the pharmacy manufactiuing laboratory in 1938, the shelter house in 1939, and the transmitter house and Hillcrest in 1940. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 24
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: CHESTER A. PHILLIPS /((/(/1940 to November 1940 Cloy Kent (Mrs. James Kent) Iowa City Chester A. Phillips served as acting president between the terms of President Gilmore and President Hancher. He had been head of the college of commerce since its founding in 1921 and retained this position until 1950. Phillips was one of the original directors on the board of the First National Bank in Iowa City, and has served in this capacity since 1932. In 1940 he became an economist for the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, III, Dean Phillips retired to become dean emeritus of the college of commerce (now business administration) in 19.50, and professor emeritus in 1952, University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 25
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: VIRGIL M. HANCHER November 1940 to June 1964 Portrait by William F, Draper (see Frontispiece) Coming to the University from a successful cor¬ porate law practice in Chicago, SUI's thirteenth president, Virgil M, Hancher, took office on the eve of World War II, That conflict and the world¬ wide social and political upheavals which fol¬ lowed were to have profound implications for higher education. Enrollments fluctuated widely, dropping off during hostilities and then rising to unprecedented heights in two great waves—the returning war veterans and the present crop of postwar babies now entering college. There was an explosion of knowledge, particularly in the sciences, which required new and expensive re¬ search tools and the trained minds to use them. Competition among colleges and universities for qualified faculty reached new dimensions. On the Iowa City campus, a lack of building funds during the depression and war resulted in an acute shortage of space. Under the leadership of President Hancher, the University survived the problems of this era with an enhanced reputation. In the mid-1940's, some little time before the idea had won the wide acceptance it enjoys today in leading universi¬ ties, Iowa revised its cinriculum to include re¬ quired general education courses in the liberal arts. During and following the war, research ef¬ forts were stepped up on all fronts, as University scientists made major contributions in such areas as space research and satellite instrumentation. hydraulics, medicine, speech pathology, chemis¬ try, physics, and many more. Progress in the sci¬ ences, however, did not obscure the University's traditional concern for the arts and humanities. The eminence won in these fields in the 1920's and 30's was maintained through the published work of SUI scholars and creative writers and the acclaim won by many of its painters, print- makers, sculptors, musicians, playwrights, and dramatic artists. In addition to its teaching and research programs, the University's service con¬ tributions to the people of the state were strength- £ ned, reflecting President Hancher's concern that the life of the University be more directly inter¬ woven with the life and activity of all lowans. New University agencies established during the period, such as the Bureau of Labor and Manage¬ ment, the Bureau of Business and Economic Re¬ search, the School of Social Work, and the Insti¬ tute of Public Affairs, exemplified this concept of the institution's role. The long-awaited building program also be¬ came a reality. Some of the major projects of the Hancher years included a new centralized li¬ brary; greatly enlarged dormitory and union fa¬ cilities; a general classroom and faculty office building; buildings for joiu-nalism, law, phar¬ macy, business administration, physics, and speech pathology; and additions for engineering, chemistry, psychology, art, zoology, and the medical center complex. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: The president and the portrait: a featured presentation of the Twenty-Sixth Annual Fine Arts Festival, Iowa Memorial Union, State University of Iowa, June 10 - August 5., 1964, including the festival program.
record.description: Festival included two art exhibitions (1) Drawing and the figure, 1400-1964 and (2) The President and the portrait: Presidents of the State University of Iowa from 1862-1964; Museum of Natural History exhibitions; lectures by Dr. Harlow Shapley, Dr. Marjorie Hope Nicholson, and Dr. Peter D. Comanduras; plays by William Gibson, Harold Pinter, Karl Sternheim, and Michael Shurtleff; an opera "La Boheme" by Giacomo Puccini, conducted by Herald Stark and directed by Seldon Faulkner; "The presidents: On the following pages are the portraits and biographies of the thirteen presidents and four acting presidents of the State University of Iowa"--page 8.

record.full-text: Introduction Foreword A separately printed part of The University of Iowa's art catalogue features the Elliott Col¬ lection of twentieth century paintings, silver, and prints. This catalogue acquaints the viewer with five exhibitions assembled for the opening of the Museum: A selection of previously acquired paintings, sculptures, and prints. Some works by former and present teachers of the School of Art. 3. Paintings and sculptures by graduates. 4. Prints by Mauricio Lasansky's former stu¬ dents. A selection of variations of contemporary sculptures. The University of Iowa collection, above all, possesses two masterpieces: the nineteen-foot Jackson Pollock "Mural" of 1943 and Max Beckmann's "CarnivalTriptych" of 1946. The former is a gift of Peggy Guggenheim, the latter a Mark Ranney Fund acquisition from the Annual Summer Exhibition. These showings, from which important acquisitions were made, were inaugurated by Earl Harper in 1939. Lester Longman, then Chairman of the Art Department, made the selections in cooperation with his faculty. It is only natu¬ ral, and history proves it constantly, that the endorsement of the new meets opposition. However, the violence and irritation about the purchase of a 1939 Miro exceeded all cus¬ tomary disagreements. Misrepresentation and twenty years of irate letters to newspaper edi¬ tors make this painting one of the University's most familiar possessions. Other paintings by Stuart Davis, Marsden Hartley, and Bradley Tomlin were similarly acquired. By the 1930s the School of Art was well enough established to attract distinguished artists as teachers: Grant Wood and Philip Guston are two names which come to mind first; more recently, prominent teachers include a British artist, Keith Vaughan, repre¬ sented by a landscape; Olivier Strebelle, Belgian, by a kinetic sculpture; and David Hockney, British, by a painting graciously loaned by the American Republic Insurance Company. Grant Wood is represented by two drawings: one is the cartoon for the "Daughters of the Revolution," donated to Coe College by our patrons Owen and Leone Elliott. This draw¬ ing brings the thought that the fame of an artist could be based on a single work. Had Leonardo created only the "Mona Lisa," his¬ tory would remember him by a single paint¬ ing. It might well be that Grant Wood's reputation in the future will depend on such genre works as the "Daughters of the Revolu¬ tion" and "American Gothic," which are suf¬ ficiently strong and memorable to overshadow his other oeuvre. The second interesting genre work by Wood in the exhibition is a large milking scene in the artist's pseudo-primitive manner, successful because of its very unpre- tentiousness. Grateful acknowledgement is made to John Deere and Company for its loan. Philip Guston, another exhibitor, taught at the School of Art in the 1940s. A I960 canvas, "Traveler II," is an oil, very painterly, with closely related values and animated brush strokes. This part of the exhibition includes also the work of painters currently teaching: Byron Burford, Stuart Edie, James Lechay, Eugene Ludins, and the printmaker, Mauricio Lasansky. A landscape by Charles Cumming, who headed the Art Department from 1909 to 1927, is also included. Although hundreds, if not thousands of stu¬ dents have been graduated from the School of Art and are now living and working through¬ out the nation, only a representative selection of their work is shown. Selection emphasizes former students represented by New York 12 University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 13
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: Why Iowa City? galleries and names remembered from the past. The exhibited sculptures fit no unifying cate¬ gory apart from works by currently teaching sculptors and a few diverse pieces represent¬ ing different philosophies. The indoor sculpture court features, in addi¬ tion to the two works by Pollock and Beck- mann, Pol Bury's "Kinetic Sculpture," a ten- foot, stainless steel, motorized sculpture com¬ missioned by the Museum's Advisory Com¬ mittee and donated by Mr. and Mrs. C. H. Crowe. The outdoor sculpture court displays "Crete" and "Snowplow" by Mark di Suvero, recently exhibited in Chicago. Kinetic blades towering twenty-five feet, by George Rickey, mark this artist's best-known style. Other ob¬ jects like Brian O'Doherty's esoteric "One," Ted Victoria's sound sculpture, and the brothers' Baschet musical aluminimi sculpture emphasize the variety of this exhibition. It is a pleasure to acknowledge the recent gift of a number of noteworthy art works which top off our American section. They reflect not only the generosity of the donors but, hope¬ fully, the attractive power of our new Museum for future donors. Mrs. Charles Prendergast has given three fine paintings by her brother- in-law, Maurice. Louise Noun has given an abstract painting of figures by Kienbusch. Mr. and Mrs. James Schramm have given an early and unusual abstract figure by Henry Moore and a splendid figure painting by Max Weber. An unusual drawing of the Ash Can School by William Glackens comes from Robert Brady. Special thanks are due to Mauricio Lasansky for giving his time and thought to an exhibi¬ tion of former students' prints shown in the Museum auditorium; to Irwin McFadden for designing the catalogue and to Gustave von Groschwitz for his painstaking supervision; to Frank Seiberling for advice and help when¬ ever it was needed and for being one of the main forces in the creation of the Museum. Ulfevt Wilke On May 5, 1969, The University of Iowa Museum of Art will open its bronzed alumi¬ num doors to the public for the first time. The opening of the new museum will be celebrated with a week-long festival — "Arts and the Artists, 1969" — culminating in the dedication of the building on May 11 by President Howard R. Bowen in the presence of the donors, who gave more than one- million dollars for the construction of the building. A total of 334 works of art, including the Owen and Leone Elliott Collection, will be shown as follows: 105 twentieth century paintings 97 old and contemporary prints 19 drawings and watercolors by old and mod¬ ern masters 21 African and conteinporary sculptures 86 pieces of silver, chiefly English. The theme of the five exhibitions listed here is The University of Iowa Tradition in Art. The state was established in 1846 and the next year the University was founded. Charles Cumming was the second head of the Art De¬ partment beginning in 1909 and made the long trip weekly from Des Moines. He was a portrait and landscape painter and some of his portraits still hang in Old Capitol. In 1908 the Mark Ranney Memorial Fund was set up as a bequest and is still used for the purchase of works of art. In 1939 the first of a series of Suminer Fine Arts Festival Exhibitions began with a showing of Grant Wood's paintings. Subsequent exhibitions were quite varied and often included pictures lent by well-known dealers. With the help of this fund it was possible to purchase important paintings and also drawings by Vasari, Guercino, Gellee, Boucher, and Grosz. The Museuin is proud of The University of Iowa Art Collection which includes gifts as well as purchases. The large Jackson Pollock "Mural" painted for Miss Peggy Guggenheim was given by her to the University in 1948. She was quoted recently by the Christian Sci¬ ence Monitor as having said, "But there was one particularly that I regretted having given away ... I tried to get it back again . . . (and) offered them a Braque . . . and they replied, 'We prefer American art' . . . Rather touch¬ ing." In her very frank, absorbing memoirs Out of This Century, Miss Guggenheim has described how in 1943 she coinmissioned "this new genius" whom she had discovered. "After weeks of hesitation he began wildly splashing on paint and finished the whole thing in three hours." Other American paintings purchased for the University Art Collection include important examples already mentioned. Print purchases include Hayter, Munch, and Picasso, and new prints by Motherwell and Ray Parker. The collection also includes some African sculp¬ ture, a Lipchitz and a Henry Moore. Another special exhibition will be devoted to the work of former teachers and graduates of the School of Art. They include Guston, Parker, Meigs, Gwathmey, and Miriam Scha- piro. (Ulfert Wilke, Director of the Museum of Art, also has a graduate degree from the School of Art.) The opening of the Museum is an occasion not only to look back but also to look ahead. Therefore, a group of sculp¬ tures will be shown, including work by di Suvero, Rickey, and the Baschet brothers. Pol Bury was commissioned to make a ten-foot fountain sculpture which has been placed in an interior slate-lined court whose ceiling with an eye and radiating spokes is thirty feet high. And finally there is the special exhibition of thirty-four prints by former students of Mau¬ ricio Lasansky, who has done so much to add to the "Iowa tradition" during the last twenty- four years. Some of these artists have in turn become well known, including John Paul Jones, Leon Goldin, Lee Chesney, and Moishe Smith. The exterior design of the Museum is like a prairie house — fitting into the hill rising from the nearby Iowa River — and faintly reminiscent of a cornice-topped Ren¬ aissance palace, except that the facade con- 13 University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 14
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: The Growth of the Art Museum Concept sists of modular precast panels of variegated shades which take the light marvelously well. Even more impressive is the interior with its effect of voluminous but well-ordered space. The Museum of Art will serve a campus com¬ munity of 20,000 individuals and a state that is certainly art-conscious. One visitor summed up his impression thus: "I need something to inspire me. The Museum does that." Gustave von Groschwitz In a university community, students, faculty, and public having an interest in art quite naturally prefer to see or study the art work in its original form. Some reproductions, to be sure, are quite faithful to the original, and practical considerations require every art de¬ partment to gather an archive of color repro¬ ductions, slides, and photographs. It is these teaching aids which have functionally come first in the academic environment. Yet, the natural attraction of live art and the happen- stances of time almost always result in gifts of art objects, and their gradual purchase. At that first moment of acquisition, an art collec¬ tion is born, even though it may be years be¬ fore enough additional works are added to constitute a collection in a more usual sense. Meanwhile, the pioneering steps may be en¬ tirely forgotten. Thus, we have no record of the first acquisi¬ tion of art by The University of Iowa, al¬ though the record is quite specific as to the beginnings of art instruction. That was in 1882, when a course in freehand drawing was offered in the civil engineering department. In the today of rapprochement between the artist and the technologist, it is interesting that many centenarian colleges and universi¬ ties instituted their art courses in the science At The University of Iowa — then the State University of Iowa — an art department as such first came into being in 1906. In that year, the new department, located in the Col¬ lege of Liberal Arts (now Schaeffer Hall), listed three courses in studio art and six in art history. That makes the Iowa Art Depart¬ ment, with the notable inclusion of Yale, one of the very oldest in the nation to combine these two branches of art under the same ad¬ ministration. The chairman of this historic beginning was Frank DeWitt Washburn, who taught the history of art courses. Even more surprising, in a way, was the founding in 1906 of a Museum of Art and Archaeology, also located in the Liberal Arts Hall. This marked the official beginning of the University's collection. The chief pur¬ chases in those early years, besides a few casts, were portraits of University presidents. Alumni paid for a number of the portraits of deans and a few popular members of the teaching faculty. These portraits for the most part were hung around campus in the areas where their subjects worked. Many are still so located. It was not until 1936 that the Art Department achieved its own building and art gallery. The gallery was located in what is now the art library. Although a large exhibition loaned by the Metropolitan Museum in New York and including Rosa Bonheur's colossal "The Horse Fair" was staged there in 1948, the most important campus exhibitions, in the main, were shown in the Iowa Memorial Union. The Summer Fine Arts Festival Ex¬ hibitions showed contemporary works each summer for over twenty-five years beginning in 1939. Most of the present collection's American paintings and a few others from overseas were acquired from these summer shows. In 1963 an extensive remodeling of the Art Department's gallery was undertaken. A mezzanine level, now used for periodical lit¬ erature of the library, doubled the exhibition potential. Much better proportions of space and greatly improved lighting were other concomitants. The locus of important shows now shifted to the Art Building. The potential for large scholarly shows was established. Of these the most important was a retrospective exhibition of the works of Charles Sheeler held in 1963, with a substantial catalogue. However, Vin¬ tage Moderns, another pioneering exhibition, was staged in the old gallery in 1962. It documented the presence of abstract art in this country in the earlier part of the century. Impressionism and Its Roots, 1964, brought the most valuable paintings to be shown in Iowa in the postwar period and was a popular U University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 15
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: exhibition having an historical format. Draw¬ ing and the Human Figure, also in 1964, with 165 entries and a scholarly catalogue, may serve as a final example of the types of exhibi¬ tion that followed the creation of a profes¬ sionally adequate exhibition area. Indeed, it was both the adequacy and also the limitation of the gallery which suggested to Mr. and Mrs. Owen Elliott the desirability of yet another step leading to a complete mu¬ seum. It would be designed as such and spa¬ cious enough for a substantial permanent collection along with changing shows. The Elliotts' farsightedness and munificent con¬ tingent gift, the fund-raising campaign that followed, and the construction of a new mu¬ seum are now a matter of history. The splendid gift of the Elliotts was joined in spirit and substance with individual contribu¬ tions from several thousand donors. It is worthy of public record that the University faculty and staff alone contributed over $180,000 to the building fund, a gift probably without parallel among American academic institutions. The new Museum of Art of The University of Iowa has one of the finest museum build¬ ings in academic America. Designed by Max Abramovitz of Harrison and Abramovitz, it has impressive interior scale and the technical capability of serving a large exhibition pro¬ gram. A conservation laboratory, curatorial offices, carpenter and workshop, storage areas, and the Maytag Auditorium are among im¬ portant ancillary aids to the Museum's func¬ tion. A number of splendid gifts of art besides those from the Elliotts have also been presented, which augurs well for the future. A lending gallery will serve for rental of orig¬ inal works, mostly brought from dealers, plus prints from the University collection. It may take time for the University and Iowa City communities and for the many con¬ tributing leaders in the state to realize what a splendid achievement they have brought about. A spectacular advance has followed the modest beginning and the patient accumu¬ lations since the first museum of 1906. Each related event during the years that followed served as part of a cumulative basis for a larger concept. This is why the Museum, if not ready for the Elliott gift in 1906, was ready for it fifty years later. The Museum today will be capable, in turn, of generating a whole new era of effective services to the people of Iowa. The next great advance is about to begin. Frank Seiberling 15 University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Fine Arts Festival exhibitions, 1969
record.description: "1969 Fine Arts Festival exhibitions inaugurating the opening of the Museum of Art on May 5, 1969, and continuing until July 15, 1969"--page 1; "This catalogue acquaints the viewer with five exhibitions assembled for the opening of the Museum: 1. A selection of previously acquired paintings, sculptures, and prints. 2. Some works by former and present teachers of the School of Art. 3. Paintings and sculptures by graduates. 4. Prints by Mauricio Lasansky's students. 5. A selection of variations of contemporary sculptures. The University of Iowa collection, above all, possesses two masterpieces: the nineteen-foot Jackson Pollack 'Mural' of 1943 and Max Beckmann's 'Carnival Triptych' of 1946"--page 12.

record.title: Page 07

record.full-text: "The foundation of the art (painting) and the beginning of all these labors of the hand is drawing and coloring," (Cennino Cennini, The Craftsman's Hand¬ book, Chapter IV.) "Thus painting is composed of circumscription (drawing), composition, and the reception of light. . . . No composition and no illumination deserve praise un¬ less there is a good circumscription in addition." (L. B. Alberti, Treatise on Paint¬ ing, Book II.) "I would say the business of a painter is this: to draw with lines and dye with colors . . ." (L. B. Alberti, Treatise on Painting, Book III.) "Painting consists of three principal parts, which we name drawing, measure¬ ment, and coloring. By drawing we mean profiles and outlines placed propor¬ tionately in their places ... I intend to consider only measurement, which we call perspective, moving in some parts of drawing, because without this, per¬ spective cannot be employed practically." (Piero della Francesca, On the Per¬ spective of Painting, Book I.) ". . . the first picture was a simple line drawn around the shadow of a man cast by the sun on a wall." (Leonardo da Vinci.) Thus did a late Trecento craftsman, an artist-humanist, an artist-geometrician, and the "universal man" recognize that the artistic process begins wtih the draw¬ ing of a line. This would not have been as readily recognized or so stated in early medieval times. What might seem blatantly obvious to us did not to the man of the Renaissance. This conception suggests an entirely new attitude toward art and aesthetic theory. Vasari often begins his artist biographies with a formula episode in which an older great artist discovers his successor by accidentally seeing some drawings done by a child prodigy. Cimabue discovers one such prodigy in peasant's rags who matures under his instruction into the great Giotto. The formula always de¬ mands that the prodigy be ragged, ignorant, and of lower caste so as to make his future achievement more miraculous and thereby enhancing also the status of the profession which made this possible. Real or fictitious, these tales are symptomatic of a society that acknowledges draughtsmanship as an essential ar¬ tistic criterion. This criterion was to be elevated to the celestial world of the ideal and deified by what the Cinquecento called Disegno. Painting, as Alberti perceived it, is no more than colored drawing. The enjoyment of a linear con¬ tour, of an indelibly precise continuous outline, is fundamental to the Renaissance ideal of beauty. Whether the line is executed with the energized brittleness of the Pollaiuoh or the harmonic and delicate assuredness of Raphael, it is the qual¬ ity of the drawn line that generates and initiates the expressive force of the fin¬ ished painting. It is a specific part which mirrors the whole. It is this the Renais¬ sance believes and understands. Both Alberti and Leonardo recognize that "excellent" drawing must unite University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 08
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: with other factors equally achieved to conceive the "excellent" painting. How¬ ever, you cannot build without it. Leonardo is concerned with outlines first, then light and shade, and finally color. The empirical world of the Quattrocento artist, the perspective studies, the anatomical studies, the chiaroscuro studies upon which western modern art is built are investigations of the means of recording the visual experience in line. That drawing is a prime factor is as true for painting as it is for sculpture and all of the visual arts. The conception of the three dimensional sculptural volume in the Renaissance rarely dissolves the restrictions and associations of its planar outlines as first conceived in the two dimensional medium of drawing. The David statues of Donatello and Michelangelo are virtually translations of an inesti¬ mable number of recorded but regrettably nonextant sketches of front, side, and back views. Vasari reports on the vast quantity of Michelangelo's drawings and how poorly they were treated. It is as an inveterate collector of drawings and as an historian that Vasari bemoaned the quantity of drawings that were borrowed never to be seen again, the quantity given away to ease some¬ one's poverty, and, worst of all, the quantity that were burned by Michelangelo. Vasari suggested that Michelangelo burned his drawings so that the public could not realize how difficult a physical task his creations were. The modem fictional image of Michelangelo with hammer and chisel, freeing spontaneously a figure from a marble block, is only accurate insofar as it describes the visual effect of the completed work. The truth was quite the opposite. All artists of the Renaissance must have possessed collections of drawings, some of which may have been bound to form sketchbooks. Cennini and Leonardo are very explicit; the formation of these collections must be derived from natural observations, from the art of antique, and from good contemporary masters. (For examples from this exhibition, see the Tuscan drawing, no. 3, and the Pollaiuoli circle drawings, nos. 8 and 9, from the Scholz collection, the Morgan Library's fifteenth-century German drawing, no. 1.) These sketchbooks constituted the visual working vocabulary of an artist from which the other masters and students in his workshop borrowed freely. They provided the heritage of traditional disci- phnes of form that were the means of artistic education. The schools of Florence and Venice owe their dominant position in the history of artistic style to the practice of passing from generation to generation a body of theoretical, technical, and aesthetic knowledge through the medium of drawing as well as the more monumental arts. Many of the unresolved questions in the field of Renaissance art studies might be answered if we possessed more drawings than the few we do. How more complete and accurate our realization of Donatello as an artistic personality would be if we possessed his drawings. Berenson regretted our ignorance of even Michelangelo because of the negligible number of his drawings extant. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 09

record.title: Page 10
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: If this is so for artists whose major plastic and pictorial works are treasured by us, what of an artist like Paolo Uccello whose major works are either nonextant or in wretched condition. Would that we still possessed that trunkful of draw¬ ings which Vasari told us Uccello left to his heirs. Perhaps Uccello's drawings like those of some others were either discarded or so appreciated that they were sought after by other artists and workshops. But the incontestable evidence for the existence and use of such sketchbooks is in the stylistic consistencies revealed in both the expressive form and content of the various Quattrocento schools of art. The pedagogical discipline of workshop training always sent the aspiring artist back to masters of the past through their drawings, as well as through their painting and sculpture. The quality and character of the sketchbooks extant from this period are more than sufficient evidence for what we have attempted to establish. Those by or attributed to Trecento Veronese Masters, Giovanni de'Grassi, Pisanello, Jacopo Bellini, and Leonardo were treasured from as early as the sixteenth century by a series of protective collectors, and were thereby saved from the inevitable de¬ struction resulting from continuous use and indiscriminate handling. Even these, however, did not escape completely unscathed. A perusal of their pages reveals how they were copied over, tampered with, added to, studied. Innumerable examples may be cited to document the function of drawings as a medium of artistic exchange, as were the more monumental arts of painting and sculpture. Jacopo Bellini's sketchbooks, which are so prominent in family documents, are a legacy from his widow to their eldest son. Gentile, and then from him to Giovanni. In fact, the stipulation for Giovanni's inheriting them was that he complete the paintings that liis brother did not finish before he died. Jacopo's legacy was not only enjoyed by his sons but also by the entire body of Venetian artists. Motifs and ideas from these books are still to be seen at work in the eighteenth century in Canalletto, Guardi, Tiepolo, and Piranesi. Another example is recorded by Lorenzo Ghiberti in his Commentaries. He describes an antic^ue statue of Aphrodite which had been unearthed in Siena but deliberately destroyed in 1357, and which was known to him through a draw¬ ing by Ambrogio Lorenzetti. The drawing had been preserved, he continues to tell us, with the greatest care by a friar who was a great draughtsman as well as a sculptor wiro took delight in this art. Such happenings occur frequently, as in the case of Diirer's 1501 drawing of Apollo (?) now in the British Museum. Based on the Apollo Belvedere, then as now in Rome, it could have been known by him only through drawings by other artists. In this present exhibition we may compare a Bloemaert drawing of a Rest on the Flight to Egypt which was copied from the earlier drawing, also exhibited, by Paul Schwender, nos. 16, 32; or the Passerotti interpretation of Michelangelo's Dawn, no. 27. The pedagogical use of drawing in the Renaissance is formularized by the University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 11
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: academies of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries and inherited by their descendants in the present era. Diderot's Essay on Painting succinctly reveals how the advice of the Renaissance masters had been immobilized by unimaginative, stultifying, and deleterious practices. Leonardo had said: First draw from drawings by good masters done from works of art and from nature, and not from memory; then from plastic work, with the guidance of the drawing done from it; and then from good natural models, and tliis you must put into practice. (Richter, I, 484) A beautiful product of this instruction is Tintoretto's Samson, no. 33, from the Bronfman Collection. (The Leonardesque child from the Seiferheld Collec¬ tion, no. 10, is an ecjually admirable example.) "Do you know what will be the consequences," says Cennini, "of this practice of drawing with the pen? It will make you expert, skillful, and capable of making original designs." (Cennini, Chap. XIII.) But in the eighteenth century, Diderot liad lost all respect for in¬ herited but misunderstood Renaissance procedures. Seven years of drawing from the live model in . . . these academic positions, strained, prepared, arranged, . . , coldly and awkwardly taken up by some poor devil, and always the same poor devil, hired to come three times a week to undress and let a professor set him up as a lay figure—what have these to do with the positions and actions of na¬ ture? There would be no mannerism either in drawing or color if nature were scrupulously imitated. Mannerism comes from the master, the academy, the school, and even from the antique. (Diderot, Essay on Painting, Chap. I.) The Romantic reaction against the Academy already can be heard. Diderot is opening the door. Leonardo would have opposed the extremists on either side. Leonardo's advice and Diderot's criticism of its misuse are absolute values for artists anywhere and anytime. It is through the early and constant discipline of drawing that the student's experience is expanded in scope and intensified in depth. One must be alerted that the drawings made of the works of other artists do not become sterile copies, but are alive and fresh interpretations. If drawing is the basic medium for all the visual arts in the Renaissance, surely the human figure is the most persistent subject. Art begins with the drawing of the human figure. For the Renaissance, the study of man was the proper concern of knowledge as it was and must be for art. It was the human figure in its en¬ tirety and in all of its parts that was the daily concern of the training artist and his master. It was the figure drawn over and over again in every pose and every facet of hght that provided a disciplined vision of the human form. (For ex¬ ample: the two pages of anatomical studies by Figino from the Scholz Collec¬ tion, nos. 20 and 21.) It gave to the mature artist of the Renaissance an under¬ standing of man that made possible the creation of an ideal that had no equal since the art of Phidias and Praxiteles. This constant study of the human figure University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 12
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs

record.title: Page 13
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: was to be the source of the philosophically significant disegno interna and the anagram so widely used in the sixteenth century, disegno, segno di Dio. For the Renaissance, the word disegno is synonymous with drawing. Sir Kenneth Clark in The Nude: A Study in Ideal Form said: This is the characteristic of disegno: that it enhances the vitality of a form by our recognition of its completeness. The great draftsmen of this kind— Signorelli or Michelangelo—are not content to record a movement, . . . but press round it, till it approaches some ideal pattern that lies at the back of the imagination: hence the continual hammering at the same motive, the tracings, copies, and replicas that so astonish the profane, (p.221) (Two exquisite examples of this: Bandinelli's Male Torso, no. 12, in the Bronfman Collection and Era Bartolommeo's Female Nude, no. 14, from the Morgan Li¬ brary. ) Throughout the history of western art, three kinds of drawings may be dis¬ tinguished within the many roles this medium enjoys—sketches, preparatory studies, and finished drawings, that is drawings as an end in themselves. Renais¬ sance drawings for the most part are of the first two types. (Raphael's study of a leg and the Carpaccio drawing in the Scholz Collection, nos. 29, 4, and the Louis de Boullogne from the Fischbach Collection, no. 37.) This is also true for post- Renaissance drawings. Leonardo's advice was dutifully adopted by future artists, Italian and foreign, although his warnings and qualifications went often un¬ heeded as Diderot later was to realize. The artist's pilgrimage to artistic monu¬ ments throughout Italy begins to build momentum in the sixteenth century which has yet to diminish. To the altars of Renaissance and Antique art the artists bring their eyes and their sketch pads. (The Morgan Library's Poussin's drawing of an antique sarcophagus, no. 56, is a fine example by an artist who took up perma¬ nent residence in Rome.) By the end of the sixteenth century this pilgrimage becomes almost a prerequisite for the artist who aspires to a role at the top. Non- Italian as well as Italian artists proceed in the same fashion. For the northerners it is a kind of post-graduate study, the Wanderjahre. The success and prestige of the Carracci as icon painters and palace decorators perhaps did much to encourage a modus operandi which they neither initiated nor codified, but to which they strictly adhered. They studied closely the works of Raphael, Titian, Correggio, Michelangelo, Bassano, and Paris Bordone, among others, as well as the sculptural fragments of ancient Rome and the natural world around them. On this they built a corporate vision and ideal which established the entire structure for the new classicism of the Baroque. (The Annibale draw¬ ing in the National Museum of Canada is a fine example of the developed style and taste of the Carracci, no. 39. The Holy Family drawing in the Seiferheld Col¬ lection, no. 38, reflects the romantic revisiting of the Venetian Idyll.) A Neo- Renaissance style which is at once both Florentine and Venetian is established in University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 14
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: Counter-Reformation Rome, a capital which begins to look once more like the great city of the Augusti. The road to Venice, Florence, and finally Rome is the last phase in the creation of the artist. Rembrandt alone of the great seems not to have taken the journey. His masters had paid their respects and passed to him what they had studied. As others who shared this hesitancy to travel, he was able to refer to the increasing wealth of copies in the form of paintings, draw¬ ings, and, above all, prints. These indirect sources did not diminish the number of artists who took their Wanderjahre in Italy. The establishment of the various national academies in Rome was to further provide encouragement and facili¬ ties for the young artist in the form of the Prix de Rome. The execution of drawings for their own sake, as works of art complete in them¬ selves, so well understood in the Baroque and modern eras, is difficult to trace archivally in the early Renaissance. Did the medium serve as a full aesthetic ex¬ pression for the artist? As an art form did drawing have its patrons and collectors as it does today? The documentary evidence is not immediately forthcoming. Is it possible to intuit from this remark in his treatise on painting, "And a good drawing, that is a good circumscription, is often very pleasing on its own account . . ." (Al¬ berti, Book II) that Alberti thought so? It is possible for us to conceive of a society so dedicated to draughtsmanship as was the Quattrocento, nothwithstanding its artisan materialism, that it could not and would not extend a sketch into a de¬ finitive drawing. Considering the variety of means of executing the underdrawing of the fresco (sinopia drawings) in both tlie Trecento and Quattrocento, it is feasible to accept an artist of this period as creating and appreciating drawing for drawing's sake. This attitude may account for the sophistication in selection of different drawing tools, different inks, different tinted papers. It seems unlike¬ ly that this variety of techniques was only to give the artist as well as patron a better idea of what the commissioned painting was to be like, if the drawing was a study for a painting. The range of sinopia drawings is from stenographic or cubistic notations to the most delicate and most finished figures with chiaroscuro modeling. The sinopia drawing beneath Fra Angelico's Cortona Polyptych (1436) provides a beautiful illustration of how intricately modeled were the drawings of his figures. Although much of this exquisite drawing was covered up by the tempera pigment, the richness of this drawing accounts for the ineffable subtleties of modeling in the finished painting. We know that drawings per se were executed, appreciated, and collected in the sixteenth century, and not only by such great collectors as the artist Vasari but also by the French Court with its portrait sketchbooks. Cinquecento intelli¬ gentsia have an educated and romantic taste for the provocative incomplete, for the revelational insights into the operative critical criteria of the creative mind, for the historical and academic assemblage of the progression of steps in the University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 15
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: sc ¦Ms? ^'. #^ I-" .t Tintoretto, no. 33 University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 16
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: development of an idea. The Florentine Martelli family preserved Donatello's early unfinished David which is now in the National Gallery in Washington, D.C, and the unfinished Slaves of Michelangelo are placed by the Medici in the Boboli Gardens. Drawings, inherently, would come into prominence. They are becoming the cabinet possessions to be treasured and studied intimately at one's leisure. Like coins, medallions, and antique gems, drawings could be held in the hand and studied with a glass. Examples of all types of drawings are to be found abundantly in art since the Renaissance. The Carlo Dolci and Bernini portrait drawings from the Seifer¬ held Collection; the Gustave Dore, Aux Tunamhules, from the Brandt Collection; as well as the William Bailey and John Thomas drawings are drawings as ends in themselves. Occasional sketches are more numerous, and the dividing line between them and a "drawing for drawing's sake" is sometimes difficult to dis¬ tinguish. The Degas nudes in the Daniels Collection, nos. 93, 95; the Chagall, no. 124, from the Rogers Collection; and the Sickert portrait study, no. 158, of a model from the Brandt Collection are to mention only a few. Studies for works to be executed in painting or sculpture are equally numerous: the lovely Domen- ichino study for the Borghese Hunt of Diana from the Goldschmidt Collection, no. 44; the Degas study for Le petit dejeuner apres le bain from the Lambert Collection, no. 92; the Larry Rivers studies for the Museum of Modern Art's George Washington Crossing the Delaware, no. 157; and also the Burne-Jones Minerva for the Perseus series from the Ittmann Collection, no. 84. The Rubens drawing from the Morgan Library is an excellent example of his architectural and sculptural decoration for the relief on the left spandrel of the main portal of the Church of St. Charles Borromeo, Antwerp. With society's increasing fascination in the creative process as well as the personality of the artist, it is possible by the time of the eighteenth century for Goethe to write to Eckermann, ". . . Drawings are invaluable, not only because they give in its purity the mental intention of the artist, but because they bring immediately before us the mood of his mind at the moment of creation." Diderot sums up the fascination for the collecting of drawings from the Renaissance to our time: A sketch is generally more spirited than a picture. It is the artist's work when he is full of inspiration and ardour, when reflection has toned down nothing, it is the artist's soul expressing itself freely on the canvas. His pen or skillful pencil seems to sport and play; a few strokes express the rapid fancy, and the more vaguely art embodies itself the more room is there for the play of im¬ agination ... In the latter (painting) the subject is fully worked out for us to look at; in the former (sketch) I can imagine so many things which are only suggested. (Diderot, Salon of 1765, Three Sketches by Greuze.) For the century that treasures its bibelots and evolves an intimate architecture University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 17
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: to provide a showcase for them, this response of the academician is no surprise. To satisfy the multiple functions for which a drawing is produced, as well as to satisfy the artist's personal taste and inclination, a variety of tools and media are used. Although the use of synthetic materials in the present century has added to the flexibility of the medium, most of the presently available equip¬ ment was known to the Renaissance. Cennino Cennini gives a complete list of drawing media. Watrous, in his admirable and indispensable The Craft of Old-Master Drawings, classifies and organizes these into two categories, the Fine and the Broad, examples of which are admirably represented by the draw¬ ings in this exhibition. (See also the classic study by Joseph Meder, Die Hand- zeichnung: Ihr Technik und Entwicklung, 2nd ed., Vienna, 1923.) The fine drawing media consist of drawings done with a sharp pointed in¬ strument, such as a stylus or pen. This includes, therefore, drawings done in metalpoint with grounds as well as pen drawings. The late middle ages and the Renaissance preferred the use of metalpoint, particularly silverpoint. Silverpoint drawings, both technically and aesthetically, were most similar to the preferred painting medium, tempera. Both media demand carefully prepared grounds upon which the image is to be drawn with the aid of a metal stylus. In painting a tempera panel, the drawing could be done with ochre or charcoal. More often in panel painting, however, the image drawn on the prepared ground with a metal stylus was then traced in with charcoal. The procedures with both media demanded precision and patience and produced the absolute linearism and lim¬ ited chiaroscuro that the early Renaissance preferred. The clarity and brilliance of tempera pigment which set off the drawing of the painted panel found its counterpart in the delicately tinted grounds used often in metalpoint drawings. Metalpoints produce strokes which are relatively light and can never produce a black line. The line, which is rather inflexible for contrasting variations in density, does produce an impression of linear purity by the inherent constancy, preciseness, and lightness of the strokes. A modern example of silverpoint is the W. Bailc)' Nude, no, 115, The Piero Pollaiuolo Half Length Torso of a Male Nude, no, 9, from the Scholz Collection illustrates how metalpoint was used often in com¬ bination with pen and wash. Pen drawings in line or wash or, as most often in combination, were done with quill, reed, or metalpoints in a variety of inks. All were used by masters of the past as they are today and with the four basic types of ink: black carbon, iron- gall, bistre, and sepia. Other colors for pen and wash work were used infre¬ quently. These "watercolors" were prepared in the same manner as the water- colors used in fresco painting (see: Anon. Tuscan, no. 3). Black carbon inks (incorporation of a black carbon pigment into an acjueous binding medium) are not usually subject to color change (see: German Master, A Fool, no. 1). Iron-gall inks (clarified extract of galls crushed and boiled or University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 18
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: Bandinelli, no. 12 University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 19
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: soaked in water or wine to which ferrous sulphate and gum arable are added) are not so black as carbonated inks neither when first prepared nor after long exposure to air which will turn the strokes brown. Bistre ink (extract of soluble tars from wood soot) is chromatically strong but very transparent brown (see the Titian, Two Satyrs in a Landscape, no. 34). The glowing and radiant transparency of its color is its best quality. Its value range is limited since even the darkest concentration can never achieve black; however, it can create light, dark, and coloristic contrasts of warm and resonant pictorial impressions. Sepia ink (orig¬ inally the ink sac excretions of scjuid and cuttlefish) was especially used for washes, most prominently in the nineteenth century. It has never been a major ink for the draughtsman. In the preparation of washes, it was often mixed with a variety of pigments so that its basic brown color could range from values of yellowish and reddish browns to brownish blacks (see: Boucher, Inspiration, no. 66, from the Slatkin Collection). The quill pen (goose, swan, raven, or crow) was the most frequently used by all masters in the past, not only because of its accessibility but also because of its versatility. The cjuill could be pared to adapt to the needs of the artist and to respond with great facility to each artist's linear eccentricities. Great maneuverability and flexibility add to its other qualities to make it one of the most expressive instruments for the drawing media. It is a veritable extension of the artist's hand. It produces a generally softer, less constant and much less mechanical stroke than modern steel pens. Reed pens are the most ancient of writing instruments but were used rarely (even today) because they were less adaptable to delicate and graceful calligraphic draughtsmanship. The reed pro¬ duces a blunter and less lively stroke than the quill; nevertheless, it can suggest a coarse and vigorous power. It produces effects which fall between the precise linearism of cjuill and steel pens and the broad sweeps of brush strokes. The steel pen is the most commonly used today for the usual commercial reasons, as well as for the sharpness of its lines so necessary for printing reproductions. Steel pens and the contemporary papers developed to be used in conjunction with them can produce an indelible image almost like a copper engraving. Chiaroscuro drawings are distinguished from pen drawings by the quality of execution, and deserve a separate category as a medium. Chiaroscuro suggests the creation of figures by light values over a dark halftone or the suggestion of partially emerging forms from a deeply shadowed background into atmospheric light. Chiaroscuro drawings are the reverse of the usual drawing method of dark strokes on light paper, creating similar relationships of dark tonal back¬ grounds and figures mostly defined by white or prominent highlights. Chiaro¬ scuro drawings can be done with fine linear pen or brush work. The Tintoretto, Domenichino, and Jordaens drawings, nos. 33, 44, 50, are examples of this tech¬ nique. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 20
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: The broad drawing media include the use of chalks, pastels, crayons, charcoal, and graphite. The old natural chalks made from a few colored earths began to be most commonly used in the late fifteenth century, when broader atmospheric and chiaroscuro effects were desired. Red chalk or matita rossa or sanguine offers broad, soft effects which, being less friable, make it suitable for drawings of modest scale, limited modeling, and warmth of tone (see the S. Rosa, Head Study, no. 57, the Pontormo, no. 28, and Guercino, no. 47, in this exhibition). Natrrral black chalk can produce tighter lines than red chalk, quite distinct from charcoal strokes (see: Louis de Boullogne, no. 37). Natural white chalks (soapstone and Calcite varieties) were always used to heighten modeling. All three chalks were frequently used together (see: Bernini, Self-Portrait, no. 36). Pastels are fabri¬ cated chalks (pastes of dry pigment and a binding media). The use of pastels may be traced back into the sixteenth century. They differ most immediately from natural chalks in the infinite number of variations in hue, value, texture, and hardness in which they can be found (see: Gross, no. 138). Soft fabricated pastels which permit broad modeling and wide strokes are admirably suited for large-scale drawings. Hard fabricated chalks are like the natural chalks and are most adaptable to drawings of a modest scale with fine lines. Crayons are more correctly the color sticks made either with oily, waxy, or greasy binding media, or with combinations of water-soluble and fatty binders. Although the making of crayons was known by Leonardo, there are few crayon drawings before the nineteenth century. Most adaptable to linear works, their fatty characteristics provide a richer bodied stroke and a deeper chromatic intensity than do their counterparts, the hard fabricated chalks (see: Lachaise, Figure, no. 145). The sanguine Conte crayon which is used in the Dix, Reclining Nude, no. 131, is a nineteenth century fabricated drawing stick which is similar to natural red chalk. It is only slightly fatty and therefore is less friable than a soft natural chalk. It tends to spottiness when smudged. Its modest tinting strength, its covering power, and its friability have made charcoal the preparatory medium par excellence for paintings and for metal¬ point and pen and ink drawings (see: Couture, A Lawyer, no. 88). Both Cennini and Vasari recommended the use of charcoal for the large-scale preparatory cartoons for fresco. Their advice was still followed by Matisse in designing dec¬ orations for the church at Vence. With the decline of the use of natural chalks, ultimately abandoned in the nineteenth century, charcoal became the major medium for figure studies. It was and still is the traditional tool for life drawing exercises in the academies. Graphite was not extensively used until the seven¬ teenth century and since then has become the principal successor of metalpoints, which it most resembles in effect. Its advantage over metalpoint is the wider range in textural effects and tonal values that can be achieved, depending on the hardness or softness of the graphite stick. The seventeenth century was the University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 21
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: Raphael, no. 29 L. de Boullogne, no. 37 University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 22
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: first to use it for finished drawings rather than as only a preliminary medium for ink, wash, or chalk drawings (see: Dolci, no. 43). It was also used in combination with the other media, particularly for achieving the gray strokes of distant hori¬ zons. The improved methods of producing fine quality graphite pencils as well as the increasing difficulty in finding good sources of the natural red and black chalks were to place the graphite medium in a prominent position in the nine¬ teenth century. Ingres and Delacroix (no. 96) often used graphite, and Degas (nos. 91,93,94,95) particularly exploited graphite for its complete range of tonal values. This exhibition is concerned with the essential means through which art and the artist give form to life, a visual knowledge of the nature of man. The goal of this humanistic passion, and passion it is in the fervor of its unquenchable egocentricity, was, in the vocabulary of the Renaissance, the revelation, identity, and union with God, but, in the terminology of modern man's persistent self- withdrawal, it is the revelation and discernment of the personal and corporate psyches. The contemporary artist as well as contemporary man finds himself be¬ tween the two poles illustrated by the Quattrocento Tuscan S^ Francis receiving the Stigmata, no. 3, and the recent Claes Oldenburg Sketch for a huge stuffed shirt with tie, and a woman standing for scale, no. 153. To what God shall we pray and in what form shall we manifest him? The artist's concern with the human figure since the Renaissance has been an inspiring dedication.to and faith in an ideal of God-Man. The perceptive creative doer and thinker has the instinct for revealing succinctly what our Gods and demons are. He is the conscience of us all. Dante considered the artist-creator as partaking in the divine functions of God. Drawings, the visual records of the creative processes, reveal a richer por¬ trait of the artist and his secret gods than do paintings or sculpture. They expose the genesis of new ideas searching for formal expression as well as the possible technical or subjective flaws that experience and educated taste remove from the created object for public consumption. Gauguin intensely expressed this: A critic at my house sees some paintings. Greatly perturbed, he asks for my drawings. My drawings, never! They are my letters, my secrets. The public man—the private man. (Journals.) Wallace J. Tomasini IOWA CITY, 1964 University of Iowa Libraries

ANONYMOUS, GERMAN MONOGRAMMIST "2. Pentecost, dated late fifteenth century Pen and ink; 9^/' x 7%" Collection of The E. B. Crocker Gallery of Art, Sacramento. ANONYMOUS, TUSCAN '3. St. Francis receiving the Stigmata, dated c. 1400 Pen, brown ink, gray, red, and white colors on vellum, IIM" x SM" Collection of Janos Scholz, New York City. Drawn on the Verso of a Tuscan document dating from about 1350 prob¬ ably by a monk. The words Mnti Liuetij and twice the dates 1416 and 1417 point toward Monte Oliveto Maggiore, which also would fit perfectly stylistically. The work must be that of a monk of modest artistic talent who drew this, much under the influence of the Giottesque Stigmatiza- tions. CARPACCIO, VITTORE (Venetian, c. 1445-1525/26) "4. Seven figures connected with the Legend of St. Ursula Pen and wash, brown ink, heightened white on olive-brown, tinted paper; 4%" X llli" approx. Collection of Janos Scholz, New York City. Formerly collections of Rob¬ inson (Lugt 1433); Gruner; Wadsworth. Lit.: Zigrosser 1950; Schoolman-Slatkin 1953; Gilbert 1958. The same figures can be found in the paintings of the Ursula legend in the Academy, Venice. The similarities but also the differences would sug¬ gest that the drawing is a so-called "simile" drawing by the artist, to be used later either by himself or his assistants. Lower half of male nude Pen, light brown ink, irregularly restored; 6M" x 2/2." approx. Collection of Janos Scholz, New York City. Formerly collections of Planiscig; de Sanctis (Cat. no. 204). Seemingly by the same hand which drew the figure in the Bonnat collec¬ tion, Bayonne (Bean 1960, no. 120), there still not considered an original by Antonio, but rather by one of the followers. POLLAIUOLO, PIERO (Tuscan, 1443-before 1496) "9. Half length torso of a male nude Pen, dark brown ink over faint lines of metal point on white paper; Tii" X 5%" approx. Collection of Janos Scholz, New York City. Formerly collections of Plan¬ iscig, de Sanctis. This and the following drawings came from a small album once in the possession of Planiscig who found it in Florence many years ago. The book was broken up and its contents sold at the de Sanctis sale in Geneva, 1947 (Cat. nos. 202-208), there attributed to Antonio Pollaiuolo. Even at a rapid glance it is evident that the drawings in this lot are not of equal quality and by different hands, hands which can also be found in the large pool of sheets by Antonio and his school in the Uffizi and elsewhere. What seems to be even more significant is the fact that this torso comes extremely close to the St. Sebastian in the National Gallery, London, a painting which has been given by various critics to either one or the other of the brothers. TINTORETTO (Jacopo Robusti, Venetian, 1518-94) *33. Samson slaying the Philistine Black chalk heightened with white, on blue-green paper; 13/i" x 8M" Collection of Gerald Bronfman, Montreal. One of a series of studies by Tintoretto after Michelangelo's sculpture group, Samson and the Philistine, intended as a companion to the David but executed only in a modello (described by Vasari) and known chiefly through various small bronze reproductions of this work. Of the drawings which Tintoretto made, studying this composition from various angles, two are in the Fogg Museum, five in the Uffizi, two in the Ashmolean Museum, and two others at Christ Church, Oxford, while still other sheets are in Berhn, Bayonne, Besan§on, and several private collections. record.title: Drawing and the human figure, 1400-1964, the Twenty-Sixth Annual Fine Arts Festival, 1964
record.description: "The Twenty-Sixth Annual Festival of Fine Arts at the State University of Iowa presents as one of its major features the exhibition of drawings ... Wallace J. Tomasini, Curator of the Exhibition"--pages 3, 5.

record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: 355 n : Contemporary A merican Painting IOWA MEMORIAL UNION G rafts and Ceramics EXHIBITION LOUNGE-ART BUILDING 17 th ANNUAL FINE ARTS FESTIVAL STATE UNIVERSITY OF IOWA June 14 to August 10,1955 it University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Inside front cover
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: ART Foreword The School of Fine Arts of the State University of Iowa, in connection with its Seventeenth Annual Fine Arts Festival, presents the exhibition of Con¬ temporary paintings catalogued herewith. The exhibition may be viewed in the Main Lounge and East Lobby of the Iowa Memorial Union. This collection of significant works by noted contemporary artists has been brought together by Edith Halpert, Director of the Downtown Gallery in New York City. The State University of Iowa is very grateful to Mrs. Halpert for her generous and expert assistance in this matter. In addition the University is grateful to the following for their assistance and par¬ ticularly for their generous loans of paintings for the exhibition: Durlacher Gallery Van Dieman-LiHnfeld Galleries William H. Land Foundation Miss Brenda Kuhn, Courtesy Maynard Walker Gallery The Kuhn Estate, Courtesy Maynard Walker Gallery M. Knoedler and Company Willard Gallery Paintings numbered 1, 2, 33, and 34 have been loaned to the University by the artists. In addition to the exhibition of paintings in the Main Lounge and East Lobby of the Iowa Memorial Union approximately one hundred examples of work in Crafts and Ceramics have been selected for exhibition in the Exhibition Lounge of the Art Building of the State University of Iowa. The selection, collection, arrangement, and cataloguing of these items represent generous and competent service on the part of Professors Raoul Delmare and Glenn Nelson of the Art Department faculty. The University thanks Professors Delmare and Nelson and all who have kindly assisted them with loans of art objects. A separate mimeographed catalogue of the exhibition of crafts and ceramics has been issued in conjunction with this catalogue. Many of the paintings and works of crafts and ceramics are for sale. Prices will be published or furnished on request. Earl E. Harper, Director, School of Fine Arts and Iowa Memorial Union State University of Iowa University of Iowa Libraries
