record.full-text: NIGERIAN ARTS 21st Annual Fine Arts Festival School of Fine Arts State University of iov^^a 1959 Art Building June 15 to August 12 University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Inside front cover
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: AN EXHIBITION OF THE ARTS OF NIGERIA Professor Roy Sieber has long specialized in African Art. For the 18th An¬ nual Festival of Fine Arts, 1956, at the State University of Iowa, he assem¬ bled and presented an exhibition of African Art v^hich was regarded as one of the leading university exhibitions of its kind. Professor Sieber has just returned from a program of research in the art history of sub-Saharan Africa which was supported by a Ford Founda¬ tion Foreign Area Training Fellowship. At the personal request of the writer he has prepared for the 21st Fine Arts Festival an exhibition of objects and photographs selected from the study collection he assembled in Nigeria only last year. Professor Sieber states that a special note of gratitude is due the Nigerian Antiquities Commission and the Department of Antiquities for the coopera¬ tion, advice and assistance without which his program of research and the assembling of this study collection could not have been profitably concluded. Earl E. Harper Director, School of Fine Arts The tribes of Nigeria have produced a wealth of traditional art forms. Many of these tribal styles are well represented in museums and collections outside Nigeria; others are almost totally unknown. This exhibition focuses attention on one well-known style, that of the Yoruba of Western Nigeria, and on the arts of two little known areas near the Benue River in Northern Nigeria. The Yoruba are perhaps the most prolific carvers in Africa. A complex culture has given rise to a truly fantastic number of figure carvings, masks and cult objects. As a result a number of important sub-styles can be dis¬ cerned; carving centers and individual carvers have produced variations on a basic Yoruba style. Little is known of the history of Northern Nigeria, of the migrations and counter-migrations, the cross-currents of conquest, that ended only with the holy wars of the Mohammedan Fulani in the last century. To the southeast of the confluence of the Niger and Benue Rivers there exist related styles of carving among the eastern Igala and the Idoma tribes. A single style may have existed in this area. Sustained by the Idoma it has become vestigial among the Igala whose culture was more heavily affected by outside influences. Despite the shattering impact of the Fulani 'horse wars' many of the tribes north of the Benue give evidence of lively traditions in the arts. These reveal an affinity with Sudanic styles rather than with those of southern Nigerian groups. The arts here exhibited by no means represent the full scope of Nigerian traditional art forms, but they may be taken as instances of the richness and complexity of African sculptural traditions and of the need for con¬ tinued research. Roy Sieber COVER: IDOMA CREST MASK University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 01
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: YORUBA There exists a strong sense of cultural tinlty among the Yoruba who nuunber over three million, "All Yoruba regard the town of Ife as their place of origin and the Oni of Ife has been generally accepted as their ritual leader. The present royal lineages of the various Yoruba chiefdoms trace their descent from Oduduwa, or Odua, the deified culture hero whom Ife mytho¬ logy credits with the creation of the earth, and from whose seven grand¬ sons the various branches of the Yoruba-speaking peoples claim descent," (Forde, pM) The Yoruba have an elaborate pantheon consisting of a creator god and over UOO lesser spirits known as Orisha, The Orisha are con¬ sidered to be the remote ancestors of those wiio have inherited their coimnitoent. However an individual may be 'called' by an Orisha so that several may be worshipped simultaneously. The cults of the Orisha gave rise to a great variety of ritual objects: carvings in wood and ivory, wrought iron staffs and elaborate beadwork, 1~$ Cult Objects 1, Eshu priest's sta.ff representing a kneeling figure playing a flute. The horn-like cap and strings of cowries are characteristic. Eshu or Elegbara, often called the orisha of mischance, a trickster res¬ ponsible for bad luck and quarrels, is perhaps best described as the uncertainty principle of the Yortiba pantheon. Collected in Oyo. H.19i" 2, Paddle - or fan-like object with handle in the form of a kneeling woman. Evidently from a shrine but of unknown use although it may be associated with Oya, a river goddess. Collected in Oyo. H. 9''3A" 3« Wrought iron staff surmounted by a circlet of birds. Staffs of this type are usually associated with Osanyin, the healing Orisha, although similar examples are found in shrines of Orisha Erinle, the hunter. Collected in Oyo. H. 29' il. Three cro;-m shaped objects of cloth and cowrie shells. "The Ori (Head) is the tmiversal household diety worshipped by both sexes as the god of fate. It is believed that good or ill fortune attends one, accor¬ ding to the will or decree,of this god; and hence it is propitiated in order that good luck might be the share of its votaiy. The repre¬ senting image is li.l cowries stinmg together in the shape of a crown. This is secreted in a large coffer, the end of which is of the same form and material. It is called 'lie Ori' (Ori's house) and in size is as large as the owner can afford to make it," (Johnson, p.2?) Collected in Oyo. 5i", 6" and ll;" 5. Drum from the Oltaiio Rock Shrine at Abeokuta, This shrine is not dedicated to an Orisha, but is the national shrine of the Egba Yoruba. Four fields of carving decorate the drtim: two are filled with an inter¬ lace design; one represents a sacred mudfish and the fourth exhibits a standing figure supporting two staffs. The latter seems to be a misunderstood version of an Abraxus-like figure whose legs terminate in mudfish tails held in either hand. Such figures appear in Yoruba carvings and in some Benin bronzes. Carved befoxre I896. The drumhead has been missing for some time, H. II4"

record.title: Page 02
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: 6-12 Ibeji. Twin figuares (IbcJi) are perhaps the most nuinerous of all types of Yoruba carvings. There is sowc confusion whether Ibeji is to be con¬ sidered an Orisha, In any case, twins are welcomed by the Yoruba (unlike many groups that fear and abhor them) for they are thought to bring luck and wealth to the family. If one or both the twins should die Ibeji are canned. The figure of a dead twin is cared for by the survivor, or, if both die, by the mother. Ibeji are fed, washed and clothed. The figures are nearly always nude and standing with arras at their sides. Tribal scari¬ fication marks are indicated and beads are often attached to them, the color indicating the orisha to whom the twin, when living, was dedicated. 6,7 Ibeji pair llected in Abeokuta, Stylistically these would seem to come from the compound of the carver Akinyode and are possibly by that master. 9" 8 Ibeji collected in Oyo. This figure is a typical example of Oyo style and is possibly by one of the Igbuke family of carvers, 12" 9) 10, 11, 12, 13 Five Ibeji collected in Oyo, 9 and 10 would seem to be variations on Oyo stylej 11 and 12 are possibly from the area north¬ west of Oyo and 13 may be decadent Ibadan style, 10", 11", 10", 9i" 9i" lU Ibeji collected in Ogbomoso but not in the style of that village. Possibly from near Shaki, 11" 1$ Ibeji carved by Abogunde about 1938, On the basis of this figure and nos, 16, 17 and 18 it is now possible to assign figures in this style to Ogbomoso, where these four pieces were collected, 11" 16 Ibeji said to be cairved by Abogunde but possibly by an apprentice about 1938, Collected in Ogbomoso. 10^" 17, 18 Ibeji pair carved about 20 years ago. Carver not remembered. Collected in Ogbomoso. 10" 19j 20 Ibeji pair collected in Oyo but carved in the style of Ogbomoso, 91" 21 Ibeji collected in Oyo but carved in the style of Ogbomoso. It would seem that 17 through 21 were carved by the same hand. 10;|-" 22-2k Egtmgun masks. Egungun is usually called a society but because of its religious elements, primarily ancestral, it might be better to refer to it as a cult. Four or five different types of Egungun exist and perhaps three of these have masks. They appear at a yearly Egungun festival and at funerals. Some impersonate relatives who have recently died, others apparently are intended only for entertainment. Not all are carved for some masks are of cloth or leather. Two types of carved masks exist; true face masks and crests that sit atop the head. The latter may represent human or animal heads, groups of figures or heads or simply a hairdress carved in wood, 22 Egiingun crest in the form of an elaborate hairdress. Called Egungun Egbe, This crest is reputed to be I4O or 50 years old. The name of the University of Iowa Libraries

record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: - 3 - YORUBA - IGALA carver was not remembered. Collected at Ogbomoso where five other instances of this type were seen, H, 12" 23 Egungun crest surmotinted by four heads. Collected in Oyo and in the style of that city, H. 8|-" 2k Egungun face mask collected in Oyo, William Fagg suggests that this mask is probably from the Falade compound of carvers at Iscyin. H, 8" 2$ Woman's adire cloth. Uncolored, imported cotton cloth is tic-dyed with native indigo in a wide variety of patterns. Collected in Ibadan, but probably made in Abeol^uta, the center of the women's guild of adire dyers. 62"x70" 26 Woman's cloth. Native cotton, dyed with indigo and woven by women on a vertical loom. Collected at Ubanloma. ]42"x72" 27 Photograph of second burial figure representing the mother of the Olowo (chief) of Owo. Another figure was used in place of this one which is stored in the Afin (palace) at Owo, Carved by Ogunleye Ologan. Life size. 28, Photograph of a detail of a door jamb or lintel carved by the great grandfather of the present Ologan (sec 27), It is no longer in use, but is stored in the Afin at Owo, H, of horseman about 2U" 29 Photograph of a detail of a guardian figure from the Afin at Owo, 30 Photograph of a pair of ram's heads (osamasinmwi) used in ancestor worship related to the harvest of yams. From the Afin at Owo, 31, 32, 33 Photographs of stone images at Esie, Possibly of Yoruba or Nupe origin they arc now protected in a small museum, 3ii, 35 Photographs of housepost in the Afin at Efon-Alaiye. Carved about 1900 by Agbonbiofe, IGAU The Igala, numbering nearly 300,000, live to the south and cast of the confluence of the Niger and Benue Rivers, It has been suggested that the Igala, Idona and Yoruba share a common origin, but were separated long ago. By tradition the Igala aristocracy are descended from the Jukun empire. How¬ ever little remains in the way of custom, art or language to sxibstantiate this belief, A western, or Idah group, and an eastern, or Ankpa group are to be distinguished on the basis of language. This distinction seems to be echoed in the styles of carvings. The photographs and carvings from the eastern Igala here exhibited differ in style from those foiind at Idah (the capitol) and are related more to Idoma and northern Ibo styles, 36 Photograph of an Egu Orumamu. (Egu - ancestor; oruraamu - chief of masks), This mask served as the symbol of authority of the elders, pronouncing judgment in cases of debt, assault and murder. Carved by Egbodu about I9UI, Collected from Chief Akpa of Ikege village, now in Jos Museum, H,23" 37 Photograph of a Janus-faced Egu Orumamu, Carved by Ada about 19li3, Okpo village, 38 Photograph of Egu Anyakatoro, Second in importance to Orumamu this is considered a dangerous (i,c, a fighting) mask. Carved by Ema of Agala village, now in Jos Museum, H, about Ik", University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 04
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: IGALA - IDCTtA 39 Inyama, a family guardian figure, said to bring good luck and riches and to serve as a protector of children. This example was used as a stopper for a calabash filled with potent 'medicine'. The upraised anas may represent a Moslem praying gesture. Carved by Adoyi in 1955» Collected in Biradu village, H, of caived portion 6", UO Photograph of a family guardian figure, A carved leopard destroyed by termites formerly accoBrpanicd this figure. Carved by Ifcne Ubojoja about I9U9. Collected in Abachi village, now in Jos Musetjm. H, about 12" kl Carved calabash stopper, called Aligenu, used for illness and fertility. Apparently identical to the Anjenu of the Idoma, This example illustrates a proverb: Leopard tried to catch hornbill, but hornbill flew off with leopard. Carved in 1958 by Ekujc of Ojugo village. Collected in Etch, L, 17" k2 Photograph of an oath image in Ajeje market. Anyone accused of theft may declare his innocence on this image and drink some water in which figure has been placed. If guilty he will act like a madman and must repay the theft and ask the spirit to remove his suffering, H, about 30" k3 Figure carved on commission by Etodu of Etctekpe village. Basically in traditional eastern Igala style, the parrot on the shoulder (because some men like to carry them thus) and the woodpecker on the head (because carving is of wood) are decorative additions, H, 23|-" kk Door carved by UJa about 19J-tl, Formerly carved doors were placed at the main entrance to the compound and served to indicate the importance of the owner. They have been almost totally replaced iy^ carpentry doors. Collected in Abachi village, ii9"x 31" k^ Man's stool, Cajrvcd by Ameh Oguche about 1920, Collected in Abachi village. L. I8" U6 Woman's stool. Made in Idah, this represents the western Igala type. Collected in Etch from a widow of a former Ata (paramount chief) of Igala. Carved in 1957. H. 11" kl Small woman's stool of eastern Igala type. Collected near Okpo. H. 5" U8 Anklets of brass bells cast by lost wax process. Worn by women of noble families. Collected at Etch. IDOMA Numbering about 250,000 the Idoma arc the eastern neighbors of the Igala. At least a portion of the Idoma were once lindcr the influence of the Jukun, Further, the Igala have to some extent assimilated or displaced Idomaf-speaking groups who lived in what is now eastern Igala land. The stylistic similarity of eastern Igala carvings to those of the Idoma suggests that the style is Idoma in origin, k9 Photograph of an Ogrinyc mask crest. The Idoma have a large number of secret and semi-secret dance guilds. Membership in the most powerful of these, the Ogrinyc society, was limited to men who had killed an elephant, a lion, or a man. The mask would appear at harvest time and University of Iowa Libraries

record.full-text: -1,. IDOMA at ftjnerals of members of the society. Carved by Ochai of Otobi village. Said to be very old. 50 Photograph of Utroku (chief of masks) mask, also known as Akatakpu- lakpula, a society of ciders who were responsible for the punishment of certain evildoers. The mask represents an elephant. It appears at harvest time and at ftjnerals. Carved by Ochai of Otobi village, L, about 6' 5l, 52 Pair of masks representing a husband and wife. Used primarily for entertainment, the dance is called Aringa: to know evil and to know good. Carved by Oba, Collected in Otobi village, 51 Husband, Carved in 195U, H, 9i" 52 Wife. Carved in 1957. H. 8-3A" 53 Agahama mask. Agaharaa (scratching grass) is unpleasant; so arc funerals at which this mask appears. Carved by Oba in 1958, Collected in Otobi village, H, 9" 51i Odugba dance mask. Carved by Oklcnyi in 1958, Collected in Akungaga village, H. 9" $S Eku (crocodile) dance mask. Representing a crocodile and a bush cow, this mask appears at beginning and end of growing season and at funerals along with 56, Carved by Oba of Otobi village in 1955. Collected in Upu village. L. 27" 56 Idire (snake) dance mask. Appears with S^, Carved by Oba of Otobi village. Collected in Upu village, L, 19" 57, 58 Ekutakpa crests. These guard farms at the time of the millet harvest to keep the women from stealing grain. Collected in Otobi village. 57 Carved by Ogwebe about I9UI, H. lU" 58 Carved by Ochai in 19ii6. H. l5" 59 Anjenu figure, Anjenu is a spirit that lives in the water or bush and who appears in dreams. The figiircs can be used to insure good luck, human fertility or in the cure of illness. Carved ty Oba about 19m* Collected in Otobi village, H, 15-3A" 60 Anjenu figure. Carved by Oba in 1958. Collected in Otobi village, H, 12" 61 Anjenu figure. Carved by Adeka in 1953. Collected in Oturkpo-icho village, H, 114- 62 Anjenu stopper for a calabash. It represents a hornbill. Carved by Akpaturaa in 1955. Collected in Upu. H. 11^" 63 Anjenu. Bowl with lid decorated with carved hvunan head flanked by two hombills. Commissioned from Oklenyi of Aktingaga village, H« l5" 6k Figxirc representing a lady school teacher preaching in chiirch. Apparent¬ ly a commemorative or ancestral figure. Carved by Oklenyi in 1958. Collected in Akungaga village. H. 17" 65, 66 Two figures carved in Otobi village in 1952. These figures show the effects of neglect, for termites have badly damaged one and all but destroyed the other. The use to which figures arc put is determined by the purchaser; they may be used for Anjenu, ancestor worship or as toys. These were used as toys, H, 13^" and 11^" 67 Toy leopard carved for his children by Akpatuma in 1955. Collected in Upu, L. 18" University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 06
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: - 6 - JABA - GOEMAI JABA The Jaba or Ham, a tribe of about 26,000, live north of the Benue River, Much of the ritual equipment they use is carved by members of a neighboring tribe, the Koro, 68 Dance crest called Nyamfaik (guardian of Faik village), Appears twice a year with other masks. Carved by Diga (a Koro) about 19U3. H, 17" 69 Dance crest called Ngamdak (man with bowed legs). Appears with pre¬ ceding mask. Carved by Diga (a Koro) about 1939. From Kanye village. H. 17" 70 Painted fiber costume for preceding mask. Made by Diga in 1955. 71 Ritual drinking cup used for ritual palm wine drinking. Such Gbcnc are used once a year during a ceremonial sacrifice and at second burials. Carved by Kwasau (a Koro) in 1958. H. 2U" 72 Decorated calabash used for a vegetable oil used as a cosmetic by women. Collected in Nok village, H, 7" 73 Disk-shaped lumbar dress ornament (oyaw) formerly worn by married women, D, 9" GOEMAI The Qocraai (Hausa; Ankwc), a tribe of approximately 20,000 live to the south and west of Shcndam, Although long tmder the influence of the Jukun Empire, Goemai arts do not seem Jukun in origin but arc closely associated with those of the Montol and other nearby tribes, 7k Carved figure, called Takindi, used to divine the cause of illness, A secret society, Kwompten, is dedicated to seeking the cause (by Spirits or witchcraft) of illness by divination and its cure by herba¬ lism. After a successful cure the patient must furnish a goat and millet for sacrifice and for a celebration by the society. Carved by Lahore of Yelwa village about I9U8. H. I8" 75 Photograph of the diviner, Luani, of Yelwa village. The figure to the left of the pair at his feet is the one described above. 76 Five photographs of a Mongop dancer. This, the chief mask of the area, normally comes out once a year during the dry season. It also officiates at the ftincrals and cnthoroneraents of chiefs. Carved by Langkwap more than 70 years ago. Bakinchiawa village. 77 Pottery head, fragment of a full figure. In some instances these figures could be used ritually, though for the most part they arc to be considered decorative. Several figures in this style are in the Jos Museum, others in the British Museum. Long Goemai, paramount chief of the Goemai, said that they were all made by one womaai, AzuraS who died about 1951. Gift of the Long Goemai, ShenrJara. H. 2-3/U" 78 Photograph of a pot for storing honey. Made by Azome before 1951. This pot was made with particular care for it was the property of the daughter of a chief. Collected at Kwande village, now in Jos Museum. University of Iowa Libraries

record.full-text: - 7 - GOMEI - MOWTOL 79, 80, 81 Three women's stools, 79 was reported to have been carved about 50 years ago; 80 about 10, and 8I about 12. 8I is in style of Wtjtpe stools and may have been imported. All were collected in Kwande village. H. 8", 11", 10" 82 Decorated calabash. Collected in Kwande village. H. 12" 83 Photograph of an old type incised decoration on a ruined hut in the coinpouad of the Chief of Kwande village. Ornamentation of this sort was done by women, 8U Figure used by a Goemai but carved by a Kanera (reported to be a very small nearby tribe). Used to treat snakebite, it is called Dakzwora (dak - doctor or medicine: zwom - spotted poisonous snake). Collected in Darlit village. H. llj" MONTOL The Montol who live to the northeast of the Goemai are a small tribe of about 10,000. Never under the Influence of the Jultun, the style of their carvings is similar to that .found rather widely in the pagan groups north of the Benue, 85 Qugwora mask* Associated with agriculttjire this mask appears at the times of planting and harvest and also appears at the burials of chiefs. Carved by Danpeh about 19U8, Collected in Lalin village, L, 30" 86 Gugwora mask. Carved by Namni about 1928. Although carved by a Montol this mask was owned by the village head of the Goemai village of Longvel. L, 26" 87, 88 Photographs of Montol dancers one of whom is wearing a Gugwom mask. The others wear Kura masks made of netted fiber which appear at the beginning and end of the growing season. Tunkus and Lalin villages. 89 Diviner's figure for Koratin (apparently identical to Goemai Kwompten). Carved about 1952, Carver's name not remembered. Collected in Lalin village, H, 12" 90 Figure for personal use, although said to be associated with Komtin, Carved by Furatay about 1953. Collected in Lalin viLlage, H, 9" 91 Figure probably for Komtin, Carver not remembered. Piece originally obtained in Baltip village about 1950, Collected in Lalin village, H,l5" JARAWAN DUT2E A small tribe which lives near Jos on the Plateau, 92 Decorated woman's headboard used for carrying loads. Collected in Fobur village, L, 20;^" In addition musical instruments, calabashes, cloths and Jeweliy from Northern Nigeria are exhibited. University of Iowa Libraries

record.full-text: State University of Iowa Publication Twenty-First Annual Fine Arts Festival STATE UNIVERSITY OF IOWA, IOWA CITY June 15 to August 12, 1959 University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Inside front cover
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: The Twenty-First Annual Fine Arts Festival at the State University o£ Iowa will con¬ tinue from the opening day of the Summer Session, June 15, to Commencement Day, August 12,1959. The beautiful Iowa Campus, rising to the hills from either side of the river which winds its way past the Theatre, the Art Building, and the Iowa Memorial Union, where most of the Festival events take place, provides a setting of rare beauty for the Festival. Each year this Festival presents symphonic, chamber, choral and band music; opera; concerts by students of the All-State Music Camp; plays in the Theatre; lectures and programs by distinguished speakers and entertainers; and exhibitions of art in many media. With the exception of the opera and the plays in the Theatre, all events are free to the public. Any inquiries concerning the Festival should be addressed to Earl E. Harper, Direc¬ tor of the School of Fine Arts and the Iowa Memorial Union, State University of Iowa, Iowa City, Iowa. ART EXHIBITIONS Two art exhibitions have been provided for the Twenty-First Annual Festival. The first is an exhibition of paintings and drawings by members of the faculty of the De¬ partment of Art of the University, featuring works by three distinguished visiting artists, Ben-Zion, Keith Vaughan, and Mitchell Fields. These will be hung on the walls of the Main Lounge, the Terrace Lounge, and the East Lobby of the Iowa Me¬ morial Union. The second exhibit will be a presentation in the Exhibition Lounge of the Art Build¬ ing of works of art and artifacts recently brought from Africa by Dr. Roy Sieber of the faculty of the Department of Art. SUMMER SESSION LECTURE SERIES Chairman, Dr. Orville A. Hitchcock Tuesday, July 80, Macbride Auditorium, 8:00 p.m. Vance Packard, author of The Hidden Persuaders and The Status Seekers Subject: "Our Morality and Our Hidden Persuaders" Tuesday, July 14, Main Lounge, Iowa Memorial Union, 8:00 p.m. Benjamin Fine, former Education Editor, New York Times, author of Our Children Are Cheated, etc. Subject: "Education for the Space Age" Tuesday, August 4, Macbride Auditorium, 8:00 p.m. Morris Hindus, author of many books on Russia and just back from another extensive visit behind the Iron Curtain Subject: "America and Russia"

record.title: Inside rear cover
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: DRAMA The University Theatre July 9,10, and 11 The Trial of Captain John Brown, an original play by Richard F. Stockton July 15 and 16 Midsummer Night's Dream Produced as a part of the program of the Workshops for High School Teachers and Students in Speech and Dramatic Art July 28,29, 31, and August 1 The Fine Arts Festival Opera August 6,7, and 8 Tiger at the Gates, by Jean Giraudoux, translated by Christopher Fry STUDIO THEATRE PROGRAM Two plays are being considered for possible production at the Studio Theatre. One of these two plays will be a new script, but the titles and the production dates are still under consideration. f OPERA Tuesday and Wednesday, Friday and Saturday, July 28, 29, 31, and August 1, Macbride Auditorium, 8:00 p.m. A dual bill of operas will be presented as a feature of the 21st Fine Arts Festival. Rita, an opera by Donizetti, will be the first offering. Western Child, libretto by Dr. Paul Engle and music by Dr. Philip Bezanson will follow. This will be the premier production of the opera, which presents the familiar nativity story in a Western, American, mountain and mining environment. Those who have read the score and heard the music are very enthusiastic about the merits of this work by two distinguished members of the faculty of the State University of Iowa. The cast will be comprised of undergraduate and graduate students of the Depart¬ ments of Music and Dramatic Art. Stage crews will be provided by the Department of Dramatic Art. Professor Herald I. Stark of the Department of Music and Professor Harrold Shiffler of the Department of Speech and Dramatic Art will collaborate as musical and dramatic directors, respectively, as they have with notable success for the past several years. Professor Stark will conduct. Professor Arnold S. Gillette, Director of the University Theatre, w^ill design the scenes. Professor Margaret S. Hall wiU supervise the costumes and David Thayer the lighting. Marcia Claire Thayer will be the choreographer. Mr. WiUiam L. Adamson of the staff of the Iowa Memorial Union will serve as Busi¬ ness Manager. Both operas wiU be sung in English.

record.title: Rear cover
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: MUSIC Sunday, June 28 "Pops" Concert by the All-State Music Camp Orchestra, Chorus, and Band, Main Lounge, Iowa Memorial Union, 4:00 p.m. Friday, July S Final Concert: Orchestra, Chorus, and Band, All-State Music Camp—Main Lounge, Iowa Memorial Union, 8:00 p.m. Wednesday, July 8 Summer Session Symphony Orchestra, James Dixon, Conductor, Main Lounge, Iowa Memorial Union, 8:00 p.m. July 28,29, 31, and August 1 Operatic dual bill, Rita, Donizetti, and Western Child, Bezanson and Engle UNIVERSITY MUSEUM The Museum, located in Macbride Hall, is open week days from 8:00 a.m. until 5:00 p.m., Sundays and holidays from 1:00 p.m. until 5:00 p.m. Throughout the Museum there will be varied exhibits ranging from a showing of extinct species down to contemporary birds and mammals of Iowa. Several famous collections will be on view. RADIO STATION WSUI Many of the events of the Fine Arts Festival are made available to radio listeners by the services of the University radio station, WSUI. In addition, a number of special programs of artistic interest will originate in the WSUI studios. IOWA MEMORIAL UNION Recordings, Radio, Television, Reproductions, Organ The spacious Music Room of the Iowa Memorial Union, with excellent high-fidelity equipment and an extensive library of recordings, will be available to the pubhc dur¬ ing the Twenty-First Annual Fine Arts Festival. Broadcasts of interesting operatic and symphonic programs are received from time to time in the Music Room. In the Television Theatre programs are available in both black and white and color every day and evening. In addition, telecasts of public events of unusual interest are presented in the Main Lounge. The Concert Organ in the Main Lounge of the Union will be heard from time to time throughout the summer festival. GENERAL ADMINISTRATION President of the University, Virgil Melvin Hancher Administrative Dean, Allin W. Dakin Provost, Harvey H. Davis Dean, Graduate College, Walter F. Loehwing Dean, College of Liberal Arts, Dewey B. Stuit Director, Summer Session, E. T. Peterson SCHOOL OF FINE ARTS-IOWA MEMORIAL UNION Earl Enyeart Harper, Director Department of Art—Earl E. Harper, Acting Head Department of Speech and Dramatic Art—H. Clay Harshbarger, Chairman Department of Music—Himie Voxman, Head University Museum—Walter C. Thietje, Curator Iowa Memorial Union—George F. Stevens, Assistant Director New series No. 1812, August 15, 1959. Published by the State University of Iowa, Iowa City, Iowa. Issued weekly during February, March, and April, semimonthly during the remainder of the year. Entered at the post office at Iowa City as second-class matter under the Act of August 24, 1912. University of Iowa Libraries

record.description: Festival included an exhibition of paintings and drawings by faculty, featuring works by three distinguished visiting artists, Ben-Zion, Keith Vaughan, and Mitchell Fields; a lecture series including Vance Packard, Benjamin Fine, and Morris Hindus; plays and musical performances; "Professor Roy Sieber has ... prepared for the 21st Fine Arts Festival an exhibition of objects and photographs selected from the study collection he assembled in Nigeria only last year ... This exhibition focuses attention on one well-known style, that of the Yoruba of Western Nigeria, and on the arts of two little known areas near the Benue River in Northern Nigeria"--Inside front cover.

record.full-text: hi'50 7, FOREWORD The Eighteenth Annual Festival of Fine Arts at the State University of Iowa is proud to present the first major exhibition in this area of African sculpture in which a survey of the principal tribal styles is attempted. The exhibition has been selected, arranged and cata¬ logued by Roy Sieber of the Department of Art. He has had the aid and counsel of a number of mem¬ bers of the Department and others among whom the following should be named: Professor Humbert Albrizio, Mr. Ralph C. Aitman, Professor William R. Bascom, Miss Geraldine Bruckner, Mr. William Fagg, Professor Melville J. Herskovits, Mr. Kenneth E. Kidd, Mr. J. J. Klejman, Professor Mauricio Lasansky, Mr. William Lasansky, Dr. Lester D. Longman, Mrs. Margaret Plass, and Mr. Nicos Zographos. A special note of gratitude is due Mr. Raymond Wielgus for his keen interest and active concern. The University is grateful to the many museums, galleries and private collectors who have loaned rare and valuable sculptures for this exhibition and who have granted permission for their reproduction. The following institutions and persons have made their valuable art objects available: Aitman Antiques, Los Angeles; Mr. and Mrs. Ralph C. Aitman, Los Angeles; The American Museum of Natural History, New York; The Baltimore Museum of Art, Wurtzburger Collection; Professor William R. Bascom, Evanston; The Brooklyn Museum, New York; The Buffalo Museum of Science; The Carlebach Gallery, New York; Galerie Carrefour, Paris; The Allan Frumkin Gallery, Chicago; Professor Melville J. Herskovits, Evanston; Mrs. W. S. Jaggard, Des Moines; Mr. and Mrs. Jack Jungmeyer, Jr., Los Angeles; The J. J. Klejman Gallery, New York; Profes¬ sor and Mrs. Mauricio Lasansky, Iowa City; Dr. and Mrs. Lester D. Longman, Iowa City; The Minneapolis Institute of Arts; The Royal Ontario Museum of Archaeology, Toronto; The Peabody Museum, Harvard University, Cambridge; The University Museum, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia; Mrs. Webster Plass, New York; Miss Jeanne H. Richards, Iowa City; The Segy Gallery, New York; Mr. Ladislas Segy, New York; Mr. and Mrs. Roy Sieber, Iowa City; The City Art Museum of St. Louis; Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Souders, Iowa City; and Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Wielgus, Chicago. Earl Enyeart Harper, Director School of Fine Arts State University of Iowa State University of \ow» LIBRARIES

record.title: Page 02
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: INTRODUCTION African sculpture makes little contact with either classi¬ cally derived canons of beauty or the 'objective' image of man and the world conjured up by the Renaissance experimentalists and substantiated by photography. Until recently this absence of both naturalism and classicism constituted a barrier to esthetic apperception, not only of African, but of all primitive and exotic arts. In about 1905 African sculpture was 'discovered' nearly simultaneously by the Fauves (and, reputedly, Picasso) in Paris and the expressionist group. Die Brucke, in Dresden, although it had been appreciated previously by a number of ethnologists. From the vantage point of a half-century, this 'dis¬ covery' seems to fit the pattern of growth of the roman¬ tic aspect of modern art. Romanticism, to take the larger meaning, is a way of life and art that replaces classical rationality and the ideal, with subjectivity, self-ex¬ pression, sensationalism and the exotic. This attitude gradually had become programmatic during the nine¬ teenth century, but not until the Post-Impressionists had it begun to focus predominantly on exotic styles instead of exotic subject matter. Artists and critics discerned in African art a world of new formal relationships, admirable because they could be construed as anti-classical and anti-'objective'. Some critics attributed personal spontaneity and self-expres¬ sion to African art in their ignorance of its traditional forms and symbols. The imputation of twentieth century esthetic refinements to the African sculptor has im¬ peded sensible analysis by forcing his work into an expressionistic strait-jacket. This point of view has been protested, as well it should be. It may have served to evangelize 'modern' art, but it has forestalled a full and accurate under¬ standing of tribal art. Works of art may be interpreted at several levels and it does an injustice not only to the art, but to the viewer, to confine the study and apprec¬ iation of any art to any one level. African sculpture has commonly been evaluated by the esthetic criteria of the twentieth century. It deserves to be examined as fully as the art of any epoch or country. The great diversity of tribal styles reflected in this exhibition, and the limited number of intensive studies of the subject combine to make generalizations about African art difficult. Studies that have been made so far indicate that highly conventionalized sets of beliefs gave rise to the sculptures. The latter, in turn, helped to strengthen and conserve those beliefs. The purposes that gave rise to the sculpture are the material and spiritual security of the tribe, the family, and the indi¬ vidual. Thus African art is a conservative art. Yet it is not so bound to tradition that individual styles cannot be recognized by connoisseurs. Certain carvings from the Baule, Yoruba, and Baluba tribes can be attributed with certainty to particular sculptors. There is no proof of great antiquity for the sculptural styles. Wood is subject to decay and destruction by in¬ sects, and as a result few carvings survive more than a century. The African sculptor is more closely integrated with his total culture than is the twentieth century artist, in that he affirms its central beliefs, rather than criticizing them. His masks and figures are part of a totality which includes an accepted mythology, music, dance, and costume. This is neither to laud the twentieth century artist for his 'freedom' nor to condemn him because he does not accept many of the premises of his culture. Esthetic value systems have varied considerably throughout history, and do not necessarily improve uniformly as we approach the present. We have no University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 03
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: assurance that our esthetic formulations are superior to those of other epochs. They may seem right for us and we believe in them. But the African believes as fully in his view of the world. To comprehend these sculptures in the context of the cultural commitments of the artist, it is therefore neces¬ sary to set aside, for the moment, our own prejudices. Only then can we examine them in their own terms and discover the richly symbolic level at which many of them function. To this end, the notes in the catalogue attempt to give an idea of the cultural role of the sculptures, often, however, as inadequately as describ¬ ing a painting by Fra Angelico as a polychromed ritual object from Central Italy. Roy Sieber The following books and catalogues are recommended illustrations, or both, to serve as a brief introductory bibl on the basis of text, ography. Allen Memorial Art Museum Bulletin, Volume XIII, No. 2, Oberlin, Ohio, 1956. Bascom, William R., and Gebauer, Paul, HANDBOOK OF WEST AFRICAN ART, Ed. by Robert E. Ritzenthaler, Popular Science Handbook Series, No. 5, Bruce Publishing Co., Milw^aukee, 1953. MASTERPIECES OF AFRICAN ART, The Brooklyn Museum, Brooklyn, 1954. Christensen, Erwin C, PRIMITIVE ART, Thomas Y. Crowell Co., New York, 1955. Fagg, William, THE WEBSTER PLASS COLLECTION OF AFRICAN ART, The British Museum, London, 1953. Griaule, Marcel, FOLK ART OF BLACK AFRICA, Tudor Publishing Co., New York, 1950. Kjersmeier, Carl, CENTRES DE STYLE DE LA SCULPTURE NEGRE AFRI- CAINE, 4 vols., Editions Albert Morance, Paris, 1935-38. Lem, F. H., SCULPTURES SOUDANAISES, Arts et Metiers Graphiques, Paris, 1948. Plass, Margaret, AFRICAN TRIBAL SCULPTURE, The University Museum, Philadelphia, 1956. Radin, Paul and Sweeney, James Johnson, AFRICAN FOLKTALES AND SCULPTURE, Bollingen Series XXXII, Pantheon Books, New York, 1952. Segy, Ladislas, AFRICAN SCULPTURE SPEAKS, Lawrence Hill and Co., New York, 1952. Sydow, Eckart Von, AFRIKANISCHE PLASTIK, George Wittenborn, Inc., New York, 1954. Wingert, Paul S., THE SCULPTURE OF NEGRO AFRICA, Columbia Uni¬ versity Press, New York, 1950. University of Iowa Libraries

record.full-text: CATALOGUE The following items are arranged in an approximate geographical sequence: from the French Sudan through the Guinea Coast, the Cameroons, French Equatorial Africa, and the Congo. All pieces are of wood, unless otherwise noted. T. DOGON TRIBE Female supplicant figure. Such figures, which may represent an¬ cestors imploring rain, are said by the Dogon to come from an earlier culture. This figure was discovered in a rock shelter sanctuary near the village of Ibi in the region of the Bandiagara escarp¬ ment on the upper Niger River in the French Sudan. H. 16 3/8 inches. (Illus¬ trated in the Allen Memorial Art Museum Bulletin, XIII, No. 2, Pi. 7.) • Lent by Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Wielgus. 2. DOGON TRIBE Hermaphrodite. Probably connected with the highly developed ancestor cult of the Dogon. This example possibly was a family altar piece and housed the tutelary spirit of the family. H. 8% inches. - Lent by Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Wielgus. 3. DOGON TRIBE Antelope mask used in funeral ceremonies in rites of expiation for tribal ancestors. The Dogon produced a great variety of masks, nearly all of which exhibit a stylized quality reminis¬ cent of their architectural forms. The abstract nature of much of the art of the French Sudan may be due to the influ¬ ence of the Moslems who have dom¬ inated the area for a thousand years. H. about 22 inches. - Lent by The Galerie Carrefour. 4. DOGON TRIBE Door latch of unusually complicated design. The figures, six in number, may serve an apotropaic func¬ tion. H. 23y2 Inches. - Lent by Aitman Antiques. 5. BAMBARA TRIBE Standing female figure of a type usually identified with an¬ cestral, occasionally with fertility, rites. H. 25'/2 inches. Lent by Aitman Antiques. 6. BAMBARA TRIBE Female figure. A child protective figure, or twin figure similar to the Ibeji of the Yoruba. H. 6% inches. (Illustrated in Segy, Fig. 113.) Lent by Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Wielgus. 7. BAMBARA TRIBE Dance headdress in the form of an antelope. Some indication of the rich variety of these chi wara masks is given by this and the three fol¬ lowing pieces. Attached to basketry caps and worn atop the dancer's head, they are used in dances which re-enact the mythological origin of agriculture. H. 29 Lent by Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Wielgus. TRIBE Dance headdress in the form of a female antelope with fawn. Copper plaques are attached to this piece from the Koutiala region. H. about 27 Inches. Lent by the Galerie Carrefour. 9. BAMBARA TRIBE Dance headdress in the form of an antelope surmounted by a female human figure. H. 18 1/4 inches. Lent by Aitman Antiques. 10. BAMBARA TRIBE Dance headdress in the form of an antelope surmounted by a human figure. From the Bamako re¬ gion. H. about 26 inches. Lent by the Galerie Carrefour. 11. BAMBARA TRIBE Mask surmounted by four horns and a female figure. Such masks were used in the boys' secret society (N'tomo). H. 24 inches. (Illus¬ trated in Wingert, No. 5.) Lent by The Buffalo Museum of Science. 12. BAMBARA TRIBE Mask of mixed human and animal (antelope?) forms. Probably a men's society mask. H. 20 inches. Lent by The Allan Frumkin Gallery. 13. MINIANKA-BAMBARA TRIBE Horned casque mask from the Mopti region of the French Sudan. H. about 20 inches. Lent by the Galerie Carrefour. 14. BOBO TRIBE Mask. A small tribe, the Bobo live in the French Sudan and North¬ ern Ivory Coast. They are best known for their intensely colored masks. Lent by The J. J. Kleiman Gallery. 15. MOSSI TRIBE Mask. This tribe has been almost entirely converted to., Moham¬ medanism and thus produces little art. Lent by The J. J. Klejman Gallery. 16. MENDE TRIBE Steatite figure. These fi¬ gures from Sierra Leone are called No- mori and are in a style totally unlike modern Mende carvings. One old wood¬ en figure in the British Museum is, however, in the same style, indicating that, although these are old, they are Lent by The J. J. Klejman Gallery. 17. MENDE TRIBE Steatite equestrian figure (Nomori). H. 4V4 inches. Lent by The Baltimore Museum of Art, Wurtzburger Collection. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 06
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: 18. MENDE TRIBE Casque mask worn in ceremonies of the Bundu or Sande secret society for women and said to represent the protective spirit of the society. H. I6V2 inches. Lent by The University Museum, Uni¬ versity of Pennsylvania. 19. KISSI TRIBE Steatite figure similar to the Nomori figures of the Mende. H. 434 inches. Lent by The Buffalo Museum of Science. 20. DAN TRIBES Male figure. The Dan of eastern Liberia and western Ivory Coast are known by various tribal names and are better known for their masks than for their figures. H. 19 inches. Lent by Aitman Antiques. 21. DAN TRIBES Poro mask in the form of a hornbill. This mask was collected among the Mende, but closely approxi¬ mates the Dan style. The Poro, a highly organized secret society to which all men must belong, is based on ancestor wor¬ ship, but has enormous social and eco¬ nomic influence. Initiation is complex, lengthy and expensive. At a 'Bush' university the adolescent initiate learns not only tribal customs, but a trade as well. The masks personify spirits and serve various functions as the following examples indicate. H. 13'/2 inches. Lent by Mr. and Mrs. Ralph C. Aitman. 22. GE TRIBE Poro mask of the Son! Clan, Be Town,. Liberia. Guardian of the boys in the circumcision bush, tending their ills. This mask and the following four were collected by George W. Harley. Lent by The Peabody Museum, Harvard University. 23. GE TRIBE Poro mask from Liola (French side), Liberia. Doctor who came to treat pestilence which had not yielded to ordinary herb doctors and diviners. H. 10 inches. (Illustrated in Wingert, No. 14.) Lent by The Peabody Museum, Harvard University. 24. GIO TRIBE Poro mask from Tawie, Bu- tulu Section, Liberia. This mask served as the badge of office of a judge who heard lawsuits for debt and settled palavers between lesser 'devils.' Lent by The Peabody Museum, Harvard University. 25. GIO TRIBE Poro mask from Beinwie, near Deneni, French Ivory Coast. One of a number of ancestoral spirits which presided at public ceremonies. This mask was called to dance when a chief wished Lent by The Peabody Museum, Harvard 26. GIO TRIBE Poro mask. This 'sheep' spirit (note ram's horns for eyebrows) probably taught medicine in the Bush school. H. 91/2 inches. , , Lent by Mr. and Mrs. Ralph C. Aitman. 4 27. WOBE (or DAN-NGERE) TRIBE Mas Probably a Poro mask. H. 12 inches. Lent by The Allan Frumkin Gallery. 28. GURO TRIBE Mask of mixed hums and animal forms. The Guro, like tl- Baule to the east and the Senufo to th north, exhibit a highly sophisticated a considered typical of the Ivory Coast. I 10 inches. Lent by The University Museum, Unive sity of Pennsylvania. 29. GURO TRIBE Mask of n human attributes. xed a University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 07
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: 30. GURO TRIBE Heddle pulley for a loom topped by a carved human head with hair arranged to resemble horns. H. 7 Lent by The Segy Gallery. 31. ALANGUA TRIBE Standing female fig¬ ure. The Alangua are a coastal people whose art shows some influence of the Baule. H. 10 inches. Lent by Mr. Ladislas Segy. 32. BAULE TRIBE Standing male figure. It is difficult to distinguish figures with an¬ cestoral significance from those made purely for esthetic enjoyment, for the Baule of the Ivory Coast exhibit a rather self-conscious 'art-for-art's-sake' attitude unusual for Africa. H. 16 inches. (Illus¬ trated in Wingert, No. 21.) Lent by The University Museum, Univer¬ sity of Pennsylvania. (Photograph courtesy of the museum.) 33. BAULE TRIBE. Seated female figure. H. 17 inches. (Illustrated in Wingert, No. 20.) Lent by The University Museum, Univer¬ sity of Pennsylvania. 34. BAULE TRIBE Seated male figure 2OV2 inches. Lent by Aitman Antiques. 35. BAULE TRIBE Seated male figure. 25V4 inches. Lent by The Carlebach Gallery. 36. BAULE TRIBE Seated female figure. H. 121/2 inches. Lent by The Carlebach Gallery. 37. BAULE TRIBE Male figure. An old, un¬ usually naturalistic example. (Formerly Andre Derain Collection.) H. 11 inches. Lent by The Allan Frumkin Gallery. 38. BAULE TRIBE Mask. H. 15 inches. (Illus¬ trated in Wingert, No. 22.) Lent by The Buffalo Museum of Science. 39. BAULE TRIBE Horned mask, apparently a prestige piece and not meant to be worn for there are no eye holes. H. 19 inches. (Illustrated in Christensen, Fig. 14.) i. Ralph C. Aitman. 40. BAULE TRIBE Mask. A rather unusual example showing outside influences, pos¬ sibly of Guro. H. 19 inches. Lent by the Carlebach Gallery. 41. BAULE TRIBE Heddle pulley for a locm. Two heads, one human, one bovine or antelope, top this piece. H. 8 inches. Lent by The Segy Gallery. 42. SENUFO TRIBE Female figure. Similar pieces have been collected among the Bobo, or attributed to the Bambara. This piece is in a style transitional between Sudan and Ivory Coast styles. Pieces of this type have been classed as fertility fetishes or divination figures. H. 8 9/16 inches. Lent by Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Wielgus. 43. SENUFO TRIBE Large casque mask ('fire- spitter') of mixed animal and human forms of the type used in the men's secret society, the Korubia, for protec¬ tion against sorcerers and soul stealers. Burning tinder is placed in the mouth of the mask so that it 'breathes' smoke and flames. L. 331/2 inches. Lent by The Carlebach Gallery. 44. SENUFO TRIBE Mask of the type used in Lo Society dances. H. I21/2 inches. 45. SENUFO TRIBE Mask. From the Koro- gho region and similar to the preceding mask. This piece is surmounted by a small human head. The style of the latter is not typical of Senufo carvings. H. about 16 inches. Lent by The Galerie Carrefour. 46. SENUFO TRIBE Heddle pulley for a loom. The top probably is a stylized hornbill. H. 51/2 inches. Lent by The Segy Gallery. 47. ASHANTI TRIBE Mother and child. The Ashanti became the dominant tribe of the Gold Coast shortly after establishing a kingdom in the 18th century. This piece is exceptional, for the Ashanti are not generally known for their sculpture. H. 121/4 inches. (Illustrated in Christen¬ sen, Fig. 17.) t by A and Mrs. Ralph C. Aitman. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 08
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: 48. ASHANTI TRIBE Wooden doll (akua ba) which served as a fertility fetish. H. 151/2 inches. (Illustrated in Wingert, No. 28.) Lent by The Royal Ontario Museum of Archaeology. 49. ASHANTI TRIBE Fifty brass weights for weighing gold dust. Representation of humans, animals, vegetables, manufac¬ tured objects and geometric forms occur. They seem to have had a complex sym¬ bolism, for example, the Sankofa bird symbolized the course of the sun; the crocodile, fertility; the snake, death. H. 1/2 to 3 inches. Lent by Mrs. Webster Plass. 50. ASHANTI TRIBE Three brass boxes for storing gold dust. L. 1 to 3 inches. Lent by The Baltimore Museum of Art, Wurtzburger Collection. 51. ASHANTI TRIBE Pottery elephant carry¬ ing an animal (hippopotamus?) in its trunk. H. about 6 inches. Lent by Aitman Antiques. 52. DAHOMEY TRIBE Janus figure which protects household from evil. Should evil get by the outward facing figure and into a household the second figure will take care of it on its way out. This piece is an example of popular art as opposed to art supported by the legend¬ ary court of Dahomey. H. about 24 Lent by Professor Melville J. Herskovits. 53. DAHOMEY TRIBE 'Bell' used by diviner to tap lightly on the ground as he in¬ vokes the powers that make divination possible. L. about 12 inches. Lent by Professor Melville J. Herskovits. 54. YORUBA TRIBE Model of a housepost from the town of Efon-Alaiye, Ekiti area. The Yoruba are one of ths largest African tribes and are prolific carvers. H. about 30 inches. Lent by Professor William R. Bascom. 55. YORUBA TRIBE Female figure with a bowl in the form of a chicken used in divination. H. about 15 inches. Lent by Professor Melville J. Herskovits. 56. YORUBA TRIBE Mother and child. Pos¬ sibly a representation of Yemanja, god¬ dess of water. H. about 18 inches. Lent by Professor Melville J. Herskovits. 57. YORUBA TRIBE Female figure. H. 273/4 inches. Lent by The Royal Ontario Museum of Archaeology. 58. YORUBA TRIBE Dance staff in the form of a figure with a 'double axe' symbol above its head, used in the cult of Shango, the thunder god. H. 263A inches. Lent by Aitman Antiques. 59. YORUBA TRIBE Symbol of authority of a priest consisting of strips of leather attached to a handle in the form of a human figure. H. (figure only) about 8 inches. Lent by Professor Melville J. Herskovits. made after the death of one or both twins. The Ibeji of the dead twin was carried about, fed, clothed and bathed by the mother or surviving twin. The figures were taken care of as long as one twin or the mother survived and kept thereafter by the family. H. 9% inches. (Illustrated in Wingert, No. 33.) Lent by The Royal Ontaric Archaeology. Muse 1 of 61. YORUBA TRIBE Twin figures (Ibeji). This pair is from the Oyo district, the area of the ruling caste of the Yoruba. Ibeji are always nude, standing, arms at sides and with facial scarifications in¬ dicative of the tribe. H. about 11 inches. Lent by Professor William R. Bascom. 62. YORUBA TRIBE Gelede mask probably from near the Dahomean border. The Gelede, a religious group, is associated with the appeasement of 'witches.' The masks are carved and worn in pairs. H. 131/2 inches. Lent by Aitman Antiques. 63. YORUBA TRIBE Gelede double mask. L. 131/4 inches. (Illustrated in Wingert, No. 38.) Lent by The Royal Ontario Museum of Archaeology. 64. BINI TRIBE Cast bronze head of a queen mother. A warlike tribe, the Bini established an empire whose capital was the city of Benin. Their bronzes are well-known, (many were brought back by a British punitive expedition in 1897). Bronze casting was a court-foster¬ ed art. This piece is one of five of this type known. They are said to represent the deceased queen mother and were placed on the Altar of the Mothers in the palace of the Oba (King). H. I81/2 Lent by The University Museum, Univer¬ sity of Pennsylvania. 65. BINI TRIBE Small bronze head. H. 81/4 Lent by The University Museum, Univer¬ sity of Pennsylvania. 66. BINI TRIBE Bronze figure of a Portu¬ guese warrior. This piece possibly was made in the 16th century. H. I51/2 Lent by The Carlebach Gallery. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 09
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: 67. BINI TRIBE Bronze plaque with two standing figures. Early reports state that the walls fronting on the main street leading to the Oba's residence were decorated with plaques. H. I6I/2 inches, (piece not quite complete). Lent by The University Museum, Univer¬ sity of Pennsylvania. 68. IBO TRIBE Fetish figure (Ikenga). Unlike the Ashanti and Yoruba, political power is not centralized among the Ibo of eastern Nigeria. As a result a wide var¬ iation of types and styles of carvings exists. This Ikenga ('strength of the right arm'), probably from the Onitsha district, is a personal fetish responsible for the strength, wealth and prestige of its own¬ er. H. 19 inches. Lent by Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Wielgus. 69. IBO TRIBE Figure representing a famil¬ iar deity of diviners. It is used to appeal to ancestors, ghosts of famous diviners and other supernatural agencies to aid in divination. H. about 12 inches. Lent by Professor Melville J. Herskovits. 102 Lent by Professor William R. Bascom. 71. IBO TRIBE 'Beautiful maiden spirit' mask of the Maw society for men. This society, which produces a number of masks, is concerned with ancestor cult rites and administrative activities. It also conducts dramatic 'plays.' H. 19 inches. Lent by The University Museum, Univer¬ sity of Pennsylvania. 72. IBO TRIBE Male Maw mask from the Udi division of Onitsha Province. H. about 17 inches. Lent by Professor William R. Bascom. 73. IBO TRIBE Maw mask from the Udi re¬ gion. There are three types of 'play' masks: beautiful, awesome and humor¬ ous. This seems to be an example of the latter type. H. about 19 inches. Lent by Professor William R. Bascom. 74. IBO TRIBE Maw mask of massive size from the Udi region. H. about 31 inches. Lent by Professor William R. Bascom. 75. IBO TRIBE Mask of the Ayaka secret society from Achi in Owerri Province. This men's society acts as a judicial, legislative and policing body. H. about Lent by Professor A ville J. Herskovits. 76. IBO TRIBE Mask from Achi H. about 14 inches. Awgu. by Professor William R. Bascom. 77. IBO TRIBE Goat mask from town of Achi near Awgu. Lent by Professor William R. Bascom. 78. IBO TRIBE Mask. Although this piece was collected among the Ibo, it is identical in style to Ekpo secret society masks of the Ibibio, eastern neighbors of the Ibo. There are strong Ibibio in¬ fluences in the Bende region where this piece was collected. Ekpo masks repre¬ sent spirits of the underworld which are wayward, irresponsible and dangerous to the uninitiated. H. about 14 inches. Lent by Professor William R. Bascom. 79. IBO TRIBE Mask. As with the preceding mask, this piece, collected in the Bende region, closely resembles certain Ibibio Ekpo society masks. H. about 10 inches. Lent by Professor William R. Bascom. 80. IBIBIO TRIBE Figure used in the Akan secret society. The figure was tied to the back of a dancer. It may never have had arms. A dance, for which similar figures were carved, is known to have been abandoned about fifty years ago. The headdress of this figure is of a type in vogue about that time. H. about 20 Lent by Professor Melville J. Herskovits. 81. IBIBIO TRIBE Female figure. This and a male figure were mounted on a platform used as a dance headdress. This piece was collected in the town of Ikot Ek- pene and was made by the Anang sub- tribe. H. about 20 inches. Lent by Professor William R. Bascom. 82. IBIBIO TRIBE Headdress in the form of a human head covered with skin from a bush deer. Fibers placed on the wood under the skin simulate tribal scarifica¬ tion marks. Despite reports to the con¬ trary, human skin was probably never used. Similar heads among the Ekoi represent ancestors. H. about 20 inches. Lent by Professor Melville J. Herskovits. 83. EKOI TRIBE Headdress in the form of a human head covered with animal skin. Such heads are typical of the Cross River area. H. 9 inches. (Illustrated in Wingert, No. 50.) Lent by The Buffalo Museum of Science. 84. MAMBILA TRIBE Figure, possibly ancest¬ ral, from the Adamawa Province, North¬ ern Cameroons. The style of this piece indicates that Mambila carving was little affected by the Fulani invasion a century and a half ago. H. about 8 inches. Lent by Professor Melville J. Herskovits. 85. MAMBILA TRIBE Double-faced animal mask. A similar, but single-faced mask, collected by Gebauer, (who also collect¬ ed this and the preceding piece), repre¬ sents a crow totem. L. about 16 inches. Lent by Professor Melville J. Herskovits. 86. BIFUMEN TRIBE Seated figure holding a bowl. H. I6V4 inches. Lent by The Buffalo Museum of Science. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 10
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: Lent by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Jungmeyer, Jr. 88. UNDETERMINED TRIBE Mask of 'human¬ ized' yet grotesque animal forms typical of the central Cameroons, especially the Bekom. H. I91/4 inches. 89. UNDETERMINED TRIBE Pottery pipe with carved human face in the style of the central Cameroons. H. about 8 inches. Lent by Professor Melville J. Herskovits. 90. UNDETERMINED TRIBE Small seated fig¬ ure holding a drinking horn. This cast brass piece is probably from the central Cameroons, the face is reminiscent of brass masks of the Bamum tribe. H. 4 3/8 Lent by The Baltimon Wurtzburger Collectior Museum of / 91. FANG TRIBES Head. A group of tribes, collectively called Fang or Pangwe, mi¬ grated into the southern Cameroons, Spanish Guinea and the Gabun about a century ago. Fang figure carvings exhibit a quite uniform, extremely sculptural style. They range from single heads, which may be the oldest type, through half to full figures. The carving at the base of the neck indicates that this piece may have been attached to some object such as a staff or a harp. H. 11 inches. (Cover photograph.) Lent by Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Wielgus. 92. BENE TRIBE Fang style male figure holding a drinking horn. This example was collected in 1919-20 and was re¬ ported to have been used as a talisman for trading ventures. H. 231/2 inches. (Illustrated in Wingert, No. 63.) Lent by The Peabody Museum, Harvard University. 93. NTUM TRIBE Fang style male figure. The posts on which many of these figures sit served to attach them to bark containers in which the skulls of an¬ cestors were kept. The figures may not represent particular persons, but may serve a protective function. H. 24 inches. (Illustrated in Wingert, No. 64.) Lent by The Peabody Museum, Harvard 94. FANG TRIBES Female half-figure col¬ lected in Spanish Guinea. H. 211/2 inches. (Illustrated in Wingert, No. 65.) Lent by The Peabody Museum, Harvard University. 95. FANG TRIBES Standing male figure. H. 16'/4 inches. Lent by The Carlebach Gallery. . FANG TRIBES Harp with carved human head. A unique piece. The head and 'body' of the instrument are carved from a single block of wood. Many small heads, especially those with holes bored through the neck, probably were detached from harps such as this. H. 281A inches; head and neck, 8 inches. Lent by Professor and ; 97. FANG TRIBES Mask. A number of tr in the Gabun make white-faced m similar to this in type. They are usl White is the color of death, or of the dead. H. 111/2 inches. Lent by The Carlebach Gallery 98. OGOWE RIVER TRIBES Mask. Masks of this type are used in the Mukui men's society dances and represent the spirits of dead women. They are attributed to the M'Pongwe, Balumbo and other tribes. H. about 15 inches. (Illustrated in Wingert, No. 71.) Lent by The Brooklyn Museum. 99. ADOUMAS TRIBE Mask. Again from the region of the Ogowe River, this rather flat type is attributed to this tribe. H. 11 Lent by The Segy Gallery. 100. BAKOTA TRIBES Funerary figure. These extremely two-dimensional wooden fig¬ ures covered with brass plates perform a function similar to the Fang figures. Placed on baskets of bones they are evil dispelling figures, but are differentiated according to sex. The concave face of this example identifies it as female. H. Lent by Mr. and Mrs. Roy Sieber. 101. BAKOTA TRIBES Funerary brass and copper plates c smaller and older piece t University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 11
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: ceding one. That this piece has seen ritual use is indicated by the partial destruction of the lozenge-shaped base. H; 12 inches. (Illustrated in Segy, Fig. 174.) Lent by Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Wielgus. 102. BAKOTA TRIBES Funerary figure. This rare type (only about 18 examples are known), is termed Ossyeba after the village where the first recorded piece was collected. This piece was formerly in the Musee de I'Homme in Paris. H. 20 inches. (Illustrated in Radin and Sweeney, Fig. 142.) Lent by Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Wielgus. 103. BABEMBE (or BABWENDE) TRIBE Female figure with elaborate scarification on abdomen and eyes of inlaid bone. Fig¬ ures of this type may represent ancestors or household deities. H. 7 inches. Lent by Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Wielgus. 104. BABEMBE (or BABWENDE) TRIBE Male figure. H. 7i/8 inches. Lent by Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Wielgus. 105. BATEKE TRIBE Male fetish figure. Ex¬ amples similar in style are known from a half dozen tribes in the region of Stanley Pool. Such figures may have originated in this area and spread to other tribes such as the Bakongo. The Bateke tattooed themselves with parallel cuts from temple to chin as seen in this figure. Similarly, the aristocracy of the tribe affected complex hair styles such as this example exhibits. H. I21/2 inches. (Illustrated in Wingert, No. 77.) Lent by The University Muse sity of Pennsylvania. I, Univer- 106. BATEKE TRIBE Male fetish figure. This piece is unusual in that it does not have a hole for 'medicine.' These figures may serve to protect a child until his initiation at adolescence. H. 10 inches. Lent by Dr. and Mrs. Lester D. Longman. 107. BAYANZI TRIBE Female fetish figure. This piece is similar in style to the two preceding, but is carved with a heavier touch. H. 6 inches. (Illustrated in Segy, Fig. 261.) Lent by Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Wielgus. 108. BAKONGO TRIBE Mother and child. Probably served as a maternity fetish. H. 12 inches. (Illustrated in Segy, Fig. 17.) 109. BAKONGO TRIBE Nail fetish (Konde). All such figures seem to come from the area of the mouth of the Congo River. The cutting of the tree from which the figure is to be carved is often ac¬ companied by human sacrifice. The nails may produce death magically, fend off disease, or ward off evil. In the latter case, the nail seems to 'remind' the fetish of its obligation. H. 25 inches. (Illustrated in Segy, Fig. 5.) Lent by The Royal Ontario Museum of Archaeology. no. BAKONGO TRIBE Fetish figure with large abdominal aperture for magical substances. Most figures of this type are used in the 'treatment' of diseases. The particular disease depends on the nature of the magical substance. H. 8I/2 Lent by The Segy Gallery. 111. BAKONGO TRIBE Effigy cup. Although this is described as Bakongo it closely resembles Bushongo palm-wine cups. H. about 5 inches. Lent by The University Museum, Uni¬ versity of Pennsylvania. 112. UNDETERMINED TRIBE Mask. Probably from the southern Congo, it may be Ba¬ kongo. H. 101/2 inches. Lent by Miss Jeanne H. Richards. 113. BAYAKA TRIBE Female figure. The style of the Bayaka (whose entry into the Congo in the 16th century is recorded in contemporary Portuguese accounts), is characterized by a sharply upturned nose. This may be an ancestral figure. H. 11 inches. (Illustrated in Wingert, No. 80.) Lent by The Peabody Museum, Harvard 114. BAYAKA TRIBE Mask. Probably sur¬ mounted, originally, by a cane and raffia structure similar to that on the following piece. These masks were worn by young men at ceremonies celebrating the end of their study at the bush school (Nkanda). H. IO1/2 inches. (Illustrated in Wingert, No. 78.) Lent by The Brooklyn Museum. 115. BAYAKA TRIBE Mask similar to preced¬ ing piece but with crest. H. about 22 Lent by The City Art Museum of St. 116. BAYAKA TRIBE Mask similar to preced¬ ing but with an owl-like face. H. about Lent by The City / I Museum of St. 117. BAYAKA TRIBE Casque mask s ed by an animal. H. I41/2 inches. (Illus¬ trated in Wingert, No. 79.) Lent by The University Museum, Univer¬ sity of Pennsylvania. 118. UNDETERMINED TRIBE Casque mask. Masks in this rather baby-faced style have been attributed to the Basuku, a sub-tribe of the Bayaka. H. 123/4 inches. Lent by The City Art Museum of St. 119. BAPENDE TRIBE Mask with horns. Col¬ lected by Frederick Starr in 1909. H. 14 Lent by The American Museum of Natural History. (Photograph courtesy of 120. BAPENDE TRIBE Mask worn by initiate and discarded after his induction into the tribe. The ceremony includes a sym¬ bolic death of the adolescent and his rebirth as an adult member of the tribe, accounting perhaps, for the rather ma¬ cabre character of the masks. H. 14 Lent by The Segy Gallery.

record.full-text: 121. BAPENDE Mask. H. 133/4 inches. Lent by The Buffalo Museum of Science. 122. BAPENDE TRIBE Ivory maskette of the type worn by the men after initiation into the tribe. If reflects the style of the initiation masks. H. about 3 inches. Lent by Dr. and Mrs. Lester D. Longman. 123. BUSHONGO TRIBE Casque mask. The Bushongo, or Bakuba, who lived be¬ tween the Kasai and Sankuru Rivers, are a large tribe with a strong oral history. This impressive mask has some stylistic affinity to Baluba carvings. H. 19'/2 Lent by The Minneapolis Institute of Arts. (Photograph courtesy of The Institute.) 124. BUSHONGO TRIBE Mask decorated with trade beads and cowrie shells. H. 9 Lent by The American Museum of Natural History. 125. BUSHONGO TRIBE Casque mask. This piece, collected before 1908, was de¬ scribed as a rarely seen war mask. Re¬ cent data indicates that they are used now only to amuse the spectators at dance festivals. H. 18 inches. Lent by The A History. n Muse n of Natural 126. BUSHONGO TRIBE Female figure. This and the following figure were collected before 1914. H. 20% inches. Lent by The Royal Ontario Museum of Archaeology. (Photograph courtesy of The Museum.) 127. BUSHONGO TRIBE Male figure. This piece is classed as Bashilele. Neither this nor the preceding piece seem typical of the Bushongo style. H. 231/2 inches. Lent by The Royal Ontario Museum of Archaeology. 128. BUSHONGO TRIBE Effigy cup used for the ritual drinking of palm wine. H. about 6 inches. (Illustrated in Wingert, No. 84.) Lent by The Brooklyn Museum. 129. BUSHONGO TRIBE Divination animal. L. 121/2 inches. (Illustrated in Wingert, No. 87.) Lent by The Buffalo Museum of Science. 130. BUSHONGO TRIBE Two cloths with geometric designs. Sizes 271/8x205/8 and 271/2x24 inches. Lent by The City Art Museum of St. 131. LULABA TRIBE Effigy cup. H. 5 inches. Lent by The Royal Ontario Museum of Archaeology. 126 132. BENA LULUA TRIBE Figure, probably male. Bena Lulua carvings are extremely delicate, many, like this piece, exhibit an intensive surface decoration based on scarification marks. Possibly this is a fetish for success in hunting and for the relief of illness. H. 91/2 inches. (Illus¬ trated in Wingert, No. 90.) Lent by The University Museum, Univer¬ sity of Pennsylvania. 133. BENA LULUA TRIBE Squatting figure. H. 91/2 inches. (Illustrated in Wingert, No. 92.) Lent by The University Museum, Univer¬ sity of Pennsylvania. 134. BALUBA TRIBE Neck rest supported by a seated female figure. The Baluba, a scattered group of tribes, were once part of the Lunda Empire. This piece, al¬ though small, is typical of the bold. sculptured forms of the Baluba. H. 51/2 inches. (Illustrated in Wingert, No. 105.) Lent by The Peabody Museum, Harvard University. 135. BALUBA TRIBE Mask. H. 13 inches. Lent by The Carlebach Gallery. 136. BALUBA TRIBE Hemispherical mask sim¬ ilar in style to the Basonge Kifwebe masks. H. 16 inches. (Illustrated in Win¬ gert, No. 98.) Lent by The Buffalo Museum of Science. 137. BALUBA TRIBE Ceremonial axe with carved head at base of handle. Length of handle 131/2 inches. Lent by The Royal Ontario Museum of Archaeology. 138. BALUBA TRIBE Ivory divination instru¬ ment (Katatora), used by diviner to dis¬ cover the person who caused an illness. H. 41/2 inches. Lent by Mr. Ladislas Segy. 139. BALUBA TRIBE Three ivory amulets (Hi- kisi mihasi), worn at waist or shoulder. They are believed to contain the spirit of an ancestor. H. 31/4, 31/2 and 4 inches. Lent by Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Wielgus. 140. BALUBA TRIBE Ivory amulet similar to preceding pieces. H. 4 inches. Lent by The Baltimore Museum of Art, Wurtzburger Collection. 141. BENA KANIOKA TRIBE Large chief's stool with carved female caryatid figure. Baluba influence is evident in this piece. H. 20 inches. Lent by The Peabody Museum, Harvard University. 142. BASONGE TRIBE Male fetish figure. The Basonge live to the north of the Baluba and have been somewhat influenced by them. The horn on the head of this figure contains the magical substance which activates it. H. 283A inches. Lent by The City Art Museum of St. 143. BASONGE TRIBE Male fetish figure. H. 151/2 inches. Lent by The Carlebach Gallery. 144. BASONGE TRIBE Fetish figure. The cav¬ ity in the stomach, and perhaps the eye

BASONGE TRIBE This small figure i with iron studs. H Lent by Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Wielgus. 146. BASONGE TRIBE Mask (Kifwebe). Masks of this rather dramatic form are said to have been worn by witch doctors. H. 131/2 inches. Lent by The Univ( sity of Pennsylvan Mus m, Univi 147. BASONGE TRIBE Mask (Kifwebe). These masks are thought to show Baluba influ¬ ence. H. 17 inches. (Illustrated in Win¬ gert, No. 99.) Lent by The Buffalo Museum of Science. 148. WAREGA TRIBE Ivory mask. The War- ega of the Belgian Congo are well known for their small but impressive ivory carvings. This mask is of the type used in the Mwami secret society by the men holding the highest degree (Kindi). H. 5 9/16 inches. Lent by Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Wielgus. 149. WAREGA TRIBE Wooden half - figure with four carved faces, possibly a dance staff. H. 71/4 inches. (Illustrated in Win¬ gert No. 106, but erroneously said to be Lent by The Buffalo Museum of Science. 150. WAREGA TRIBE Wooden half-figure with upraised arms. H. 9 inches. (Illus¬ trated in Wingert, No. 106, but erron¬ eously said to be ivory.) Lent by The Buffalo Museum of Science. 151. BAMBOLE TRIBE Male figure. Figures of this type (Opola) are reported to have been used in the initiation ceremonies of the Libwe Society. This tribe has been little studied. H. 12% inches. Lent by Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Wielgus. 152. NKUNDU TRIBE Ivory trumpet. Undec- orated, but with a carved mouth-piece on the inner curve of the tusk. L. about 30 inches. Lent by Mrs. W. S. Jaggard from the Jaggard Collection on loan to The Drake Divinity School. 153. NKUNDU TRIBE Three cloths. Lent by Mrs. W. S. Jaggard from the Jaggard Collection on loan to the Drake Divinity School. 154. NGBAKA (BWAKA) TRIBE Mask from Bobagalawa village of the type used in tribes of the northwest Belgian Congo are not noted for their sculpture. This piece was carved late in 1955 for a missionary and therefore has not seen tribal use. Its color, typical of most freshly painted pieces, seems harsh when compared to older pieces. H. 91/2 inches. Lent by Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Souders. 155. BAJOKWE TRIBE Figure. This tribe in¬ habits the southern Congo and Angola. Their aggressive nature is reflected in their carvings. H. ]0V4 inches. Lent by The Royal Ontario Museum of Archaeology. 156. BAJOKWE TRIBE Wooden mask. Lent by The Royal Ontario Museum of Archaeology. 157. BAJOKWE TRIBE Square wooden stool with leather top. The four cross-braces are carved with a procession of human figures. H. 15 inches. Lent by The Royal Ontario Museum of Archaeology. 158. BAJOKWE TRIBE Staff surmounted by a double-faced head. H. about 30 inches. Collection of The State University of 159. ZULU TRIBE Neckrest in the form of a buffalo. A number of neckrests of this type have been attributed to tribes in the area of the upper Zambesi River in Rhodesia. They are often said to be Barotse. L. 23 inches. (Illustrated in Win¬ gert, No. 117.) Lent by The Peabody Museum, Harvard 160. BAGA TRIBE Figure. Most carvings of the Baga of the Guinea Coast are as¬ sociated with the Simo secret society. record.title: African sculpture: 18th annual Fine Arts Festival, School of Fine Arts, State University of Iowa, June 12 - July 31, 1956
record.description: "The Eighteenth Annual Festival of Fine Arts at the State University of Iowa is proud to present the first major exhibition in this area of African sculpture in which a survey of the principle tribal styles is attempted. The exhibition has been selected ... by Roy Sieber of the Department of Art"--page 1.
record.topical-subject-lcsh: Bambara (African people); Dogon (African people); Senufo (African people); Baule (African people); Dan (African people); Bakota (African people); Fan (African people); Bateke (African people); Bapende (African people); Bushongo (African people); Sculpture, African

record.corporate-name-subject: University of Iowa. School of Art and Art History

record.title: Page 01
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: /SiTO FOREWORD r Session of 1957 i: The Fine Arts Festival at the State University of Iowa during the Sumi nineteenth in an annual series which presents concerts, dramatic productions, lectures, art exhibitions, radio and television programs, an opera, and many corollary events. The Art Exhibition of the Nineteenth Annual Fine Arts Festival introduces paintings, prints, sculpture, crafts, and design representing recent work of former students who hold one or more degrees from the State University of Iowa. The exhibition is presented in the Main Lounge of the Iowa Memorial Union and the Main Gallery and East Foyer of the Art Building. The selection of artists spans two decades of the "Iowa System" for educating artists, a system which has become the prototype for those schools which integrate a balanced studio-art history program into the traditional curricula of the College of Liberal Arts and the Graduate College. The University thanks Dr. Lester D. Longman, head of the Department of Art during the entire period when the artists represented in this catalogue received their education at the State University of Iowa, and Professor Byron Burford who has assumed personal responsibility for assembling, hanging, and cataloguing the exhibition. Members of the faculty of the Department of Art have been very cooperative, as have been the artists, galleries, and collectors who have made this exhibition possible. The University is likewise indebted to Professors Carroll Coleman and Dale Ballantyne for indispens¬ able services in preparing this catalogue. Earl E. Harper, Director School of Fine Arts and Iowa Memorial Union State University of Iowa. 3tato University of Iowa LIBRARIES sity of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Recent work by former Iowa art students: 1957 summer exhibition
record.description: "The Art Exhibition of the Nineteenth Annual Festival of Fine Arts at the State University of Iowa introduces paintings, prints, sculpture, crafts and design representing recent work of former students who hold one or more degrees from the State University of Iowa. The selection of artists spans two decades ... Dr. Lester D. Longman, head of the Department of Art ... has assumed personal responsibility for assembling ... the exhibition"--Foreword (page 1).

record.title: Fifteenth annual Fine Arts Festival: paintings by American masters, State University of Iowa, School of Fine Arts, June 17 - July 31, 1953
record.description: "The exhibition 'Paintings by Americam Masters' is presented as part of the Fifteenth Annual Fine Arts Festival at the State University of Iowa. The present exhibition presents several paintings by each of ... the [eleven] best painters in America ... named ... in LOOK Magazine, February 3, 1948."--page 3.
