record.title: Page 03
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: Foreword Since 1939, exhibitions of graphic and plastic art have been presented as major features of the Festival of Fine Arts at the State University of Iowa. Several of these, notably the definitive exhibition of the paintings of Grant Wood in 1939, assem¬ bled with the artist's personal cooperation; the annual presentations of contemporary painting from 1945 to 1949 inclusive, brought together and catalogued by Dr. Lester D. Longman, Head of the Depart¬ ment of Art of the School of Fine Arts at the State University of Iowa; the exhibition of contemporary sculpture in 1949, select¬ ed by Dr. Longman and arranged with the aid of Professor Humbert Albrizio; and the show entitled "Six Centuries of Master Drawings," prepared and catalogued by Professor William S. Heckscher for the Festival of 19.51, have proven of nation¬ wide interest. This year attention is drawn to the status of contemporary art in Iowa. The exhibi¬ tion is divided into two parts: (1) "Art Created in Iowa," and (2) "Art Collected in Iowa." For the purposes of this exhibition, con¬ temporary creative activity in Iowa is rep¬ resented by works of art in several media by members of the faculty of the Department of Art at the State University of Iowa. Limitation of space for exhibit¬ ing and the problems of selection and col¬ lection of works to be shown have led to this restriction. Next fall, art in several media by artists who are at work in other Iowa institutions of higher learning and in private studios will be presented in a spe¬ cial exhibition in the Iowa Memorial Union. All of the works of art by faculty members listed in this catalogue have been produced within the past two years — most of them within one year. This part of the exhibi¬ tion, which is housed in the Art Building of the university, has been collected and organized by Dr. Longman. The paintings presented under the caption "Art Collected in Iowa" have been chosen from museums, private collections, and from one high school by the undersigned. This part of the exhibition is presented in the Main Lounge and Lobby of the Iowa Memorial Union. The number of paintings chosen, involving the number of collections represented, has been limited by the space available. Many paintings, as well as sculptures, prints, and other works of art of excellent quality would have been available from the collections represented, as well as from other collections, both public and private, throughout the state. In general, it should be understood that the Exhibition of Contemporary Art in Iowa of the Fourteenth Annual Fine Arts Festival is in no sense intended to be ex¬ haustive, but only indicative of the activi¬ ties of Iowa artists and collectors. The university is grateful to those persons and institutions who have willingly and generously cooperated in lending the works of art presented in this exhibition. Invaluable assistance in preparing this cat¬ alogue for press was rendered by Professor Carroll Coleman of the School of Journ¬ alism. The cover was designed by Mr. Dale Ballantyne of the Departments of Art and Audio-Visual Instruction. Earl Enyeart Harper Director, School of Fine Arts State University of Iowa University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 02
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: TWENTY-TWO FESTIVAL YEARS This exhibition is dedicated affectionately to Dr, Earl E. Harper, Director of the School of Fine Arts and Founder of the suimner Festival of the Arts at the University of Iowa. In its twenty-two years the Festival has pros¬ pered in every way, reflecting his breadth of in¬ terest in all the arts and, within each, in the experimental and the traditional. The forward-looking character of the current ex¬ hibition provides an auspicious moment to look pleasantly to the years ahead under his leader¬ ship* ACKNOWLEDGMENT To the source of the exhibition, the artists, and to the generous donors of their paintings: Charles Alan, Dennis Adrian, Grace Borgenicht, Philip A. Bruno, Mr. and Mrs, AndrS Qraaerich, Sally Fairweather, Allan Frumkin, John Hohnsbeen, Martha Jackson, Sidney Janis, Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Johnson, Seymour H. I^ox, Samuel M. Kootz, Morton G. Neumann, Betty Parsons, Robert Schoelkopf, Jr., Mr. and Mrs. James S. Schramm, Gordon M. Smith, Director, Albright Gallery, Eleanor Ward and Virginia Zabriskie. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 03
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: INTRODUCTION Ubiquitous Nonobjectivity and Abstraction Today American art is in a state of furious fer¬ ment - at several levels of usage of the express¬ ion. Editorials against the contemporary trends have appeared in leading newspapers, and the not so loyal opposition has picketed the Musettm of Modem Art in New York, The question has been raised in Congress as to whether the whole abst¬ ract art movement is a gigantic communist plot, and the President of the United States has taken issue with the judgment of a committee of ex¬ perts who chose the U.S. art for the Moscow Fair. Others have likened the American artist to the Angry Yo\mg Man of Great Britain and have raised the question of deliberate perversity, contend¬ ing that the abstract artist is making the straight crooked and the plain places rough. At the same time record-breaking crowds have been attracted to avant-garde art. The galleries of the Modern Museum in New York are often far more crowded than those of the Frick Museum or Metro¬ politan, and every day, long queues form outside the new Guggenheim Musetjm for the privilege of a dizzying descent past the works of Kandinsky and Mondrian. It is clear that something exciting is going on. And it is not unique in the United States. In Caracas, Sao Paulo, Tokyo, London, Paris and Rome, abstract artists are at work, and indeed the Bi¬ ennial Exhibition at Venice - certainly an inter¬ national show - could legitimately attract the same pickets as protested in New York. Although the movement is not new - nonobjective art began fifty years ago - it has become internationally vigorous since the war. Today, several exhibitions of comparable scope and quality to ours, but chosen University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 04
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: from different American artists, could have been staged and would leave about the same impression. While the works of some contemporary American pain¬ ters are very difficult to procure for exhibition purposes, there is no dearth of possible choices. Abstract art, in short, beside being nation wide and world-wide in extent, is almost certainly es¬ poused today by the largest number of artists who have adhered to a single tendency. An Abstract for the Abstract Nonobjective (non-figurative) art is that i^ich refers to no visual objects beyond itself. It may by coincidence happen to use the color of grass or a shape which could signify the moon, but if it looks like grass or suggests the appearance of moon, it is no longer nonobjective. The true non- objective work can look like nothing but itself. In this respect it resembles music, for music does not suggest anything objective, except in program¬ matic music like Peter and the Wolf. Yet music may arouse, in its nonobjective way, the most in¬ tense feelings, covering a spectrum from gaiety to gloom. There is no theoretical reason why abs¬ tract organization of line, color, shape and tex¬ ture cannot similarly create an emotional effect. Another parallel between music and abstract art is that in each the absence of objective referents ties the work more potently to the artist's own hand, imagination or feeling. The fact that music can be made to imitate a bird call, the blast of an auto horn and other "natural" sounds requires no composer to do so; why should the artist be expected necessarily to refer to natural objects? In contrast to nonobjective art, abstract art does make use of stibject matter i^ich recalls University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 05
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: the appearance of the visual world; but the appea¬ rance may be modified, changed or distorted for purposes of the artist's interpretation, comment or personal expression. Whether working with or without a visual reference to something outside the picture, the artist tries to achieve an effect of visual totality or wholeness. This is form in art, and when lifted to a level of intensity it is expressive, and what every artist seeks. The Formal Side Broadly speaking, the works in the exhibition divide into two esthetic categories: 1) those which achieve visual unity through a balance of stable shapes and 2) those which achieve unity through an ultimate equilibrium of shifting effects. Subject matter drawn from nature can be treated either way, and so can the pure abst¬ raction. An example with the visual shapes of its subject matter in balance is Milton Avery's Two Woiaen (p. 10). A figurative work with an ¥quiilbritjm of more shifting effects is seen in Robert Bame's Old Jolyon Forsyte at the Opera (lO). '" """^"^ In Fromboluti's Red Nude the effect is so shifting that the subject may not even be discerned at first. In another work, Golub's Philosopher (lU), design may be quite stable - even monumen¬ tally fixed in its plane - and yet have a dyna¬ mically active surface in detail. Another distinction worth noting is that some artists are more prone than others to emphasize spontaneity. In its most extended expression this has been called "action painting" or "urge paint¬ ing." Kyle Morris's Cadence and Sam Francis' huge Blue-Black (13) are good examples. The idea is to break through whab is felt to be the impedi¬ menta of reason and to achieve the direct revela- University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 06
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: tion of feeling. This is not to suggest that no conscious organization of the canvas takes place, but it is not done with the strong intellectual rein of Ilya Bolotowsky or of Josef Albers (9). Finally, the well-tempered gallery goer will notice among the paintings a tendency towards increased size. This is simply a device for heightening the affective power of the painting, particularly in evoking the artist's emotional "presence." A tiny painting by Vermeer may move us as much or more, but it is a different experience resulting from close observation and patient contemplation. The contemporary artist frequently seeks a more immediate and direct impact, reaching us with an overwhelming total effect that is close to the emotions and personally expressive. Hence the term "abstract expressionism." The Question of Meaning All fine art is a compotmd of esthetic elements and of underlying meanings which influence the direction the esthetic solution takes. If a design lacks a personal quality, it loses its status as a fine art and becomes like wall paper or a terrazzo floor - impersonal and dehumanized. It does not follow, however, that the artist must have an intended meaning or even discern any mean¬ ing after the fact. It is enough for him to achieve some form of visual wholeness in a personal way. Then the meaning will automatically be there, a synthesis of his reaction to his en¬ vironment at the time. Depending on the individ¬ ual, and on his mood and intentions, this reac¬ tion may be profound and far reaching or extremely superficial and fleeting. But however slight or slighting, the personal touch separates art from both nature and the machine. There is no art without meaning.

record.title: Page 07
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: Surrealism began with the recording of random impressions and images regardless of how irra¬ tional, bizarre or unrelated to one another. The segment of contemporary painting that depends heavily on spontaneity and impulse is hence em¬ ploying an approach related to Surrealism. While the new vehicle may be abstract form rather than visually identifiable images, the extent to which impulse controls the choice of color and shape gives them the possibility - even the likelihood - of a relation to the stibconscious. It has been claimed that the violent contrasts of color frequently found today, and the ragged irre¬ gular shapes, reveal an acute subconscious anxiety and insecurity. This hypothesis might be worth serious investigation if it applied to the whole of contemporary painting, but the formal structure varies so greatly - even in an exhibition of this size - that it is impossible to find a prevailing form type. However, when individual works are considered, personal differences are evident. The compara¬ tively soft color and the rising shapes in Osver's Tuscan Spring (20) look lyrical and romantic in comparison with Lhe brashness and bold assertive- ness of color and shape in Hans Hofmann's Exuberance (15). Tadashi Sato's (22) three lines in a field suggest a refined and reticent personality. In contrast, Hans Hofmann's brilliant color and energetic shapes appear outgoing and vehement, while the equal vehemence of Esteban Vicente's very painterly T, 1959 is of an inner sort. Mark Tobey's impenetrable maze is introspective in a more intellectual way (23). Similar contrasts occur in the subject matter, when it does appear; only now the subject may be the vehicle for a particular symbolic intent. Thus, University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 08
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: Oliveira'sman by the sea (20) is totally alone, a faceless figure whose individuality has been blotted out. Diebenkom's Woman at Window (l2) is likewise alone in her great space, but there is a melancholy serenity to her isolation and the mood is not one of almost savage frustration and despair, as in the Oliveira. Leon Golub's Philosopher (lU) is a giant having a look of inner awareness who nevertheless seems capable of facing the future with implacable determina¬ tion and force. Not a gay picture - indeed the scarred surface and neutral tonality suggest a world of pain and loneliness - it nevertheless affirms a faith in the power of man. While there is some gaiety in this exhibition, it must be admitted that more often the mood is dis¬ turbed. And when serenity is foimd it seems to come through a withdrawal from external referen¬ ces into a self-created realm of inner order, symbolized through pure form. With varying effort, the gallery goer may verify these observations for himself or develop contras¬ ting ones. In either case it is clear that a simple realism could not create the impact of this exhibition or so effectively suggest the richness, complexity, uncertainty, turmoil and excitement of our contemporary world. Above all, the exhibition is an affirmation of the importance of freedom and of the integrity of the individual at a time when internal pressures re¬ sulting from a highly industrialized society and external pressures from the world power-struggle trend towards conformity. The freedom to break away from stereotypes is the wellspring of the airtistic, as it is of the intellectual life. Frank Seiberling University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 09
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs

record.title: Front cover
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: 5oa.o 20th TWENTIETH ANNUAL ^^ FESTIVAL OF FINE ARTS SCHOOL OF FINE ARTS SUMMER SESSION STATE UNIVERSITY OF IOWA Exhibition of Contemporary Paintings JUNE 18 • AUGUST 13. 1958 University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Inside front cover
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: THE FESTIVAL The Annual Fine Arts Festival at the State University of Iowa was inaugurated July 16 to 23, 1939. The first, second, and third annual festivals were compressed within a period of one week. The fourth festival was dated July 1-29, 1942. In 1943 the Fifth Annual Fine Arts Festival was extended to eight weeks, the full period of the Summer Session, and this pattern has been followed since. The Festival of Fine Arts at the State University of Iowa has chiefly been a "home talent" program from its inception. Visiting conductors, composers, dra¬ matic directors, playwrights, artists, lecturers, and critics have made their contri¬ butions to the public events of the festival largely through coaching, directing, and administering concerts, plays, and exhibitions featuring student achievements. Exhibitions of art in many media, symphony and chamber music concerts, and choral productions were featured from the beginning, but two major innovations were the introduction of an exhibition of works of art by internationally distin¬ guished artists in 1945, and an opera with complete cast, setting, lighting, costum¬ ing, and orchestral accompaniment in 1950. Each of these developments has been a major feature of the festival in subsequent years. In connection with the establishment of the Summer Exhibition of Contempo¬ rary Art, a policy of purchasing works of art for the University Permanent Collec¬ tion was inaugurated in 1945. Major art exhibitions have usually been housed partly in the Iowa Memorial Union and partly in the Art Building. In subsequent years this practice has been varied from time to time by placing separate exhibitions in these two centers. In addition to annual exhibitions of contemporary paintings, sculpture, prints, and crafts have been presented. In 1951 an important exhibition of masterpieces of drawing was featured and in 1956 an equally significant exhibition of African sculpture. This year a comprehensive exhibition of Mexican art, organized by the University of Michigan Museum staff with the co-operation of leading Mexican institutions, authorities, and artists, will be presented in the Exhibition Gallery of the Art Building from June 27 to August 3. This show, ranging from pre-Colum¬ bian days to the present, will be separately catalogued. 1 i vc'>' -" '^ ' - The first opera presented, during the festival of 1950, was The Bartered Bride, by Smetana. Since that date the following operas have been produced, each for three or four performances: University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 01
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: 1951: Die Fledermaus, Strauss 1952: Cost fan tutte, Mozart 1953: La Boheme, Puccini 1954: Love for Three Oranges, Prokofieff 1955: Marriage of Figaro, Mozart 1956: Samson and Delilah, Saint Saens (concert production) 1957: Albert Herring, Britten 1958: Madama Butterfly, Puccini (in rehearsal) In the University Theatre from three to five plays have been presented each summer since the beginning of the festival. These have ranged from early classical drama to contemporary plays and have included several original plays produced "for the first time on any stage." The staff and faculty of the Department of Dramatic Art have directed this intensive program with the assistance of a number of well known, visiting playwrights and directors from the United States and England. The Festival of Fine Arts, presented as a feature of the annual Summer Session of the University, was conceived and has been developed from the beginning through the agency of the School of Fine Arts, but only generous and effective co-operation on the part of administrative officials of the University, the director of the Summer Session, and the executive officers and faculty members of the Departments of Art, Dramatic Art, and Music, the Museum of Natural History, and the Summer Session Lecture Series, have made the festival possible. Names of individuals who have contributed to the success of the festival are recorded in the extensive program file but are too numerous for mention in this brief statement. There is a deep and abiding appreciation of the contributions which many distinguished, talented, and devoted men and women have made. New developments in connection with the annual festival are under study at the present time. It is hoped that in 1963 there may be planned and presented the 25th Annual Festival of Fine Arts at the State University of Iowa with appropriate ceremonies and observances. Earl E. Harper Director School of Fine Arts State University of Iowa State University cf Iowa University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 02
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: THE EXHIBITrON The paintings presented in this catalogue were selected and secured by Mrs. Edith Halpert, Director of the Downtown Gallery, 32 East Fifty-first Street, New York City. Mrs. Halpert was one of the first advisers consulted at the time an exhibition of contemporary art at the State University of Iowa was projected in connection with the Annual Fine Arts Festival. Subsequently her great knowledge and good offices have been helpful in connection with the planning of several festival exhibitions. Forty-three paintings by twenty-five well known artists comprise the exhibition of contemporary art for 1958. The media represented are oil, watercolor, tempera, polymer tempera, and mixed. The paintings represent artists of enduring fame and include works executed before or at the time of the creation of the festival in 1938, and others of recent date by the same artists. All of the artists have been represented in previous ex¬ hibitions at the State University of Iowa, and paintings by several of them are in¬ cluded in the Permanent Collection of the University. Some of the artists have been guests of the University in campus visits from time to time. Many of the paintings are for sale, and prices and vendors will be made known to those who are interested. The University itself will make purchases from the exhibition on the basis of the judgment of representative members of the faculty of the Department of Art at the University. It is regretted that because of unavoidable delays and inescapable deadlines it has been impossible to include in this catalogue reproductions of the paintings of some of the distinguished artists represented in the exhibition. The University thanks the artists, galleries, and collectors who have contributed paintings to the exhibition and gratefully acknowledges the helpful co-operation of the following: New York Galleries: The Downtown Gallery 32 East 51st Street Sidney Janis Gallery 15 East 57th Street Pierre Matisse Gallery 41 East 57th Street Museum of Modern Art 11 West 53rd Street Nordness Gallery 700 Madison Avenue Paul Rosenberg & Co. 20 East 79th Street The Whitney Museum of American Art 22 West 54th Street Also: William H. Lane Foundation Standard Pyroxoloid Leominster, Massachusetts Mr. and Mrs. Milton Lowenthal Mr. William E. Scott 6100 Curzon Fort Worth, Texas University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Exhibition of contemporary paintings: twentieth annual Festival of Fine Arts, School of Fine Arts, Summer Session, State University of Iowa, June 18 - August 13, 1958
record.description: Festival included an opera, Madama Butterfly, by Giacomo Puccini; "The paintings presented in this catalogue were selected ... by Mrs. Edith Halpert, Director of the Downtown Gallery ... New York City ... forty-three paintings by twenty-five ... artists of enduring fame and include works executed before the creation of the festival in 1938, and others of recent date by the same artists"--page 2; "A comprehensive exhibition of Mexican art ... ranging from pre-Columbian days to the present ... organized by the University of Michigan Museum staff with the co-operation of leading Mexican institutions, authorities, and artists ... will be separately catalogued ... [and] presented"--Inside front cover.

record.full-text: \ '¦\ '. The Thirteenth Annual Festival of Fine Arts at the State University of Iowa presents aS one of its major features the exhibition of drawings catalogued herewith. In the past the Iowa Summer Show has presented paintings and sculp¬ tures by contemporary artists. The present show features both historical and contemporary drawings. The exhibition has been chosen by Dr. Lester D. Long¬ man, who has selected the contemporary works, and Dr. William S. Heckscher, who is responsible for the historical section. The catalogue has been prepared by Dr. Heckscher with the able assistance of Mr. Wayne K. Nowack. The University is deeply grateful to those who have made loans of drawings. Museums, galleries, and private collec¬ tions have loaned rare and valuable items for this ex¬ hibition and have given us permission to reproduce them. Among those to whom the University is indebted are the following Lenders to the Exhibition: The Dudley Peter Allen Memorial Art Museum, Oberlin College. Charles P. Parkhurst. Winslow and Anna Ames, Springfield, Mo. Associated American Artists, Inc., New York. Miss Pegeen Sullivan. Curtis O. Baer, New Rochelle, N.Y. George Binet Gallery, New York. George J. Binet. record.title: Page 02
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: INTRODUCTION The twentieth may well be the last century of the "Renaissance." Mediaeval, as opposed to modern, that is. Renaissance art, lacked the ability and the desire to suggest to the beholder, as he studied a design on a white sheet of paper or vellum, that he was looking at shapes in space (1**). As people began to examine their surroundings from an egocentric point of view, powerful symbols were needed to give visual expression to a new craving to organize the world around the individual rather than to incorporate the individual into the hierarchy of a world order that the Middle Ages had known. At the end of the fourteenth century drawing became one of those symbols. Beginning with the fifteenth century (the century of art produced to cater to specific individual needs by means of woodcuts for the simple and the superstitious, books of hours for the nobles, panel portraits for the cultured; the century of scientific perspective, surface anatomy, theory of propor¬ tion), artists produced line drawings whose broken sil¬ houettes, whose ever-more carefully organized hatchings, whose imponderable stipples and other devices gave vivid expression to a revolutionary desire to make the ground on which drawings were created a "window out into space," the lines and washes, and passages heightened with white, themselves signposts to spherical and tangible shapes within space. Drawings of course might serve vastly diver¬ gent purposes: from drawings produced for the sake of production, to drawings produced for consumption; from work-drawings and sketches (in books of models or as car¬ toons in preparation for pictorial compositions, for sculpture, or for architectonic projects), to drawings that may be considered the final crystalhzation of an artistic impulse; from soliloquies — never intended to be revealed to the outsider — to exhibitions of skill. From the middle of the fifteenth century onward the artists themselves began to collect (and preserve) drawings. Here again the motives differed greatly. At first drawings were considered didactic and mnemotechnical aids. Soon collectors were urged by local pride to concentrate on drawings of certain regional ' schools." Beginning with the seventeenth century, the cen¬ tury perhaps richest in the production of drawings (50-88), non-artists entered the field, and soon the amateur art lover as a novel type came into being. The eighteenth was undoubtedly the greatest century for collecting and con- noisseurship in the field of drawing. Artists more and more produced for the "market" (89-113). What follows, as far as the appreciation of drawings is concerned, is consolida¬ tion and refinement, specialization and the opening up of new fields (such as, e.g.. Oriental drawings). America has, as far as her own history of collecting is concerned, accomplished in decades what it took centuries to accomphsh in Britain and on the European continent. Beginning with the 1930's we have seen significant exhi- (* see reproduction) "Drawings of the great masters, those enchant¬ ing hieroglyphs, will lead the true art lover step by step up to the threshold of the kingdom of the arts—and from there, once one has looked ahead, there is no return ..." Johann Wolf¬ gang von Goethe, Der Sammler und die Seini- gen, 1799. bitions of the American treasures of drawings at Buffalo, Cleveland, San Francisco, Philadelphia, just to name a few. This country is at present swept by an unmistakable and noble "vogue" for drawings. Great institutions, Croesuses, but also enthusiastic individuals are increasingly focussing their attention on drawings as objects of studv and ac¬ quisition. In selecting items for the present show in Iowa we were guided by two fundamental considerations: 1. It seemed im¬ portant to present a survey (however incomplete and un¬ even) of the entire range of post-mediaeval drawing; 2. With one or two exceptions we considered it unwise to attempt to show once more those stars of the first magni¬ tude which have featured in the United States in the "great" shows of the last two decades. Instead we have tried to aim rather at drawings that might help to illustrate significant stages in the development of the modern way of drawing, as it has been practised in the last five hundred and fifty odd years. Besides, we have endeavored to select drawings that are distinguished on account of their in¬ trinsic beauty — a kind of beauty more elusive to definition, description, and reproduction than that of any other art form in existence. While for reasons stated we could not bring to Iowa examples of the skill of some of the uni¬ versally known draftsmen (Michelangelo, Diirer, Holbein, van Gogh, Cezanne and others) we are showing first rate drawings by van Eyck (school) (4*), Perugino (9*), Wolf Huber (15, 16*), Breugel (42*), Veronese (38), Rem¬ brandt (85, 86 a.* & b., 87), Poussin (71, 72 a.* & b.*), Claude Lorrain (58*, 59 a. & b., 60, 61*), Ingres (123*, 124*), Caspar David Friedrich (118*), Daumier (116*), Kathe Kollwitz (189*), Barlach (155*), Maillol (197*), Picasso (211*, 212*, 213), and other "giants" in the field. One does not have to be a "snob" in order to be impressed by the giants, nor does one have to be an "initiate" in order to be attracted by some of the works by lesser known names. Among the latter, visitors to the show would do well to turn to such items as the immaculate sixteenth century "Man Reading and Writing" (12*), to discover for them¬ selves pearls such as the manneristic compositions by Luca Cambiaso' (25, 26*, 27*), the priceless Gossaert Mabuse (46), shown here for the first time, the brilliant and yet intimate statements by virtuosos such as Hans Bol (41*), the Elder Breugel (42*) and Roelandt Savery (47*), and the last word in elegance of line in Stefano della Bella (49, 50 a.* & b.) and Callot (52*, 53*); the two drawings by Guercino (64*,' see cover, and 65*), among the finest one can hope to find here or abroad; the rare Gillot (98 B*), Watteau's great teacher; Poussin's relaxed sketches (72 a.* & b. *); Paulus Potter's inconspicuous "Bull" (84*) which yet seems to state the artist's range of intention: the little Peter Stevens (88*), like most of the others never ex-

record.title: Page 03
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: hibited or published before; the charming watercolor of the "Mouse" (75*); the practically unknown Carl Wilhelm Kolbe (127*) whose oaks and river landscapes ushered in the "Storm and Stress" movement in German art; the two Menzels (145*, 146*) which will perhaps help in re¬ habilitating the name of that much mahgned "reahst"; the accomphshed Winslow Homer (142*)—and from there on down to the great number of carefully selected contempo¬ rary drawings of high rank (155-231). As for these latter, this show, possibly more than any other we have had in Iowa, will help to demonstrate the raison d'etre of Modern Art in its pivotal position as a great last summing up of the achievement of the Renaissance and as a pointer into an as yet unknown future. Those who had the privilege of helping in the assembling of this vast "Anthology of Drawings" cannot conclude this brief introduction without mentioning the self-effacing read¬ iness on the part of all lenders, helpers and advisers to communicate to the visitors of the Summer Show some of their own love and enthusiasm for drawings. William Sebastian Heckscher Department of Art State University of Iowa CATALOGUE Drawings are exhibited in the Art Building (Gallery) and in the Iowa Memorial Union (Lounge). Numbers attached to the drawings refer to the numbers under which they are listed in the Catalogi An asterisk ( *) means that the drawing is reproduced. All plain numbers are listed in numerical sequence at the end of the Catalogue. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Six centuries of master drawings, thirteenth annual Fine Arts Festival, summer 1951
record.description: "The Thirteenth Annual Festival of Fine Arts at the State University of Iowa presents as one of its major features the exhibition of ... historical and contemporary drawings. The exhibition has been chosen by Dr. Lester D. Longman, who selected the contemporary works, and Dr. William S. Heckscher, who is responsible for the historical section"--page 1.

record.full-text: SIXTEENTH ANNUAL FINE ARTS FESTIVAL kcH. an.Ji aw AMERICAN PAINTING IN THE 1930's AND 1950's State University of Iowa • School of Fine Arts June 13 to July 31, 1954 • Art Building and Iowa Memorial Union University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 03
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: The Fine Arfs Festival af the State University of Iowa, now in its six¬ teenth year, annually presents a major exhibition of art, exhibitions of paintings, sculpture, and prints by the Department of Art, plays in the University Theatre, symphony and choral concerts, an opera, and varied ensemble concerts and recitals by the Department of Music, a series of University lectures, special exhibits in the University Museum of Natural History, radio and television programs, and moving pictures and programs of recordings in the Iowa Memorial Union. For the Festival this year Dr. Lester D. Longman, Head of the Depart¬ ment or Art, has prepared the interesting and illuminating exhibition en¬ titled THEN AND NOW which is catalogued and interpreted In this publication. The University thanks Dr. Longman for assembling this exhibition. Pro¬ fessors Carroll Coleman and Dale Ballantyne for service in preparing this catalogue, and the numerous museums and galleries which loaned pictures for their kind cooperation and assistance. The paintings of the I930's are all from museum collections, but all paintings of the I950's are for sale. Prices may be obtained at the main office of the Art Building. Earl E. Harper Director, School of Fine Arts University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 04
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: FOREWORD University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 05
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: This exhibition has been designed to dramatize the contrast between American art in the I930's and I950's. The painters who represent the decade of the thirties are a majority of those who were at that time considered the leading progressive artists of the day. Those who represent the fifties are a major¬ ity of the leaders of the present advance-guard movement. The selection Is the result of consultations with several authori¬ ties: Mr. Lloyd Goodrich, Associate Director of the Whitney Museum, Mr. Andrew C. Ritchie, Director of the Department of Painting and Sculpture of the Museum of Modern Art, and Mr. James J. Sweeney, Director of the Solom.on R, Guggenheim Museum, Several artists are the choice of the writer alone; ail others are represented on the list of at least one other critic although not all the painters who were recommended could be Included, In spite of a few unavoidable omissions of such artists as Shahn, Levlne, Tobey, and Rothko, the exhibition gives a fair summary of what was considered the progressive art of two brief Intervals in American history. In the thirties there was a clearly recognized distinction be¬ tween conventional "Illustration" and a creative art character¬ ized by "formal values," Most of the painters represented In this exhibition were classed In the second of these categories, and hence they would have been Included In major cross-section shows of American art. On the other hand, esthetic values were obscured by much talk of the Independent value of top¬ ical themes, socially-conscious realism, local scene painting, regionalism, etc, and artists sought to arrive at a genuine American style by avoiding foreign Influences. All this died out abruptly with the coming of the second World War. The decade of the I940's was a period of rapid transition, as this exhibition amply demonstrates by omitting it altogether. The war and its aftermath encouraged cultural Internationalism In many ways. One instance of this was the emigration to the United States of many European artists who stimulated a better understanding of surrealism and abstraction, which until then had not been assimilated into the main stream of American art. By 1950, however, this had taken place, with the result that only an expert can recognize the differences between the avant- garde painters of the United States, France, England, Italy, and Western Germany. Everywhere the new art is now abstract and international in content. A small proportion of contemporary abstract painting Is geo¬ metric in form (c-f. 3 1), but most of It is expressionistic. The custom^ary designation Is "abstract expressionism," but those who are unimpressed call it "smear abstraction" or "metaphys¬ ical wallpaper." It Is not normally Intended to be decorative, at least on first acquaintance, but rather to express powerful or disturbing emotions which could only be paraphrased in mysti¬ cal or dadalstic language no more lucid than the Images them¬ selves. Technical competence, ability to represent, and tradi¬ tional principles of design have become purely optional, since they may or may not be useful to the artist. One judges the esthetic potential of a painting by the Intensity of Its emotional charge, which is directly proportionate to degree of originality University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 06
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: and contemporaneity. Like scientists, the artists make "discov¬ eries," and old art like old science loses its value. The painting of the thirties is out of date; that of the forties is old-fashioned. Objects are genuinely beautiful only as long as their originality remains spiritually contemporaneous; thereafter with the pas¬ sage of time they become beautiful in the popular sense and thus die. And anxiety among artists increases as, year by year, the life-span of new movements diminishes. Although critical attention today centers on abstract expres¬ sionism. It is also possible to attract favorable comment with the kind of meticulous, photographic renderings known as "magic realism." Doubtless a legacy of Dallnian surrealism, its present "contemporaneity" seems to consist In the surprising omission of all the fantastic imagery which once constituted its claim to originality (cf. 58 and 60). Nothing in between these extremes seems to appeal any longer to artists and critics who make a point of being up-to-date. On the other hand, a few painters of note, such as Willem de Kooning and Jackson Pollock, have recently begun to reintroduce a slight reference to recognizable representation, and their apologists are calling attention to it as a new virtue. Others are following their example. Perhaps it is a straw In the wind (cf. 41, 44, 47, and 54). Some who read these pages may not be aware that painting in Russia and its satellites is propagandistic and nationalistic in subject matter, and is realistic or naturalistic in style, like American "slick magazine" illustrations. It also resembles the painting of Nazi Germany, although the subjects naturally dif¬ fer. Communist art In Western Europe Is similar to that in Russia. We have no analogous art movement In the United States. Strangely enough, some uninformed Americans believe that abstract art is communistic, whereas the fact Is that It might be difficult at present for an American painter to return to some form of representational art without being suspected by connoisseurs of totalitarian sympathies. The cost and danger of transporting heavy or fragile ob¬ jects made it impossible to include sculpture In the current exhibition. Nevertheless, the visitor may see twenty examples from the 1930's and twenty-five from the I950's by means of three-dimensional color slides installed In the main gallery of the Art Building. These were made by the writer in New York at the Museum of Modern Art, the Metropolitan Museum, the Whitney Museum, and several sales galleries. The fourteen sculptors representing the thirties and the eleven representing latest developments are among the leading artists of the two periods and were chosen In the same way the painters were selected. It will be observed that the earlier sculptures are all representational and characterized by closed forms and solid volumes. They are ordinarily carved in stone or wood or cast in bronze. The recent ones, on the contrary, are expression¬ istic, open in form, lacking In large, solid volumes, and usually made of metal welded into striking or intricate abstract con¬ figurations. Lester D. Longman University of Iowa Libraries

record.full-text: THE FOURTH SUMMER EXHIBITION OF CONTEMPORARY ART is presented as a major feature of the Tenth Annual Fine Arts Festival at the State University of Iowa. In addition to this exhibition the Festival presents a full program of plays in the University Theatre; symphony, chamber music, choral and band concerts in the Iowa Union; and exhibitions of painting, sculpture, and prints by faculty members and students in the Art Building. The administrative plan of the Iowa Summer Show has been abundantly justified by the widespread interest, not only of the University public, but of artists, critics, and art educators throughout the nation. The established pattern has been followed again this year with slight variations. Dr. Lester D. Longman, Head of the Depart¬ ment of Art, selected the paintings and once again he has written a foreword which constitutes an important statement upon the subject of contemporary painting. The following committee of judges will choose twelve paintings from which the University will make purchases according to its available means: Daniel S. Defen- bacher, Max Weber, Lester D. Longman. The purchases made by the University will be announced during the month of July. The University thanks those who have made loans to the exhibition and is grateful to the following galleries in New York City for their cooperation: A. C. A., 61 E. 57+h St. Macbeth, I I E. 57th St. The Artists Gallery. 61 E. 57th St. Matisse, 41 E. 57th St. Associated American Artists, 711 5th Ave Midtown, 605 Madison Ave. Babcock, 38 E. 57th St. Milch, 55 E. 57th St. Buchholz, 32 E. 57th St. Niveau, 63 E. 57th St. Chinese, 38 E. 57th St. Norlyst, 59 W. 56th St. Contemporary Arts Inc., 106 E. 57th St. Parsons, 15 E. 57th St. Downtown, 32 E. 51st St. Passedoit, 121 E. 57th St. Durand-Ruel, 12 E. 57th St. Perls, 32 E. 58th St. Durlacher, I I E. 57th St. Rehn, 683 Fifth Ave. Grand Central, 55 E. 57th St. Rosenberg, 16 E. 57th St. Knoedler, 14 E. 57th St. Salpeter, 128 E. 56th St. Kootz, 15 E. 57th St. Schaefer, 32 E. 57th St. Kraushaar, 32 E. 57th St. Weyhe, 794 Lexington Ave. Levitt, 16 W. 57th St. Willard, 32 E. 57th St. Levy, 42 E. 57th St. The cover and frontispiece of this catalogue were designed by Dale Ballantyne. Most of the paintings are for sale and while purchases must be made directly from the galleries or artists, price lists are available in the exhibition galleries. EARL E. HARPER Director, School of Fine Arts

record.title: Page 04

record.full-text: FOREWORD After a war victorious countries often become more conservative for a time. Hence, it is not surprising that during the past year liberal opinion In the arts has been on the defensive and preoccupied with self-analysis. Issues are sharply drawn. Cru¬ saders for freedom and adventure consider themselves "experimental"—their oppo¬ nents "reactionary." The exponents of order and security consider themselves "sane" —their opponents "radical." A wise counsel would preserve the values of freedom of expression, however, and at this juncture a new plea for tolerance of what one dislikes and fears seems to be in order. Tolerance combats prejudice, but does not require one to sacrifice his right to judge, or imply that everything shall be considered equally worthy of attention. It does not obligate the museum to hang everything with "democratic" regard to the proportion of kinds of work produced. Such a chaos of freedom without order entails confusion and cultural anarchy. The museum should accept the responsibilities of its judicial function, choose with discrimination, and publicly defend its judgment, taking the utmost care not to thwart progress, for example by refusing to hang what the public cannot easily understand. The museum is an educational institution. This responsibility for judicial appraisal is not a license to dictate. The critic can¬ not "enjoin" artists to behave in some approved fashion without Impairing freedom and adventure. It may be difficult to define the watershed between criticism and dogma, but we are not likely to err if we remember that judges are not preachers, and that the enforcement of "sane" doctrine, however benevolent In method and Intention, freezes Individual initiative and produces claustrophobia rather than nour¬ ishment of the creative spirit. The defense of judgment should be conducted by museums and critics on a high level of discussion, avoiding the popular terms of partisan polemics. For instance, every responsible critic knows that there is no deliberate "cult of bewilderment" In modern art, but only bewildered people. Therefore, the loose use of such a phrase, perhaps to refer to a frequent preoccupation with the enigmatic, merely confuses the serious student and gives unintended comfort to dogmatic reactionaries. This Is par¬ ticularly Important now, since much of the recent criticism of what the public calls "modern art" comes from within the ranks of progressive critics, who seem to be engaged in an effort at reappraisal. Friends of "modern art" seem uneasy, caught in the uncomfortable quandaries which characterize the predicament of the genuine liberal today, who has a readier talent to Identify the cancerous condition of society than to initiate successful remedies. The progressive artist has long fostered a trenchant art of rejection, of negation, of disillusionment, cynicism, and morbid despair, exquisite documents indicting a neurotic society. For years he has pointed the finger at evil and social injustice, at bigotry, exploitation, and stupidity. Now it seems that his impotence, the homeless- ness of his cause, is producing an attitude of complete futility. He Is sapped of his power to resist, his will to satire, as both left and right close in upon him. Satiated with the fight for social reform, he surveys with resignation the running sores In the University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 05
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: diseased tissue of society, and becomes preoccupied merely with the evidences of pathology in the minds of men. The ambition of the young progressive artist and the scope of his effort are also drugged and emasculated by his emotional retreat, his loss of boldness and vigor. He avoids any preoccupation with the implications of a subject, for a "subject pic¬ ture" is as hard to do well as it is easy to do badly. Instead, he escapes into intro¬ spection and is beguiled and gratified with charming essays in human sensibility, graceful lyrics In pure form, highly charged emotive fragments. Often they are original and ingratiating, but at times the content is so slight that one cannot remem¬ ber whether he has seen a given picture before or not. This creeping paralysis of will, this weariness and sense of defeat also drain him of his creative powers. As a result many "experimenlar' artists now seek, but do not find. Recent years have been characterized less by discovery than by dissemination. The multiplication of converts in all parts of our country has fortunately led to a wide acceptance of abstraction and surrealism, but it has also produced dilution, dull re¬ iteration, opportunistic mannerism, a fashionable mediocrity which still masquerades as a frontier of experiment. There appear to be no more surprises for the informed. The more honest the artist in his desire for progress the more disturbed he will be that his own weakness adds fuel to the malevolent attacks of reactionaries. The world is still infected with injustice, violence, and neuroticism, of which the reflection is bound to appear in both the form and content of any art which merits his attention. Perhaps he cannot be content to point, but will have to engage the enemies of social welfare with weapons of improved design and higher caliber, involving some con¬ structive and practical ideas. A conscientious reappraisal of his articles of faith may reveal new frontiers of esthetic experiment against which attack may be more success¬ ful and discovery more rewarding. Each artist must find his own direction, since there is no single right answer to the problem, no categorical imperative inherent in the nature of current events. Nevertheless, one avenue which promises results to the more ambitious and youthful pioneers, is that which leads toward synthesis rather than fragmentation and analysis, toward a consolidation of the discoveries of the numerous explorers of our century in an art of more monumental, more epic proportions, as though modern art were to be led out of its primitive stage and into the developed period of a new historic cycle. Many experimentalists may be too old now to change their mental habits so radically. If so, this is not their solution. To the most inflexible it will be indisttnguish- able from reaction. By some Spenglerian rationalization it may be argued that in our tortured and grotesque society no painter can presume to speak in epic language, and no effort at synthesis could succeed. Yet it can be expected today in architecture and city planning. Every important achievement seems difficult or impossible before It is done, and it remains "impossible" if no one tries it. Shall painters be dismayed and put to route by a rationalization which presumes categorically to define the realm of the possible? One suspects that the floundering liberal will develop a resonant voice when he gets an important idea. LESTER D. LONGMAN ¦sity of Iowa Libraries

record.full-text: The combined art collection of the Nebraska Art Association and the University of Nebraska is outstanding among University col¬ lections in the United States. This permanent exhibition of art masterpieces originated in 1888 when the Haydon Art Club was organized in Lincoln, Nebraska. This organization was incorporated as the Nebraska Art Associa¬ tion in 1900. Each year since 1888 the Nebraska Art Association has purchased a picture for its collection and financed an exhibition of contem¬ porary art at the University of Nebraska. In 1928 Mr. and Mrs. F. M. Hall left their personal art collection to the University together with a generous fund for further pur¬ chases. It has been required since 1928 that each picture pur¬ chased be chosen by a committee consisting of the head of the fine arts department of the University and two nationally known art critics. As a result of this policy the quality and significance of the purchases made during the last dozen years have been especially noteworthy. The University of Iowa acknowledges with gratitude the generous cooperation of the University of Nebraska and the Nebraska Art Association in making available for the Second Annual Fine Arts Festival forty-five pictures representative of the highest standards of achievement of American art. University of Iowa Libraries

record.full-text: The Damnation of Faust (Translation used in the edition of G. Scliirmer, Edited by Dr. Leopold Damrosch) Part I (Plains of Hungary, Sunrise) FAUST (alone in the fields) The winter has departed, spring is here! River and brook again are Ilowing free. Behold, from the dome of heaven pouring forth. Fresh splendor breaks and gladness ev'ry- where. I greet with joy the cool, reviving breath of morning. I drink lull draughts of soft, delicious balsam, I hear the birds awake, midst the weeds, Tlie low, deep murmuring o£ waves and ^vater-reeds. O joy, to dwell (vilhin tlie lonely forest. Far from the crowded world and all its striving! PEASANTS fhe shej^herd donned his best array. With a jacket and ribbons gay. Oh, but he was fine to see! The circle closed round the linden-tree. .\11 danced and sprang—like madmen danced a\vay. Hurrah, huzza, huzza, huzza! Tra la la la! Ho! Ho! The fiddle bows went merrily. (Dance of peasants under the linden-tree) PEASANTS But nimbly speeds it in the ring. Right and left they dance and swing; Skirts are flying as tliey skip. They all grow red, they all grow warm. Take breath a moment, arm in arm. Hurrah, hurrah, huzza, huzza! Tra la la la! Ho! Ho! FAUST What mean these cries, these song^, that dis¬ tant noise? It is the village folk at early dawn. Who dance and sing upon the grassy lawn. My darkened soul begrudges them their joys. FAUST A splendor of weapons is brightly gleaming afar! Ha! the sons of the Danube, apparelled for war; They gallop so proudly along; "Be not familiar," then she cried; "Many men deceive their bride; Ah, how many have cheated and have liedl" But he persuaded her aside! And echoed from the linden-tree The shouting and the fiddles. Hurrah, hurrah, huzza, huzza! Tra la la la! Ho! Ho! (Another part of the plain: an army advancing) Ho(v sparkle their eyes, how flash their shields! All hearts are thrilled, they chant their battle story. My heart alone is cold, all inimov'd e'en by glory. (The army passes by, Faust withdraios) HUNGARIAN MARCH Part II (North Germany) FAUST (alone in his study) Without regret I left the smiling iireadows. Where grief pui'sued me still. And without delight I now greet our haughty mountains; To iny home I return, still is sorrow my guest. .'\h, I suffer! I suffer! Starless night. Spreading far her silence and her shades, Adds another sorrow to my troubled heart. For me alone, O Earth, thou hast no flowers. Where shall I find that ^vhich my soul desires? Vainly I seek; it flies my eager quest! Enough, we'll make an end. But I tremble! Why tremble thus at the abyss that before me yawns? O cup, too long denied to my most ardent ivishes! Come, vial, from thy shelf. I the poison will drain Which must give me new light, or for aye end my ivoes! (He lifts the cup to his lips—A sound of bells—An Easter hymn is heard from a neighboring church) CHOIR Christ is risen from the dead! University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 22
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: The gloomy abode Of decay forsaking. To the Heavenly gales Transfigmed He moinits; Whilst to endless joys celestial He swiftly is borne up on high. We His loving children .Are left to languish here below. Alas! on this earth He hath left us Doomed this life's sad burden to bear. Hosanna! O heav'niy Master! Thy bliss hath brought us affliction and sorrow. Thou hast left us, doomed this life's sad binden to bear. But let us trust in His word everlasting. We shall soon follow Him To the heavenly mansions to which He hath call'd us. Hosanna! Hosanna! FAUST O, my memories! Oh, my poor trembling spirit, wilt thou Ascend to heav'n, borne up by holy songs? My tottering faith revives, recalling all my peaceful infancy. My happy boyhood, the blessedness of prayer. How pine was my enjoyment to wander. All wrapt in thought, through the verdant meadows. In the glorious light of the vernal sun! Memory holds me noiv with childish feeling Back from the last, the fatal step. Alas! Heav'niy tones, why seek me in the dust? NVhy visit the accursed? S\v'eet hymns of devotion. Why come and conquer thus suddenly my stubborn will? Your soft melodious strains bring peace to my soul; Songs more sweet than morning I hear again! My tears spring forth, the earth has won me back. MEPHISTOPHELES (suddenly appearing) O pious frame of mind! Again you tinn to Heaven. You once more are content. This glad Easter song, these joyful singing voices, Have charmed to peace again your troubled earthly brain. FAUST And who art thou whose glances so fierce. Even as a poniard, my marro\v transpierce. And burn like a flame my spirit? Speak, tell me thy name! MEPHISTOPHELES .Ah, for a Doctor llie question seems [li| pant, I am your friend and comfort, I will en yom' sorrow! I'll give you all you wish, wealth and fara ijoundle.ss joy, Whate'er the wildest dreams yoiu' raort l)rain can know. FAUST Tis well, wretched demon, I wait; let n hear. MEPHISTOPHELES Hark! I will once again arouse thine agii senses. Be binied no more, like the burrowin worms that gnaw at thy books. Come! Ari.se! Follow me! FAUST Be it so. MEPHISTOPHELES Let us go! Thou shalt study the world And leave thy den, leave thy hateful studj (They disappear in the Air) (Auerbach's Cellar in Leipzig) STUDENTS .Another glass of Rhenish wine! MEPHISTOPHELES Here, Faust, l)ehold a jolly set of fellows. Who with wine and song make merry ; night. STUDENTS 0 what delight When storm is crashing To sit all night Round the bowl, High in the glass the liquor flashing. While thick clouds of smoke float arounc When 1 was born and saw the sunlight, 1 could not stand upon my legs. I came fortli to the earth and staggered; Drinking was then my only thought. SOME STUDENTS AVho knows a lively song to give us? Nought like mirth to give zest to wine. Now, Brander, thou! OTHERS He forgets all his ballads. BRANDER Nay, I know one, I made it myself! .STUDENTS Let us all listen! BRANDER Since you invite me, I'll give you at once something new. STUDENTS Bravo, Bravo! University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 23
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: mad, BRANDER There was a rat in the cellar nest. Whom fat and butter made smoother; He had a paunch beneath his vest Like that of Dr. Luther. The cook laid poison cunnnigly. And then as sore oppressed was he, As if he had love in his bosom. He ran around, he ran about. His thirst in puddles laving; He gnawed and scratched the house through¬ out. But nothing cured his raving. He whirled and jumped, with torment And soon enough the poor beast had, .As if he had love in his bosom. .And driven at last, in open day, He ran into the kitchen. Fell on the hearth and squirming lay, In the last convulsion twitching. Then laughed the niinderess in her glee: "Ha! ha! he's at his last gasp," said she, "As if he had love in his bosom." STUDENTS ,\s if he had love in his bosom. Retiuiescat in pace! Amen! BRANDER .And now sing a fugue; To the Amen a fugue; Let's improvise now a scholarly piece! MEPHISTOPHELES Take notice now, their bestiality will show itself, ere long, in ils true colors. STUDENTS .Amen! Amen! (Tliey sing a fugue on the melody of Brander's song) MEPHISTOPHELES (advancing) By heavens, sirs, your fugue is splendid! To hear it is to dream one is in some holy place. Pray, let me freely say it: 'tis scholarly in style; devout, thoroughly so; One could not better express the pious senti¬ ments which, in closing all her petitions, Holy Chinch sums up in this one word. In my turn, I will respond, by your leave, with a song on a no less pathetic theme than yours, sirs. .STUDENTS Ah, he dares to mock us to our face? Who is this fellow? How pale and ghastly! Who ever saw hair so red? No matter. Well, go on! Give us thy song! IJcgin! Begin! MEPHISTOPHELES Reigning in ro)al splendor .A king had raised a flea. As flesh and blood he loved him. His dearest kin was he. The monarch called his tailor And let him know his wants. He said, "I want my flea ivell dressed. So measure him for j^ants." He wore the finest velvet, .And silks of colors bright. The)' gave him highest orders, •And made him a noble knighl. He had a star of jewels .As minister of state. His relatives were favored At court they all were great. The courtiers and the ladies From bites were very sore. The queen and her attendants Could l)ear the pests no more. They dared not even scratch them. They scarce could bear their plight, \\'hile we can crack and kill them At once whene'er they bite. STUDENTS (shouting) Bravo, bravo, bravissimo! Ha! Ha! We crack them and \ve crush them At once, whene'er they bite. FAUST (to Mepliislopheles) Enough! let's quit at once this company so brutal, AVith joys degrading and ignoble deeds. Hast thou no piner pleasines, no calmer sports To offer me, thou dread, infernal guide? MEPHISTOPHELES This is not to thy taste? Come on! (They spread their mantle, and take flight) (Bushy meadoius on the banks of the Elbe) MEPHISTOPHELES In this fair bower, Fragrant with many a flower. On this sweet-scented bed. Dearest Faust, lay thy head. And slumber, soothed by voluptuous repose. Whilst fragrant roses on thy fever'd brow shall breathe. Their blossoms W'reathe, Thine ear shall music. Oh, hearken! Dost hear earth and of air E'en now lo lull lliy slumber with sweet str.ihis begin. unfolding, thy pillow to be ravished with heavenly it? The spirits of (Faust's Vision) University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 24
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: SYLPHS AND GNOMES WITH MEPHI¬ STOPHELES Sleep, happy Faust! Ere long, 'neath curtains of azure and gold, Thou shalt close thine eyes in slumber deep. Bright in the sky thy star now is gleaming, Siv'eet dreams of love shall enrapture thy soul. With forms of beauty rare Now clothes itself the landscape, .\ vision fair unfolding Of tlow'ry groves and meads .And pleasant leafy bowers Where tender lovers meet. Their ardent vows exchanging. Beyond are seen the vines. Their branches thickly cover'd With tender shoots and leaves And fruit in pinple clusters. See yonder loving pair, .Along the winding valley; They take no note of time. Beneath the shady bow'ers .A fair one follows them In meditation litpt; Beneath her lashes gleams .A solitary tear. Faust, this beauteous one Ere long thy love shall be. MEPHISTOPHELES See her with magic charms; Faust, she shall be thy love! FAUST (dreaming) O Marguerite! SYLPHS AND GNOMES AND MEPHI¬ STOPHELES Extended lies the mere, All along the green hillsides; Bright the sunbeams are shining On its mirror so clear. Here with laughter and singing Its border loud resound— Ha! There to music of viols The merry dance goes round; AVhile some are boldly climbing The rugged mountain side- Hal Others are lightly swimming Upon the glassy tide. Happy all seem and tireless Seeking one common end This bright existence To the full to enjoy. To all is given the siuishine. Thy darling shall make thee in love with life again. All pleasures, like the sunshine. Come to all from above. Y'et of raptures the sweetest. The siveetest of all O Faust, is love! Sleep! Sleep! Happy Faust! Sleep! Sleep! FAUST 0 Marguerite! MEPHISTOPHELES He sleeps! \ve}\ done, my dainty elves. This debt I must repay! Now let him dream of love. DANCE OF SYLPHS (The spirits of the air hover aiuhile roun, the slumbering Faust, then gradually dit appear) FAUST (suddenly awaking) Marguerite! .... What a dream! ^Vhat a celestial image! What angel in human form! Where dwelles thou? 1 feel the pmest bliss, since I dreamt of the( O angel! MEPHISTOPHELES .Arise and follo\v me again. To the modest chamber I'll bring thee; Where she thy mistress sleeps. Of thy dream thou shalt see the truth! Here comes a jolly j^arty of students an soldiers! They'll pass before thy beauty's dwelling. .Along with these young fools, With their loud shouts and songs. We to the fair one's house will go. But thy raptures restrain. Hark, and lear to obey. (Students and Soldiers marching toward th town) SOLDIERS Stoutly walled cities we fain would win, .And maidens ^vith lofty and with scornti mien. Though daring the venture, yet rich is th prize. The tnnnpets are sounded with powerh breath. They smnmon to glory, they summon I death. We rush into action nor quit we the field Till both maidens and towns to us then sehes yield. STUDENTS Jam no.x stellata velamina pandit; Nunc bibendum et amandum est. Vita brevis fugaxque voluptas, Gaudeamus igitur. Nobis subridente luna. Per urbem quarerentes jDuellas eamuj Ut eras fortunati Caesares dicamus Veni, vidi, vici. i University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 25
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: Part III (Evening. Drums and trumpets in the dis¬ tance) F.AUST (in Marguerite's chamber) I'hou sweet twilight, be welcome! Thee greet I from my heart. Thou softly fill'st this place to chaste repose set apart, \Vherein I feel a vision kiss my fever'd brow, Like the balmy breath of early morning. .Ah, 'tis love, surely love inspires me. Oh', how I feel my cares take wings and fly away! How dear to me this silence, how joyously I breathe this pure air! Lovliest maiden, my sweet enslaver! How I love thee, O earthly angel! What awful joy this moment swells my heart! With what ecstasy I gaze on thy maidenly couch! How sweet the air of this chamber! 0 God, after long years of torture, what joy is mine! MEPHISTOPHELES (entering) 1 hear her coming! Conceal thyself behind these curtains. FAUST Ah! My heart will break for very joy. (Mephistopheles hides Faust) MEPHISTOPHELES Now make the most of lime. Farewell. Thyself reslrain, or thou shalt lose her! Good! my sprites and I now shall shig tor you The sweetest wedding ditties. FAUST Calm thee, my heart, be quiet. (Enter Marguerite icith a lamp. Faust con¬ cealed) MARGUERITE How sultry is the air! I tremble like a child. 'Tis my dream last night which fills my heart with sadness. I saw him in my dream, my predestined love. Hoiv handsome he was! O ho^v tender was his love! How dearly he loved me, and how dearly I loved him! And shall we ever meet upon this earth? What folly! (She sings while undressing) *There was a king in Thule, ^Vas faithful till the grave. To ivhom his mistress, dying, .A golden goblet gave. Nought was to him more precious. He drained it at every bout; His eyes ^vith tears ran over As oft as he drank thereout. When came his time of dying The towns in his land he told. Nought else to his heir denying Except the goblet of gold. He sat at the royal banquet With his knights of high degree In the lofty hall of his fathers. In the castle by the sea. There stood the old carouser. And drank the hist life-glow, .And hurled the hallow'd goblet Into the tide below. He saw it plunging and filling And sinking deep in the sea. Then his eyelids fell forever, .And nevermore drank he. There was a king once In Thule, Faithful was he To the grave— Ah! (Square before Marguerite's house) MEPHISTOPHELES (Invocation) Ye spirits of flickering flame, Hither come! Haste! I need your aid. Quick appear, quick appear! Y'e will-o'-the-wisps, your baneful and treach'rous glimmers Must bewilder a maid, and lead her unto us. In the name of the devil, get you dancing! Take care no\v, ye fiddlers of hell. To mark the measure well, or I will blow you out! MINUET MEPHISTOPHELES AND WILL-O'-THE- WISPS Come on! We'll strike up a moral song, This damsel's ear to tickle. The more surely to beguile her heart. (Serenade) \\'hy dost thou wait at the door of thy lover. My foolish Kate, in the gray of the morning? A\'hy dost wait, foolish Kate, foolish Kate? •Berlioz adds this direction to tlie Song "Le Rol de Thule" in his score "Eight Scenes from Faust": "In her rendering of tlie ballad tlie singer must not strive to vary the expression of the song in accordance with the different nuances of the poem; on the contrary, she should endeavor to render it as uniformly as possible. It is evident tliat the very last person that concerns Mar¬ guerite in this moment is the King of Thule, and his woes; for her it is simply an old tale that she heard in childliood, and wliich she now absently hums," University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 26
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: O beware, nor enter there! Trust his fair speeches ne\er; Men deceivers were ever, .And love is but a snare. Maiden, take heed! Lose no time here in sighing. Reck ;vell my rede; Shun the danger by flying. O take heed, foolish Kate, O lake heed! Ha! MEPHISTOPHELES Ssh! Now disappear! (Will-o'-the-wisps vanish) Keep silence! Let us list to the cooing of our doves. MARGUERITE (seeing Faust) 0 God! 'iVhat do I see? Can it be he? Can I believe mine eyes? FAUST .Angel ador'd, whose dear and lovely image. While yet I had not known thee, illumined my dark soul! .At last I thee behold, and o'er the jealous cloud-veil ^\'hich hid thee from my sight, my love the \'ict'ry hath won. Margarita, I love thee. MARGUERITE Thou knowest my name, and I too Have often whispeied thine—Faust! FAUST (timidly) That name is mine; But I will take another if it please thee better. MARGUERITE In dreams I thee have seen, such as I see thee now. FAUST Hast seen me in thy dreams? MARGUERITE 1 know thy \'oice, thy face, thy sweet and winning speech. FAUST Dost lo\'e me truly? MARGUERITE .Ah, for thee I longed. FAUST Margarita, I love thee! MARGUERITE My tender love was thine by inspiration. FAUST Margarita is mine! MARGUERITE O dearest love, thy sweet and noble image, ^V'hile yet I had not known thee, shone brightly in my soul. At last I thee behold, and o'er the jealoi cloud-veil \Vhich hid thee from my sight, thy love H vicl'ry hath won. FAUST Thou art mine! Dearest maid, svveetest treasure! To my love ivithotit measure ^'iekl thee now, I implore! For thy embrace my heart fondly yearnetl Come! O come! Sweet love! Come! MARGUERITE What transports of pleasure To his arms me impel! Born of love without measure! \\'hat gentle languor seizes my whole beiiij In my eves are tears! all is darkness! I taint! Ah! I die! MEPHISTOPHELES (entering abruptly) .Away! It is loo late! MARGUERITE Who is that man? FAUST .A brute! MEPHISTOPHELES Nay! a friend! MARGUERITE .Ah! his glance with horror freezes my blooi MEPHISTOPHELES No doubt I am intruding. FAUST Who bade thee enter here? MEPHISTOPHELES 1 came lo save this angel. E'en now the neighbors all, awakened b our songs. They come, chattering villains, and poin out the house. .At Margaret they are scoffing, and they ca for her mother. The dame will soon be here. FAUST O terror! MEPHISTOPHELES We must be off! FAUST Death and Hell! MEPHISTOPHELES Soon shall you meet again! Consolation is near. It follo\vs close upon sorroi\'. MARGUERITE Then farewell, dearest lovcl W'c shall mec on the morrow. Now tarry not, they come! University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 27
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: FAUST Farewell, then, blissful night U'hich scarcely has begun! Farewell, rich feast of love. Which I had hoped to taste! MEPHISTOPHELES "ome on! The morning dawns. FAUST Wilt thou no more return, Hour of rapture loo fleeting. In which my soul, erst plunged in grief. To joy at length awoke? CHORUS OF NEIGHBORS Holla, Dame Oppenheim! 5ee what your daughter's doing! Fhe warning's not one whit too soon. There's a lover now in )our house, And you and all yours ere long will get into trouble! Holla! Holla! MEPHISTOPHELES The crowd is coming. Let us hasten away! MARGUERITE O Heav'n! Dost hear their foul jibes? If thou be fotnid with me. My life they'll surely take. Farewell, make thy escape garden gate! FAUST O despair! O my angel, fare thee well! MEPHISTOPHELES Come, 'tis time to be going. O what folly! Quick away! FAUST Now do I know, at last, all the joy of existence. Hajjpiness, thou dost smile upon me, Call'st me to thee, and I come. At last thou art mine! Lo\e a ne'er dying flame in my bosom hath kindled Of my consuming love soon shall I taste the joy. MARGUERITE Dearest Faust, unto thee I give my whole self. Love a ne'er dying flame in my bosom hath kindled. O my heart's joy! My sole treasure! To lose thee were to die. MEPHISTOPHELES Thus I drag thee around at my pleasure. Haughty Faust! Lo, the hour approaches In which thou shalt be mine. Slave of lo\'e, whose joys thou ne'er shalt taste. In hell thy fierce desires shall inflame and torment thee. through the NEIGHBORS There's a lover now in your house! .And mark ye well! ere long he'll get ye all in trouble! Holla! Dame Oppenheim! See vv'hat your daughter's doing! Holla! Ha! Ha! Ha! Ha! Holla, Dame Ojipenheim! Holla! INTERMISSION Part IV MARGUERITE (alone in her chamber) O, to hold him thus forever. My heart with grief is heavy. My peace of mind is o'er! Ne'er again shall I find it! Ah, never more! Where my love is not vvith me Is to me as the tomb, My life ^vithout his presence All shrouded is in gloom! My brain, so sore bewilder'd. Hath no pow'r of thought, My dull and feeble senses .Are entirely distraught. I look out at the casement. His fine, tall form to see: To meet him and be ivith him Is heaven's own joy to me. His proud and noble bearing, or his smile the winning grace. Of his hand the soft pressure,— And ah, his fond embrace! .All day long, to be near him Fondly yearns my poor heart: .Ah, could I tightly clasp him, I would ne'er let him part. All glowing with love's fire. And on his lips still hanging, I'd fain with one long kiss exjiire! (Drums and trumpets sound a retreat: Soldiers and Students singing in the distance) SOLDIERS The trumpets are breath; They summon to death. sounded with powerful glory, they summon to MARGUERITE Day's reign will soon be ended. Dusky tivilight apjjroaches. SOLDIERS Though daring the venture yet rich is the prize! MARGUERITE Afar the evening drums and trumpets now are sounding, With songs and shouts of joy, .As on that blessed evening when first I saw Faust. University of Iowa Libraries

Invocation to Nature) FAUST (al07ie) 0 boundless nature, spirit sublime, mys¬ terious! Alone thou givest comfort to my unhappy soul. On thy breast, mighty power, is my sorrow abated; .And, my strength renewing, I seem to live again: Blow, ye fierce, howling winds! Cry out, ye boundless forests! Fall down, ye rocks! And roar, ye mountain streams, wildly rushing. With your thundering sounds my voice loves to unite. Ye rocks and streams and woods, accept my homage. Bright, sparkling worlds above, towards you leaps forth the piteous cry Of a heart in anguish, of a soul madly longing, vainly striving for joy!
