record.full-text: PROGRAM Symphony No. 4, in E minor, opus 98 Brahms Allegro non troppo Andante moderato Allegro giocoso Allegro energico e passionato Intermission Tone Poem, The Great Stone Face* Leon Karel Tone Poem, Ibycus and the Cranes* Jewel Peterson Prelude, Scherzo, and Passacaglia" • Wendell Otey (With piano obbligato) ••' first performance PROGRAM NOTES Symphony No. 4, in E minor, opus 98 Johannes Brahms This symphony, tlie last composition in this form given to the world by Brahms, was composed in the summers of 1884 and 1885. The symphony is highly regular in its ireatnient of tlie forms used in the several movements, although the passacaglia, which Brahms employed for the finale, has been more frequently employed by other composers outside of the symphony. A later paragraph deals with the history and structure of the passacaglia. Tone Poem, The Great Stone Face Leon Karel Mr. Karel was born February 28, 1919, in Riverside, Iowa. After preliminary training in the public schools of Washington, loiva, and Riverside, and mem¬ bership in the .-Vll-State High School music organizations at Iowa City during the summers of 1935 and 1936, he entered the University of Iowa, and in June, 1940, he received the B.Mus. degree, with a major in musical composition. The composition performed this e\ening ^vas offered as his final thesis tor his degree. Hawthorne's short story, "The Great Stone Face," was undoubtedly sug¬ gested to Haivthorne by a rock formation near Franconia, New Hampshire, which from a distance resembles a colossal human face. In Hawthorne's story the Great Stone Face appears as a symbol of the eternity, omniscience, and benevolence of the Creator: the boy Ernest, who passes his humble life under the shadow of the Great Stone Face, yearns for the fulfillment of an ancient prophecy, that when a man shall arise whose own face resembles the Great Stone Face, he shall bring great hapjjiness to the people of the region; in turn a rich man, a soldier, and a stateman are for a time believed to embody the features of the Great Stone Face, but are toinid to lack the beneficent powers which had been anticipated, until a poet has the discernment to point out that Ernest himself has grown into the likeness of the Great Stone Face. Mr. Karel's composition does not attempt to reproduce the story event by event; but the prevailing mood is suggested by the tranquil majesty of the Great Stone Face and there are suggestions for contrast of the other principal characters in the story. Tone Poem, Ibycus and the Cranes Jewel Peterson Miss Peterson wa% born in Fosloria, Iowa, .^fter receiving her B.A. degree from Augustana College (Sioux Falls, South Dakota), cum laude, in 1929, and her M.A. degree from the State University of Iowa in 1930, she taught in Central University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 43
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: College (Pella, Iowa) from 1930-1937, returning to the State University of Iowa as research assistant while studying for the degree of Master of Fine .\rts in composition, receiving this degree in 1940 as the first candidate offered by the Department of Music. Her compositions include another orchestral composi¬ tion, several songs and part-songs, and more extensive compositions for piano in large and small form. The present composition ^vas offered as her thesis for the M.F.A. degree. The story of Ibycus and the Cranes is a Greek myth of some antiquity; a quaint English version, too long for quotation here, may be found in Bulfinch's "Mythology." Ibycus is represented as a pious poet, whose benevolence ex¬ tended prayer aiitl good wishes toward some cranes circling over his head as he approached Corinth, where he had jjlanned to attend the chariot races and musical competitions. .Attacked and murdered by thieves, he called upon the cranes to avenge him. His body ^vas found, Ijut his murderers were not identi¬ fied until the cranes, circling o\er the assembly at Corinth, provoked the un¬ guarded outcry of one of his murderers, "These are the cranes of Ibycus." The music closely follows the details of this story; a woodwind figure suggested by the cry of the cranes, ser\es as a leading motive in the development of both the story and the music. Prelude, Scherzo, and Passacaglia Wendell Otey (With piano obbligato) Dr. Otey was born .August 10, 1914, in Harrisbing, Illinois. He received the B.Ed, degree from Southern Illinois Stale Teachers College (Carbondale, Illi¬ nois) in 1935, the M.A. degree from the Stale University of Iowa in 1936, and the Ph.D. degree from the State Uni\'ersit)' of Iowa in 1939. After holding several teaching positions. Dr. Otey is at present a member of the music faculty at the University of Pittsburgh, and is a guest member of the music faculty of the State University of Iowa during the summer of 1940. His compositions in¬ clude Ten Miniature Variations on an Original Theme (performed by the University of Iowa Symphony Orchestra, March 5, 1939), a quintet for piano and strings, sonatas for violin and |3iano, several sets of variations for different instrumental combinations, songs and part-songs, and many works for piano. The conijjosition played this evening was offered as a thesis for the Ph.D. degree. The Prelude and Scherzo serve as an introduction to the Passacaglia itself, w'hich is a series of twenty-eight \'ariations on a sixteen-measure theme employ¬ ing motives previously hinted at in the two preceding movements but not bound together in a complete presentation until tlie opening of the Passacaglia. The piano is employed less as a solo instrument than as a prominent instrument in a large orchestra. A NOTE ON THE PASSACAGLIA Since tivo passacaglias are presented on this evening's program, a word con¬ cerning this musical form is appropriate. The laassacaglia is one of the pre¬ cursors of the modern variation form; but the variations are built not upon a melody but upon a bass figure of four, eight, or sixteen measures. In the earlier passacaglias this bass was literally repeated throughout all variations, though new melodies and harnionies might be constructed above it in each variation in turn; modern procedure in treating this form, as in treating most traditional forms, has tended away from strictly literal repetitions throughout the entire development, and in both the passacaglias played this evening the initial "ground bass," after several literal repetitions passes into the inner voices of the harmony, and eventually becomes the starting point of many derivatives without literal quotation. Traditionally the passacaglia is cast in a broad triple rhythm, and its development is worked out by rhythmic and harmonic elaboration, rather than by any considerable change of pace; this tradition originated in very early days, when the passacaglia was known as a solemn ceremonial dance many centuries before its employment as a concert form. University of Iowa Libraries

record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: 1 Probably the most famous passacaglia is that in C minor for organ by Johann Sebastian Bach, which has been transcribed for the modern orchestra by-Leopold Stokowski, Frederick Stock, and others; but, while the passacaglia is an "old" form, many composers from the time of Bach to the present have composed in this form, although iew of them have placed a passacaglia in a symphony such as Brahms has clone in his Fourth Symphony. record.full-text: '». ^ ¦^^^^^K ^^K^^^^B IOWA MEMORIAL UNION JEAN CHARLOT FREDERIC McCONNELL c ^ w^ r. THOMPSON STONE GRANT WOOD Second Annual Fine Arts Festival State University of Iowa July 14.ia 1940 PROGRAM DAILY Monday to Thursday, July 15-18 Lectures, recitals, radio broadcasts, conferences, and seminars. All departments of the School of Fine Arts. Exhibition of contemporary American art, Iowa Union. Exhibition of painting and sculpture by students and alumni, Art Building. Special recorded programs, the new Iowa Union Music Room. Noon luncheons with addresses by distinguished guest artists and educators. Forum discussion. EVENINGS Sunday, July 14 The Damnation of Faust (in Concert Form) Berlioz University Chorus Soloists University Symphony Orchestra Conductor, Thompson Stone Monday, July 15 Concert, Summer Session Symphonic Band Conductor, Charles B. Righter All-State High School Chorus Conductor, Thompson Stone Play, University Theatre Directed by Professor E. C. Mabie and Staff Tuesday, July 16 , Chamber Music Concert String Quintet Woodwind Ensemble Strings with Piano Play, University Theatre Wednesday, July 17 Concert, All-State High School Symphony Orchestra Conductor, Charles B. Righter Play, University Theatre Thursday, July 18 Concert, University Summer Session Symphony Orchestra Conductor, Philip Greeley Clapp Play, University Theatre Note: A special University lecture will be presented Friday night, July 19. ART BUILDING MHUP GREELEY CLAPP LESTER D. LONGMAN CHARIJIS B. RIGHTER EDWARD C. MABIE MUSIC STUDIO BUILDING Published by the University, Iowa City, Iowa. Issued semi-weekly January 1 to May 31 and weekly June 1 to December 31. Entered at the post office at Iowa City, as second class matter under the Act of August 24, 1912. University of Iowa Libraries UNIVERSITY THEATRE

record.title: Insert back
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF IOWA Summer Session, June 8 - August 23 Paul C. Packer, Summer Session Director George F. Kay, Dean of College of Liberal Arts Earl Enyeart Harper, Director of School of Fine Arts DEPARTMENT OF ART Lester D. Longman, Head Jean Chariot, Grant Wood, Harry Stinson, Edna Patzig, Charles Okerbloom, Jr., Alden F. Megrew, Clifford Jones, Gail Martin. A comprehensive curriculum of undergraduate and graduate courses, including the history, theory, and practice of art, will be presented by members of the regular faculty of the Depart¬ ment of Art. Jean Chariot, as guest instructor, will teach classes in life and fresco painting. DEPARTMENT OF DRAMATIC ART E. C. Mabie, Head Thomas Wood Stevens, Frederic McConnell, Vance M. Morton, H. D. Sellman, William D. Coder, A. S. Gillette, Helen Forrest Lauterer, Wallace A. Goates, Peter Marroney, John G. Felton, Jr., Maurine Morgan, Lewis McFarland, Bess Whitcomb, John Ross Winnie. Members of the regular faculty of the Department of Dramatic Art will offer a full range of graduate and undergraduate courses during the Summer Session. Opportunity will be afforded for participation in plays and observation of direction and production. DEPARTMENT OF MUSIC Philip Greeley Clapp, Head Modeste Alloo, Thompson Stone, Charles B. Righter, Hans Koelbel, Arnold Small, Esther M. Swisher, Addison Alspach, Herald I. Stark, Thomas Muir, Otto Jelinek, Himie Voxman, Alan Richardson, Wendell Otey, H. C. Stump, Ansel Martin, Vivian M. Robe, Lorene Liston, William Gower, Thomas Collins, Emily Anthony, Dorothy Johnson, David Robert¬ son, Robert Titus, Hugh Gunderson, James Huff, Robert Gaskill, Eldon Obrecht, Thomas Turner, Charles Eble. The music faculty, including Modeste Alloo and Thompson Stone, will teach throughout the entire Summer Session. A full curriculum is offered in theoretical and applied music at the graduate and undergraduate levels with participation and teacher training in chorus, orchestra, band, and chamber music. A rare opportunity will be afforded to observe the daily work of the All-State High School musical organizations. FINE ARTS FESTIVAL COMMITTEE Earl Enyeart Harper, Philip Greeley Clapp, Frederic G. Higbee, Lester D. Longman, Edward C. Mabie, Bruce E. Mahan, Frederick M. Pownall, Charles B. Righter. For further information address Director of the School of Fine Arts, University of Iowa, Iowa City, Iowa. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Fine Arts Festival, University of Iowa, July 14-18, 1940
record.description: Festival included luncheon speakers featuring Jean Charlot, Modeste Alloo, and Thomas Wood Stevens; an exhibition of American paintings and etchings; graduate student art exhibitions; plays and musical performances.

record.full-text: the UNIVERSITY THEATRE SUMMER School of Fine Arts 1941 University of Iowa presents: 6 SUMMER PLAYS WHEN WE ARE MARRIED by J. B. Priestley A farcical comedy June 16, 17, 18, 19 and 20 LITTLE CLAY CART by King Shudraka An Oriental romance June 23, 24, 25, 26 and 27 GEORGE WASHINGTON SLEPT HERE A rollicking comedy June 30, July 1, 2, 3 and 4 FLIGHT TO THE WEST by Elmer Rice A stirring drama July 7, 8, 9, 10 and 11 THE WINTER'S TALE by William Shakespeare A romantic comedy July 14, 15, 16, 17 and 18 MY HEART'S IN THE HIGHLANDS by William Saroyan A fantastic comedy July 21, 22, 23, 24 and 25 SIX PLAYS THREE DOLLARS Subscribers will pay $3.00 for six plays. This makes the cost of each play 50c. All seats will be reserved. The price of single ad¬ missions will be $1.00. The purchaser of the season ticket there¬ fore makes a real saving. RESERVATION OF SEATS One week before each play seat reservations may be made at Room 8A Schaeffer Hall. Mail orders for out-of-town guest will be given special attention, at 8A Schaeffer Hall. They must be ac¬ companied by remittance. On the evenings of performances tickets will be available at the box office of the new Dramatic Arts Building on Riverside Drive. Seat reservations once made, will be exchanged gladly provided the ticket presented for exchange can be resold. Therefore, such re¬ served seat tickets should be exchanged a reasonable time in ad¬ vance of the date printed thereon. If presented after noon of the date printed thereon, the ticket will not be accepted for exchange. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 18
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: Summer Session Chorus Summer Session Orchestra Thompson Stone, Conductor jr The Dream of Gerontius by Sir Edward Elgar SOLOISTS DORIS BERGH, Contralto HERALD STARK, Tenor . . MARK LOVE, Baritone Sir Edward Elgar, upon commission to write a choral work for the Birmingham Festival, submitted his musical setting of Cardinal Newman's poem, "The Dream of Gerontius." It was accepted and received its first performance at Birmingham, on October 3, 1900, under the direction of Hans Richter. Cardinal Newman's famous poem, regarded as one of the greatest apocryphal poems in the English language, was discussed by vari¬ ous composeis with the view of setting it to music. Among them was Dvorak, who talked the matter over with the Cardinal in person. But it required special qualities of a composer who elected to undertake the task. He would have to be in emotional sym¬ pathy with the mystical suggestiveness of the poem and respond to its religious significance. Elgar was a Roman Catholic and understood the doctrines of the Church. Gerontius is the faith¬ ful Christian lying at the point of death. He makes his confes¬ sion of faith, heai's the chants of the prayers at his bed-side, dreams of his soul's transportation to the unknown beyond, its delivery to the Judgment Seat by its guardian angel and its purgatorial cleansing in preparation for its eternal happiness. "The Dream of Gerontius" is divided into two parts, and each part is an uninterrupted whole, without breaks or divisions into set musical numbers. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 19
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: PART I Gerontius Mr. Stark Assistants Chorus The Priest Mr. Love Gerontius Jesu, Maria—I am near to death, And thou art calling me; I know it now. Not by the token of this faltering breath, This chill at heart, this dampness on my brow,— (Jesu, have mercy! Mary, pray for mel) 'Tis this new feeling, never felt before, (Be with me, Lord, in my extremi- ty!) That f am going, that I am no more. 'Tis this strange innermost abandon¬ ment, (Lover of souls! great God! f look to Thee,) This emptying out of each constitu¬ ent And natural force, by which I come to be. Pray for me, O my friends; a visit¬ ant Is knocking his dire summons at my door. The like of whom, to scare me and to daunt. Has never, never come to me be¬ fore; So pray for me, my friends, who have not strength to pray. Assistants Kyrie eleison, Christe eleison, Kyrie eleison. Holy Mary, pray for him. All holy Angels, pray for him. Choirs of the righteous, pray for him. All Apostles, all Evangelists, pray for him. All holy Disciples of the Lord, pray for him. All holy Innocents, pray for him. All holy Martyrs, all holy Confess¬ ors. All holy Hermits, all holy Virgins, All ye Saints of God, pray for him. Gerontius Rouse thee, my fainting soul, and play the man; And through such waning span Of lite and thought as still has to be trod, Prepare to meet thy God. And ^vhile the storm of that bewil¬ derment Is tor a season spent, And, ere afresh the ruin on me fall. Use well the interval. Assistants Be merciful, be gracious; spare him. Lord. Be merciful, be gracious; Lord, de¬ liver him. From the sins that are past; From Thy frown and Thine ire; From the perils of dying; From any complying With sin, or denying His God, or relying On self, at the last; From the nethermost fire; From all that is evil; From power of the devil; Thy servant deliver. For once and for ever. By Thy birth, and by Thy Cross, Rescue him from endless loss; By Thy death and burial. Save him from a final fall; University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 20
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: By Thy rising from the tomb. By Thy mounting up above. By the Spirit's gracious love. Save him in the day of doom. Gerontius Sanctus tortis, Sanctus Deus, De profundis oro te. Miserere, Judex meus, Parce mihi, Domine. Firmly I believe and truly God is Three, and God is One; And I next acknoivledge duly Manhood taken by the Son. And I trust and hope most fully In that Manhood crucified; And each thought and deed unruly Do to death, as He has died. Simply to His Grace and wholly Light and life and strength be¬ long. And I love, supremely, solely. Him the holy, Him the strong. Sanctus tortis, Sanctus Deus, De profundis oro te. Miserere, Judex meus, Parce mihi, Domine. And I hold in veneration, For the love of Him alone, Holy Church, as His creation. And her teachings as His own. And I take with joy whatever Now besets me, pain or fear, And with a strong will I sever All the ties which bind me here. Adoration aye be given. With and through the angelic host. To the God of earth and heaven. Father, Son and Holy Ghost. Sanctus fortis, Sanctus Deus, De profundis oro te, Miserere, Judex meus. Mortis in discrimine. I can no more; tor no\v it comes again. That sense of ruin, which is worse than pain. That masterful negation and col¬ lapse Of all that makes me man. And, crueller still, A fierce and restless fright begins to fill The mansion of my soul. And, worse and worse, Some bodily form of ill Floats on the wind, with many a loathsome curse Tainting the hallowed air, and laughs, and flaps Its hideous wings, And makes me ^vild with horror and dismay. O Jesu, help! pray for me, Mary, pray! Some Angel, Jesu! such as came to Thee In Thine own agony .... Mary, pray for me. Joseph, pray for me. Mary, pray for me. Assistants Rescue him, O Lord, in this his evil hour. As of old so many by Thy gracious power: Noe from the waters in a saving home; (Amen.) Job from all his multiform and fell distress; (Amen.) Moses from the land of bondage and despair; (Amen.) David from Golia and the ivrath of Saul; (Amen.) —So, to shoiv Thy power. Rescue this Thy servant in his evil hour. Gerontius Novissima hora est; and I fain would sleep. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 22
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: Whether I hear, or touch, or taste the tones. Oh, what a heart-subduing melody! Angel My work is done. My task is o'er. And so I come. Taking it home, For the crown is won. Alleluia, For evermore. My Father gave In charge to me This child of earth E'en from its birth. To serve and save. Alleluia, And saved is he. This child ot clay To me was given. To rear and train By sorrow and pain In the narrow way. Alleluia, From earth to heaven. For speaking's sake. I wish to hold with thee Conscious communion; though I fain would knoiv A maze of things, were it but meet to ask. And not a curiousness. Angel You cannot now Cherish a wish which ought not to be wished. Soul Then I will speak. I ever had be¬ lieved That on the moment when the strug¬ gling soul Quitted its mortal case, forthwith it fell Under the awful Presence of its God, There to be judged and sent to its own place. What lets me now from going to my Lord? Soul It is a member of that family Of wondrous beings, who, ere the worlds were made. Millions of ages back, have stood around The throne of god. I will address him. Mighty one, my Lord, My Guardian Spirit, all hail! Angel All hail, my child! My child and brother, hail! what wouldest thou? Angel Thou art not let; but with extrem¬ es t speed Art hurrying to the Just and Holy Judge. Soul Dear Angel, say. Why have I now no fear at meeting Him? Along my earthly lite, the thought of death And judgment was to me most ter¬ rible. Soul I would have nothing but to speak with thee Angel It is because Then thou didst fear, that now thou dost not fear. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 23
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: Thou hast forestalled the agony, and so For thee the bitterness of death is passed. Also, because already in thy soul The judgment is begun. Angel A presage falls upon thee, as a ray Straight from the Judge, expiessi\'e of thy lot. That calm and joy uprising in thy soul Is first-fruit to thee ot thy recom¬ pense. And heaven begun. Soul Now that the hour is come, my fear is fled; And at this balance of my destiny, Now close upon me, I can forward look With a serenest joy. But hark! upon my sense Comes a fierce hubbub, which would make me fear Could I be frighted. Angel We are now arrived Close on the judgment-court; that sullen howl Is from the demons who assemble there. Hungry and wild, to claim their property. And gather souls for hell. Hist to their cry. Soul How sour and how uncouth a dis¬ sonance! Demons Low-born clods Of brute earth. They aspire To become gods. By a new birth. And an extra grace, And a score of merits. As it aught Could stand in place Of the high thought. And the glance of fire Of the great spirits. The powers bless, The lords by right. The primal oivners, Of the proud dwelling And realm of light,— Dispossessed, Aside thrust. Chucked down. By the sheer might Of a despot's will, Of a tyrant's frown. Who after expelling Their hosts, gave. Triumphant still, And still unjust, Each forfeit crown To psalm-droners, And canting groaners. To every slave. And pious cheat. And crawling knave. Who licked the dust Under his feet. Angel It is the restless panting ot their being; Like beasts of prey, who, caged with¬ in their bars. In a deep hideous purring have their life. And an incessant pacing to and fro. Demons The mind bold And independent, The purpose free. So we are told, Must not think To have the ascendant. What's a saint? University of Iowa Libraries

record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: One whose breath Doth the air taint Before his death; A bundle ot bones. Which fools adore. Ha! ha! When life is o'er. Virtue and vice, A knave's pretence. 'Tis all the same; Hal ha! Dread ot hell-fire, Of the venomous flame, A coward's plea. Give him his price. Saint though he be. Ha! ha! From shrewd good sense He'll slave for hire; Hal hal And does but aspire To the heaven above With sordid aim. And not from love. Hal ha! Soul I see not those false spirits; shall I see My dearest Master, when I reach His throne? Angel Yes,—for one moment thou shalt see thy Lord. One moment; but thou knowest not, my child. What thou dost ask: that sight of the Most Fair Will gladden thee, but it will pierce thee too. Soul Thou speakest darkly, Angell and an awe Falls on me, and a fear lest I be rash. Angel There was a mortal, who is now above In the mid glory: he, when near to die, Was given communion with the Cru¬ cified,— Such, that the Master's very wounds were stamped Upon his flesh; and, from the agony AVhich thrilled through body and soul in that embrace. Learn that the flame of the Ever¬ lasting Love Dotli burn ere it transform. Choir of Aiigelicals Praise to the Holiest in the height, And in the depth be praise: Angel Hark to those sounds! They come of tender beings angelic¬ al. Least and most childlike of the sons of God. Choir of Angelicals Praise to the Holiest in the height, And in the depth be praise: In all His words most wonderful; Most sure in all His ways! To us His elder race He gave To battle and to win, \Vithout the chastisement ot pain, Without the soil ot sin. The younger son He willed to be A marvel in his birth: Spirit and fresh His parents were; His home was heaven and earth. The Eternal blessed His child, and armed. And sent Him hence afar. To serve as champion in the field Ot elemental war. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 25
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: To be His Viceroy in the world Of matter, and of sense; Upon the frontier, towards the foe, A resolute defence. A ngel We now have passed the gate, and are within The House of Judgment. Soul The sound is like the rushing ot the wind— The summer wind—among the lofty pines. Choir of Angelicals Glory to Him, who evermore By truth and justice reigns; Who tears the soul from out its case. And burns away its stainsl A ngel They sing of thy approaching agony, Which thou so eagerly didst ques¬ tion ot. O loving wisdom of our God! When all was sin and shame, h. second Adam to the fight And to the rescue came. O wisest love! that flesh and blood Which did in Adam fail. Should strive afresh against the foe. Should strive and should prevail; And that a higher gift than grace Should flesh and blood refine, God's Presence and His very Self, And Essence all divine. O generous love! that He who smote In man for man the foe. The double agony in man For man should undergo; And in the garden secretly. And on the cross on high. Should teach His brethren and in¬ spire To suffer and to die. Praise to the Holiest in the height. And in the depth be praise: In all His words most wonderful; Most sure in all His ways! Soul My soul is in my hand: I have no fear,— But hark! a grand mysterious har¬ mony: It floods me, like the deep and sol¬ emn sound Of many waters. Angel Thy judgment now is near, for we are come Into the veiled presence of our God. Soul I hear the voices that I left on earth. Angel And now the threshold, as we trav¬ erse it. Utters aloud its glad responsive chant. Choir of Angelicals Praise to the Holiest in the height. And in the depth be praise: In all His ^vords most ivonderful; Most sure in all His ways! Angel It is the voice of friends around thy bed, ^Vho say the "Subvenite" with the priest. Hither the echoes come; before the Throne Stands the great Angel ot the Ag¬ ony, The same -.vho strengthened Him, what time He knelt University of Iowa Libraries

record.full-text: Lone in the garden shade, bedeived with blood. That Angel best can plead ^vith Him for all Tormented souls, the dying and the dead. Angel of the Agony Jesu! by that shuddering dread which fell on Thee; Jesu! by that cold dismay which sickened Thee; Jesu! by that pang ot heart which thrilled in Thee; Jesu! by that amount of sins which crippled Thee; Jesu! by that sense of guilt which stifled Thee; Jesu! by that innocence which gir¬ dled Thee; Jesu! by that sanctity ivhich reigned in Thee; Jesu! by that Godhead which was one with Thee; Jesu! spare these souls which are so dear to Thee, Souls, who in prison, calm and pa¬ tient, wait for Thee; Hasten, Lord, their hour, and bid them come to Thee, To that glorious Home, where they shall ever gaze on Thee. Soul I go before my Judge. Voices on Earth Be merciful, be gracious; spare him. Lord. Be merciful, be gracious; Lord de¬ liver him. Angel Praise to His name! O happy, suffering soul! for it is safe. Consumed, yet quickened, by the glance of God. Soul Take me away, and in the loivest deep There let me be. And there in hope the lone night- ivatches keep, Told out for me. There, motionless and happy in my pain. Lone, not forlorn,— There will I sing, and soothe my strain. Until the morn. There will I sing, and soothe my stricken breast. Which ne'er can cease To throb, and pine, and languish, till possest Of its Sole Peace. There will I sing my absent Lord and Love: Take me away. That sooner I may rise, and go above. And see Him in the truth of ever¬ lasting day. Souls in Purgatory Lord, Thou hast been our refuge: in every generation; Before the hills were born, and the world was: from age to age Thou art God. Bring us not. Lord, very low: tor Thou hast said. Come back again, ye sons of Adam. Come back, O Lord; how long: and be entreated for Thy servants. Angel Softly and gently, dearly-ransomed soul. In my most loving arms I now enfold thee. And o'er the penal waters, as they roll, I poise thee, and I lower thee, and hold thee. And carefully I dip thee in the lake, University of Iowa Libraries

record.full-text: And thou, without a sob or a re¬ sistance, Dost through the flood thy rapid passage take, Sinking deep, deeper, into the dim distance. Angels, to ivhom the willing task is given. Shall tend, and nurse, and lull thee, as thou liest; And Masses on the earth, and prayers in heaven, Shall aid thee at the Throne of the Most Highest. Farewell, but not for ever! brother dear. Be brave and jDatient on thy bed of sorrow; Swiftly shall pass thy night of trial here, And I will come and wake thee on the morrow. Souls Lord, thou has been our refuge, etc. Amen. record.full-text: PROGRAM Symphony No. 4 ("Romantic") in E flat major Anton Bruckner (1824-1896) Ruhig bewegt Andante Scherzo Finale Anton Bruckner was the eldest child among eleven in the family ot a hard¬ working and underpaid village schoolmaster. He was educated—perhaps it were better to say that he was trained—in the monastery ot St. Florian in pre¬ paration for a similar career. 1 he existence of an excellent organist in the monastery early gave a tangible focus to musical pre-occuj^ations in the mind ot young Bruckner which in his native environment might never have found any other outlet. By dint of iiard work and great frugality he somehow managed to amass a tiny sum which enabled hira to seek musical instruction in Vienna at an age of thirty. Rustic and uncouth in personality, he was at first the butt of ridicule from an examiriing committee consisting of five musical scholars of Vienna; but when the examiners had set before him what they hoped would be an impossibly difficult subject for the improvisation ot a fugue on the organ his performance was so masterly that an examiner re¬ marked "He should be teaching us." By dint of grim determination and the acceptance of poor financial re¬ wards, Bruckner managed to remain in Vienna for the rest of his life; he never was adequately paid, and undoubtedly the most comfortable material circum¬ stances he ever enjoyed were after his retirement, when royalty ^vas interested to assure him a modest living and comfortable quarters in which to continue his composition. His career was a prolonged struggle for recognition under extra¬ ordinarily adverse conditions. The musical taste ot Vienna then was practically dictated by Eduard Hanslick, the leading opponent of Wagner, an opponent armed ^vith a pen as vitriolic as Wagner's own. \Vagner's new type of opera was unwelcome to Hanslick; an innate incompatibility of Hanslick's temperament with Wagner's style was undoubtedly aggravated by the fact that Wagner had snubbed Hanslick socially. Hanslick ^vrote reviews, pamphlets, and finally an entire book to prove that \Vagner's compositions could not properly be defined as music at all; Wagner retaliated by lampooning Hanslick in Die Meistersinger. Hanslick was obliged to produce a post-Beethoven symphonist to refute Wagner and conveniently "discovered" the youthful Brahms. The Wagnerites of course had to find a rival contemporary symphonist, and in turn conveniently "dis¬ covered" Bruckner. Probably Bruckner was the sanest individual connected with the contro- vei-sy. On one occasion, ^vhen someone asked him how he could bear Hanslick's disparagement of his works and praise of Brahms', Bruckner remarked "He does not really understand Brahms any better than he luiderstands me." Bruckner's "Romantic" Symphony is the only one to which he himself apjjended a descriptive title, although such titles have been suggested for his other symphonies by those who appreciate his genius. There is always a strong element of dramatic and poetic characterization in Bruckner, though his rather homely attempts to name or classify this poetic content in colloquial speech are not al\vays happ)'. Anyone who is responsive both to music and to the influence ot such scenes of beauty in nature as siuiomid Vienna should be at no loss to understand the term "romantic" as applied to this symphony. INTERMISSION "Venus and Adonis," Symphonic Poem (First performance) Ralph Dale Miller (1909- ) Mr. Miller was born at Whitehall, Illinois, in 1909. He w.as educated in the public schools of Bloomington and Peoria, Illinois, the Illinois State Normal University (B.E. 1936), and the State University of Iowa (M.A. 1939). At various times he has been a professional player of trinnpet, and teacher or supervisor in Pontiac and Normal, Illinois. His Rural Sketches has been widely performed by college and high school bands. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 41
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: Venus and Adonis is based upon Shakespeare's poetic version ot the Greek myth. Venus woos in vain the fair mortal youth, Adonis, whose love is not for woman but for the hunt. Despite her pleadings, he rushes away to hunt a wild boar which eventually slays him. After a frenzied search, the goddess finds his lifeless body in the forest, his blood drenching the earth. While she passionately mourns him his body vanishes and is replaced by a beautiful flower which she plucks and places in her bosom. "A Southern Iowa Suite" for Orchestra (First complete performance) Robert O. Barkley (1898- ) Comshuckers' Dance Sunday Evening in Bloomfield Coimty Fair Mr. Barkley was born at Moulton, Iowa, in 1898. After graduating from the Moulton High School in 1915 he moved with his parents to Des Moines and entered Drake University. For se\eral years he played in Chautauqua and Lyceum work which carried him into every state in the Union and into Canada. At first he planned to be a professional violinist, but later completed at the State University of Iowa his studies for the B.A. degree, which he re¬ ceived in 1923. A high school appointment in Rochester, New York, enabled him to study at the Eastman School ot Music with Eugene Goossens, Albert Coates, and Gustave Tinlot. In 1927 he became Director of Music at Sault Ste. Marie, Michigan. In 1932 he entered the Summer Session ot the University of Iowa (M.A. 1935). In 1936 he assumed charge of the large music depart¬ ment of the public schools ot Wilkinsburg, Pennsyhania. He has composed in various forms for various media. The Southern loioa Suite, has recently received the Second Prize in a recent competition for symphonic works by native composers sponsored by the National Symphony Orchestra Association of Washington, D.C., and one movement has already been performed by that Orchestra under the conductorship of its permanent leader, Hans Kindler. The performance this evening is the first j^ublic performance of the entire com¬ position. Mr. Barkley has furnished a very complete account ot the composition and content of his suite, unfortunately too long for complete quotation here, but as racy and enjoyable as the music itself. A few excerpts follow: — "The scenes from this suite represent actual pages from the boyhood life of the composer. The times and melodies are aiuhentic, or else based on authentic and characteristic folksongs and old fiddler tunes ot the region. Bloomfield, Iowa, was the childhood metropolis of this ivriter .... 'Sunday in Bloomfield' was a real and memorable event in his life as a high school boy .... Opening with a friendly bell-ringing contest between the rival sextons of the Methodist and Presbyterian churches, the sultry calm ot the summer Sunday evening is disturbed only by the solitary call of a meadow lark .... Worship begins with an old-time gospel hymn. The thin and reedy bass voices of two pillars of the 'official board' is heard. The somnolent spell ot the hymn is bioken by a group of young hotbloods from Missouri, who come racing madly past the chinch, honking the horn of their Model T Ford and upsetting the service no end. They are slightly inebriated and are appar¬ ently looking for trouble. They get it ... . After this disturbance the service comes to a close, as the local boys line up alongside the church steps, ready to escort the girls on their circinnambulatory way home .... "Similarly, the first and third movements represent other pages from the life of the composer. In the first movement, the Comshuckers' Dance, the listener witnesses the wide-eyed ivonder of the high school boy attending his fii-st barn-dance and being struck dumb with amazement at the clomping and strutting of the heavy-footed 'farm-hands' as they follow the merry strains of the Arkansas Traveler and the Devil's Dream .... "The third movement. County Fair, is a kaleidoscope of events and im¬ pressions. In the opening part a 'Silver Cornet Band' contends with the merry-go-round for the attention of the crowd of farmers and townspeople .... There is a 'Midway', brightly it fitfully lighted by flickering gasoline torches, assisted by festoons of the new-tangled carbon-filament electric lamps. University of Iowa Libraries

record.title: Page 42
record.digital-collection: University of Iowa Art Festival Programs
record.full-text: The sideshow spielers bawl raucously at the crowd, their remarks being punc¬ tuated by the maternal mooing of frustrated bossy cows and the whinny of horses .... A fire breaks out in the poultry barn .... There is a good bit of raillery which finally causes fists to fly. It is much too hot to do any real fighting, however, and events move noisily but pacifically to the grand climax of the fair: the harness races .... few running races but a great number ot both trotting and pacing races. "The composer has attempted in this work to catch and retain the flavor and aroma of an era which has nearly passed away—an era in which the pioneer spirit still held sway—only to come to an abrupt end with the first World War." -P. G. C. record.full-text: Third Annual Fine Arts Festival PROGRAM The Annual Fine Arts Festival at the State University o£ Iowa is a unique and significant event. It is tiniqtie because it brings together in one festival concerts of the highest order; attractive exhibitions of painting and sculpture; dramatic productions staged under ideal conditions; and lectures, discussions, and demonstrations ranging throtigh all the fields of the fine arts. It is significant because it makes public presentation of an educational program in the fine arts which has won nation-wide note. During the Stimmer Session the School of Fine Arts adds to its regular faculty distinguished guest artists. A full range of graduate and undergraduate courses is offered, which carry full credit toward the various degrees conferred by the University. Guest-artist faculty members who will teach and assist in preparations for the Fine Arts Festival in the Summer Session of 1941 include Thomas Wood Stevens, Frederic McConnell, and Mrs. Fairfax P. Walkup in the Department of Dramatic Art; Fletcher Martin in the Department of Art; and Thotnpson Stone and Modeste Alloo in the Department of Music. The Summer Session Symphony Orchestra, the Summer Session Chorus, the Summer Session Symphonic Band, and the Chamber Mtisic Ensembles have established themselves as brilliant and versatile musical organizations. The All-State High School Symphony Orchestra and Chorus draw their membership from sttidents who have won high ranking in high school musical organizations throughout the state and who spend five weeks on the University campus preparing the concerts which they play and sing during the festival. In the Theatre, casts of students produce plays worthy of comparison 'ivith professional produc¬ tions. Among these sttidents are men and women of great talent, in many instances profession¬ ally experienced, who have come to the State University of Iowa to pursue graduate and pro¬ fessional studies in dramatic art. Three art exhibitions will be presented during the 1941 festival. One of these will be an ex¬ hibition of paintings and sculptured works by alumni and students of the University, several of whom have won recognition in professional exhibitions. The campus of the University, rising from the valley to the heights on either side of the Iowa River, is a scene of beauty. The buildings of the School of Fine Arts represent architectural achievement of a high order, perfectly adapted to the functions for which they are designed. The Iowa Union and the Theatre, where concerts and plays are presented and where all major gath¬ erings of the Fine Arts Festival are held, are equipped with modern air-conditioning machinery. Whether you come to the campus of the State University of Iowa for the week of the Fine Arts Festival or to take advantage of the entire Summer Session, yoti will find educational offerings and inspirational experiences which will prove memorable. July 13-17, 1941 Daily Monday through Thursday, July 14-17 Lectures, recitals, radio broadcasts, conferences and seminars. All departments of the School of Fine Arts and radio station WSUI. Walt Disney Retrospective Exhibition, Art Building. Exhibition of painting and sculpture by alumni and students. Art Building. Contemporary art of 79 countries (exhibition of the International Business Machines Corporation at the San Francisco Fair), Iowa Union. Recorded programs and special radio broadcasts, Iowa Union Music Room. Forum discussions led by distinguished guest artists and educators. record.title: Fine Arts Festival, University of Iowa, July 13-17, 1941
record.description: Festival included panel discussions featuring Lester D. Longman, Thomas Wood Stevens, Arnold Small, Philip Greeley Clapp, Fletcher Martin, W. D. Coder, E. C. Mabie, Thompson Stone, and Horst Janson; an exhibition of contemporary art of seventy-nine countries; retrospective exhibition of the Walt Disney Medium; lectures, a play and musical performances.
